speechtext:
There seems to be no provision in this section for second and third offences. It seems to me that when a proprietor wants to engage in the luxury of continuing the habit of selling goods under weight, he should be made to pay the price. I suggest that after the words " twenty-five dollars " at the end of the section, the following words be added:
for the first offence, and $100 for the second or any subsequent offence of the same nature.
We should not permit any one to continue this practice without bringing him to book rather sharply. A fine of $25 ma.y be

sufficient for the first offence, but if a merchant becomes an habitual offender, the law ought to reach him in a more drastic way. I would also suggest that there be inserted in the section some provision whereby it should be declared definitely and conclusively that the section in no way interferes with the provisions of the Criminal Code respecting false pretences, and I move that the section be amended to read:
61A. Notwithstanding the provisions of section 405 of the Criminal Code, any person who sells, delivers or causes to be sold or delivered anything by weight, measure or number short of the quantity ordered or purchased, shall be guilty of an offence and liable to a fine not exceeding $25 for such first offence and $100 for any subsequent offence under this section.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
But under this measure, any person may at any time be subjected to petty annoyances. An instance has been cited this afternoon of a number of bags of sugar having been weighed up and exposed for sale, the weights not all being uniform. As the human ' element is not as exact as some mechanical device for measuring, if some customer of a merchant purchased one of those bags and it happened to be short weight, that particular merchant would, under this measure, be liable to a penalty of $25. That is placing the merchant in a very unfair position, and it should not be the attitude of this Committee to place the mercantile community of the country in a position of this kind. I have many employees labouring for me distributing merchandise. How can I control all their actions? I employ the best help I can obtain, and I warn them 
to be careful in their actions as regards matters of this nature, but if they are careless, then I am not only held responsible, but subjected to the petty annoyance of being hauled up before a magistrate and exposed to the odium of being fined for their carelessness. They are not fined, but I am.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
If the section were to be amended as the hon. member suggests, there would be very little protection for the public. If a dealer has careless employees in his store and they grow accustomed to delivering short weight or short measure, that employer should suffer the penalty. Further, I do not think those in mercantile business will object to this see-
4 p.m. tion, because it is for the protection of the man who is careful and honest as well, in measuring or weighing the goods which he sells to his customers. My hon. friend would be surprised if he knew of the great quantities of goods delivered in this country which are actually short weight. It would be impossible to establish knowledge on the part of the principal, and it is not a difficult matter to deliver proper weights. The delivering of short weight or short measure is due to carelessness or dishonesty against both of which the public should be protected. If short weights were delivered by any merchant and that fact came to the attention of the officers of the department, the merchant would not be prosecuted for the first offence; he would be warned and consideration would be given to his reputation in the community, the character of his staff and so on. I quite agree with my hon. friend that the section might be abused, but I do not see how the public can be protected in any other way.
. Mr. JACOBS: I might come to the assistance of the minister by pointing out

that under the Liquor License law, the fact that liquor was sold is sufficient to justify a conviction, whether the owner knew of the matter or not.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
In penalizing it is always dangerous to go further than the common law, which has well considered what is criminal and what is not, and enters into the philosophy of the condition of mind of those .who may be charged with crime. When we remove the safeguards . provided by the common law and constitute a crime regardless of the state of mind of the individual, we are on very dangerous ground. We passed a law the other day whereby, if a lady put a pan of bread into the oven in too big a fire, and the bread should burn, she is liable to two years in the penitentiary. That is extraordinary, but it is the law to-day that if by negligence any person makes a fire which destroys property of any kind he is liable to be sent to the penitentiary. Now we are coming forward with another law by which, if a pound of tea is one-thousandth of an ounce short in weight a man may be fined 825, or, according to the amendment, $100 for a second offence. It is better to err on the side of mercy and fairness, and it is better that the responsi-

bility should be thrown on the Crown to prove wilful intent, than to make it easy to punish people. We should not neglect the time-honoured principle of the common law that there must be criminal	intent in	order	to render aperson criminally liable, and I fully agree with	the	hon. member who
insists that the word "wilful" should be inserted. If this word were added I would have no great fault to find. I do not think that the store-keeper could be criminally liable for a sale made by his clerk. He would be civilly liable in damages for the quality of the goods and for any shortage or inferiority. My view of the criminal law is that the master is not liable criminally unless there is criminal intent on his part. Of course, if he instructs his servant to do an illegal act he is responsible through his agent and is parti ceps criminis. I think the whole difficulty might be circumvented by adding the word "wilful." It is better that the department should experience some difficulty than that people should be fined and imprisoned who are not really criminally liable.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
I do not want the hon. member for Frontenac to put words into my mouth. Not for a moment did I suggest that it was all right for such people to live together. I was not discussing morals but law, and it is in that respect that my friend no doubt misunderstood me.
I said that adultery, at least in Ontario and Quebec, had never been recognized as a crime. The hon. member may be quite right in saying that it should be made a criminal offence, but if we are going to make it such let us do so in a direct way and not set traps for people. What I said was that so long as the law of Canada did not recognize adultery as a crime, I thought it was unreasonable that those who were living together openly as man and wife should be made criminals simply because they went to a hotel, lodging house, or boarding house and represented themselves as being married. I object to setting traps for people who are innocently-if I may use that word without giving offence to the hon. member for Frontenac-doing something they would have a right to do under the general law of the country but which becomes an offence when they register at a hotel or. boarding house, or represent themselves as having a certain status which they have not.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: I am not a lawyer. I am looking at the interpretation of this clause from a common sense standpoint, and there is a difference sometimes between legal interpretations and common sense. Suppose I were to introduce a Bill and it were to become law-(although there is not the slightest chance of that-penalizing a lawyer for advising a client that he has got a good case in court, whereas he has not a leg to stand on. It would be just as reasonable for me, if I were Minister of Justice, to press through a Bill of that kind as it is to pass legislation of the character contemplated here. What a storm there would be in the House if I were to attempt, as a legal adviser of the Government, to pass a Bill of that nature. It is all very well to say that the officers of the department will not be unduly exacting, but under this Bill, as I read i,t, it will be open to the individual- purchaser to institute proceedings. It does not state that it is necessary for an official of the department to prosecute. Any Tom, Dick or Harry who goes into a store and buys a package of merchandise is able to take action before the magistrate, and we all know how human are magistrates in administering justice. It all depends on the state of their liver. If they have been out late the night before and are feeling the effects, we all know what kind of a deal they are likely to hand out. As a matter of fact, I have known many magistrates decide cases before they heard the evidence.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
We have a moral law to observe in Canada as well as a criminal law. There may be sympathy coming to the man and woman who live as man and wife before they are married, but I have not heard any reason expressed for such sympathy. The most binding law which should be observed in the world to-day is a law not enacted by this Parliament. If there is no law on the Statute Book prohibiting one of the greatest crimes that is

taking place in this Dominion to-day, I think it is about time such a law was enacted. For my part I cannot let the opportunity pass without voicing my disapproval of it.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
I am still sorry that the minister is obdurate, unconvinced. He says

that complaints are from time to time coming in to the department, and I have no doubt of that, but am sure, when the department investigates the basis of the complaints, it will find that in the majority of cases they are without foundation and fact, and that the actual cases of short weights and offences of that kind are infinitesimal. No business man could continue long in business if he habitually delivered short weights and measures. According to this legislation one would think that the mercantile people of this country were a crowd of thugs, robbers and criminals, and that a wall had to be built round the public for their protection, as if the public were not capable of protecting themselves. From my experience, I have no hesitation
5 p.m. in saying that should customers be given short weights or measures they very quickly go back to the store and demand their pound of flesh, and I do not think the minister is well advised in acting the part of Shylock in asking that this section pass. It may be not only the pound of flesh, but some of the heart's blood along with it, and it was the latter to which Portia objected so well. I move:-
That section 61A be amended by inserting the word " knowingly " after the word " who " in the first line.
The principle underlying this amendment is admitted by the minister; it covers the point of carelessness, which is all that this Committee should be concerned in. If a man deliberately, habitually, commits this offence, then he should be penalized, but as the section now reads, if the action is only casual, occurring once in a while, he is liable to a penalty.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: We have discussed that principle pretty thoroughly, and I hope my hon. friend does not want to press the amendment. The sense of the Committee is, I think, that the section would be absolutely of no use if the word " knowingly " were inserted.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: I might also mention the case where a married man represents to a woman that he is unmarried and then marries her, committing bigamy. The woman who might be perfectly innocent would be liable under this section.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speakerposition: Minister of the Interior; Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs
speechtext:
The amendment suggested by the hon. member for Kingston and the suggestion of the hon. member for North Grey, have come to my attention only this afternoon. With regard to the latter suggestion, from the momentary consideration I have been able to give it, it might well be that innocent persons, man or woman, might be prosecuted if the innocent one was at the time under the belief that he or she was legally married. I think the suggestion is worthy of a few moments' consideration by the Committee. The latter remark applies also to the amendment suggested by the hon. member for Kingston. The amendment, however, would be more easily accessible to abuse for the reason that it suggests no time over which the open living together as man and wife must have continued before it shall constitute relief from the penalties imposed by the Act.
I would like the members to express their views particularly on the amendment and on the suggestion of the hon. member for Grey (Mr. Middlebro).

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: I have no sympathy with, and I do not care to afford any protection to any man and woman who are living together in open adultery in this country. It may be permitted, but certainly it is in violation of everything we regard as good citizenship and good morals. Although perhaps we have not provided any direct law to punish it, we undoubtedly should not throw any protection around it". If any man and woman coming to Canada -have not yet been married, or have had no opportunity of being married, they can be married in Canada and should immediately comply with the law. I am not in sympathy with the amendment and do not think it should be accepted.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
This Bill was before the House last year and was considered rather hastily I am afraid. In the Senate, where perhaps, if not wiser, there are older heads than in this House, they look at matters with that detached attitude which in questions of this kind is essential, they came to the conclusion that the entire Bill was useless, that it was provocative of blackmail and other offences of that nature, and consequently they failed to pass it. In view of that I do not consider it wise to send the Bill again to the Senate this year. 'This Bill was, as I understand, prepared and drafted by some association for the propagation of morality generally. It is not a request coming from any well recognized body, nor is public opinion, I venture to say, in favour of it. In view of all these '.circumstances I do not think it should form part of our law, particularly as we have, as I said before, a sufficient number of provisions of this kind in the Criminal Code to act as a drag-net for people desirous of committing offences against morality. As a matter of fact, I think we have too many of these measures already and they are not sufficiently carried out on account of that very reason perhaps. I am against the clause as amended and intend to so vote.
Section as amended carried.
Bill reported.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
There is no doubt the matters discussed by the hon. member for Lunenburg could be discussed on the Estimates; but I think when the Acting Prime Minister considers that he has himself admitted that the hon. member is quite in order in bringing them up on this Bill, it is on this Bill that the answer should be made, because when the minister comes along CSir Thomas White.]
with his Estimates, it will then be necessary for the hon. member to make his speech over again and put those facts before the minister in connection with another matter. We want to avoid that and to save time.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: If my hon. friend had been Minister of Trade and Commerce, instead of being minister of all trades in the present Government, he would have seen that the Voyageur sailed from a Canadian port to a foreign port. I repeat, Mr. Chairman, and I am in earnest, we have done practically nothing. I know, of course, that our export trade during the war has wonderfully increased, but this was due to our war industries, and there is an end to those industries. To-day we must revert to peace trade and peace activities, and long before peace was declared an anny of commercial agents from England and the United States were marching through many countries in order to capture as much as possible of their trade. I am told that Mr. Hoover himself, although his mission was to feed the Central Empires, has captured the blue ribbon for the United States, having secured enormous orders for American concerns. But Canada has done nothing at all.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
How many are there in Canada?
Major-General MEWBURN: In the various hospitals in Canada close on to 14,000. A very large number of those men, if they do not require any further treatment in the military medical hospitals, will be discharged, and will come under the Department of Soldiers' Civil Re-Establishment for vocational training, and so on. Referring to, the amount that is required out of this particular vote, it is purely and simply to complete the pay and allowances, and deferred pay and war gratuity for the troops that are on active service. We estimate that ff we have no setbacks, our troops will be brought back from overseas by August. There may be some hospital staffs and other details remain for a further period, but by the end of this year, I have every expectation, the whole of these staff's will be cut down to the very lowest minimum, and nobody will be retained except to carry out the problems of cleaning up. I believe we shall enter upon next year with a very small staff both at Headquarters and in the military districts. I am quite satisfied of that. I think if my hon. friend would' look at these items on the page referred to, he will see that they have nothing

to do with the future upkeep of the militisl and are not intended for military purposes in Canada beyond actual necessary cleaning-up purposes.
' Mr. LEMIEUX: So the expression used here, " Defence and security of Canada ", has reference only to the war situation?
, Major-General MEWBURN:	Only to
that.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
While we are upon this
subject, I would like to draw the minister's attention to a phase of military life which has been brought out in a letter received by me to-day from a soldier's father. Speaking in regard to his son, the writer says:
He enlisted at London, Ontario, in December 1915, went to England in January 1916, and to Prance in June 1916, and has been there on active service ever since, while his wife and child are with us. The Canadian Authorities in Division One, London, Ont., took the initiative in the signing up of the boys conducting their medical examination, etc. They advised them to enlist in the Imperial Mechanical Transport, as the C.E.F. at that time did not need any more recruits. They took their advice. Had my son signed up with the C.E.F., he on discharge would have been entitled to $100 per month for six months, a total of $600. Instead of that the B.E.F. will only grant $75 all told, a difference of $525.
Now since this Bill, as it is worded, refers purely to the demobilization of Canadian soldiers, I thought it would be an opportune time to ask the minister whether he intends in the expenditure of these moneys to provide to the extent of $525 for the war gratuity of a young Canadian soldier who is married and has a wife and child? If the minister intends to do nothing in that direction, will he make representations, if such may be proper, to the Imperial authorities to influence them to act equitably to this young man who was misled, according tQ my information, by the officers of the minister's department 'at London. On inquiry, I find that there are overseas many hundreds of Canadian young men who have gone to the front in some capacity or other, having either transferred to, or enlisted directly in this country in, the Imperial Forces. If the Imperial Government are doing nothing for these young men, I want the minister to tell me whether he intends to do anything for them, and whether this fund will be available for that purpose? If the minister replies in the negative, I would say that I would be rather ashamed to live in the country if such inequity should be passed out to these young men who fought for their King and country as Canadians
in the Imperial Army. I take this opportunity of asking the minister whether he has considered the matter, and if he has not done so, to state, if he can, that he will consider it and that he will look favourably upon the application which I am making on behalf of these men.
Major-General MEWBURN: The subject which the hon. member has raised has certainly been given a good deal of consideration, particularly of late. The war gratuity does not apply to such a man as the hon. gentleman has referred to, hut I may say that some little time ago suggestions and claims came from different soldiers regarding the war gratuity, a few of the class are Imperial army reservists, who, when the war began, left Canada and rejoined their units. The claim has been made that those men should participate in this war gratuity, or be paid the difference between what they received from the Imperial Government and what Canada is giving. There were also pensioners resident in Canada who returned to England and re-enlisted-I am speaking of British pensioners, on whose behalf application was made; likewise, men who especially enlisted in Canada in the British Army Service Corps and the Royal Engineers ; men who enlisted in Canada and the United States (British subjects), and Canadians who enlisted while overseas in the Imperial Forces.
I may say for the information of my hon. friend that a committee has been working on this for the last week, and while it is not a Committee of the House, I understand, unofficially, that several hon. members who have had those matters brought before them have been meeting and are drafting a memorandum, which I believe they are giving to the Government, and I know it includes such items as those. Whether the Government can see their way to concede those or some other items, I am not prepared to say. But there are a great many hardships. A great many Canadians I know joined the Imperials, and a'large number of university graduates went over to England and took commissions. I understand the Imperial Government are giving very much larger gratuities to officers than the Canadian Government, but not anything like what we are giving to the rank and file. But that matter is having our most serious consideration.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speakerposition: Parliamentary Under Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Will the Northwest
Mounted Police who were reservists be included? I happened to travel on the same

train when they were going overseas, and among them was Michael O'Leary, who later won the V.C. They were very anxious to return to Canada after the war, and hoped to -have a stake in the country when they came back.
Major-General MEWBURN: That particular man, I think, is in the Canadian Expeditionary Force.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
Lieut. R.N.C.V.R.
Now, Mr. Chairman, I think that under the circumstances, and having regard to what I have said, there should be a full and complete investigation into naval affairs in Canada during the last four years. Furthermore, I have no hesitation in saying that owing to the black eye which has been administered to the navy, it is too late now to endeavour to do anything to put naval affairs in Canada on a satisfactory basis. At the time of the Soudanese war, when the question of sending help
to Britain was discussed in this Parliament, Sir John A. Macdonald used the expression: " Not a dollar, not a man." I repeat that statement [DOT] now without any hesitation. I say in all seriousness that Canada should not spend one dollar on naval matters for the next few years at least. One reason is that our financial condition will not warrant it, and even if we wished to do so we could not vote sufficient money to build or to purchase naval boats which would be Of any service in time of trouble.
Because of its inefficiency, the Naval Department at Ottawa should be closed up, the officers in charge of it should be paid off and the offices closed. Canada has nothing to lose by doing this, and a large amount of money would be saved the taxpayers.
In my opinion Parliament can do only one of two things: Appropriate $100,000,000 at least, to build and equip an efficient navy, or else not spend one dollar. I do not think that in our present financial condition we can afford to spend the large amount which I have mentioned; consequently I say that not one dollar should be spent and not one man engaged at the present time under the excuse and pretence that we are doing something for naval affairs in this country. Sell off the useless trawlers, drifters and patrol boats, clear up the mes£ and make the * best of a bad job.
It might be said, of course, that we have the naval bases at Halifax and Esquimalt, and that they should be kept up. My answer to that is this: If the British Government require Halifax and Esquimalt for naval bases and for coaling purposes, they should take them over and operate them at their own expense. We certainly cannot do it, and I have no hesitation in asking that the whole idea be abandoned.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
(Questions answered orally are indicated
by an asterisk.)

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
A message from His Excellency the Governor General transmitting Supplementary
Estimates for the year ending March 31, 1919, was presented by Sir Thomas White (Minister of Finance), read by Mr. Speaker to the House, and referred to the Committee of Supply.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
I am very pleased indeed with the explanation given by the Minister of Militia as to what he intends to do regarding militia matters, and it is interesting to know that he has already appointed a committee of eminent soldiers who during the next twelve months will visit the different militia districts and get information to enable him to lay a concrete proposition before the House next session. I understood from his remarks that these three gentlemen are military men. I have no objection to their appointment, but I would suggest for his consideration that he also appoint to that committee at least one business man. It seems to me that the matter should not be left entirely in the hands of men who have served in the army or who are officers of the Militia Department.
Dealing with section 2 of this Bill, I see that a part of the $350,000,000 to be borrowed is to be spent (a) for the defence and security of Canada; and (b) for the conduct of naval and military operations in or be-jond Canada and the demobilization of the Canadian forces. I do not think it is necessary to spend much time in discussing subsection (a), because the Minister of Militia, when his Estimates were being discussed recently, convinced me that it is not his intention to spend any money in the defence and security of Canada except what is absolutely necessary to continue the staff at headquarters and to provide for the upkeep of other pre-war military organizations in different parts of the country.
With regard to subsection (b), I am in hearty agreement with that portion which states that this money is to be spent for "the demobilization of the Canadian forces." I think we all agree that every effort should be made to have our Canadian boys returned from France and England at the earliest possible moment, so they may be discharged and take their place again in civil life. But with the first part of this

subsection "for the conduct of naval and military .operations in or beyond Canada,"
I am not in agreement- I do not think it is necessary to provide that one dollar should be expended in military operations during' the year 1919, except as outlined by the Minister of Militia. Instead of spending money on military operations, we should strain every nerve to cut our expenditures down to the very lowest possible minimum. Let us see what we have spent for this purpose in the last four years. In 1914-15, the first year of the war, we spent $53,176,613.55; in 1915-16,	$160,433,416.42;
1916-17,	$298,291,030.66;	1917-18,	$316,669,-
871.95, and in 1918-19 to March 31, $289,229,119.38, making a total expenditure of $1,117,791,051-96 to equip and send our boys overseas and maintain them there. In addition there was spent on account of mUi-tary hospitals about $12,800,000, and with cur other expenditures in connection witn the war we spent up to March 31 of this year a total sum of $1,225,114,112.36. A great deal of criticism has been directed against the extravagant expenditure of part of this money, but so far as the Department of Militia and Defence is concerned, we have the satisfaction of knowing that while they have spent an enormous amount of money, and in some cases have spent it not as wisely as we would like to have it spent, yet they despatched at least 500,000 men overseas to fight for the Empire, and Canada to-day realizes that the splendid valour =hown by our soldiers on the battlefields of Flanders and Belgium fully justifies the action of the Department of Militia and Defence. 'Consequently, while as I said before there may be some criticism of the-manner in which portions of this large amount of money were spent, yet Canadians everywhere feel that they have received value in return for what has been disbursed.
What about the Naval Department? My good friend from Maisonneuve (Mr. Lemieux) thinks that the naval defence of Canada is a great deal better than it really is. Perhaps the reason for that is that "distance lends enchantment to the view," and my hon. friend, living as he does in Ottawa, does not know a great deal about naval defence on either the Atlantic or the Pacific coast. Since 1914 the enormous sum of $30,982,683.22 has been spent by the Naval Department on what is termed "strictly war expenditure;" and in addition millions of dollars have been expended in keeping up the dockyards and naval colleges at Halifax and Esqui-malt and in paying the salaries of officials

at Ottawa, Halifax and other places. Speaking for the moment of what is termed " strictly war expenditure," in 1914-15, $3,096,125.35 was expended; in 1915-16, $3,274,019.94; in 1916-17, $3,806,329.19; in 1917-18, $9,666,229.14; and in 1918-19 to March 31, $11,139,979.60; making, as I said before, a grand total of $30,982,683.22 I am going to show, Mr. Chairman, that [DOT]this $31,000,000 was practically all wasted, that it was not spent in the interest of the taxpayers of Canada; that it was entirely unnecessary, and did not in any particular, or in any way help to defend Canada or to protect the property of her citizens.
Before trying to show the Committee exactly what has happened during the war, I think it would be well for a few moments to give the history of naval matters in Canada. In giving this short resume of naval history, I do not intend to deal with the matter from a political standpoint In 1909 Sir George Foster introduced into the House of Commons a resolution, the substance of which was that Canada should proceed with the building of a Canadian navy for the protection of our own coasts. This resolution, with a slight amendment made by the leader of the Government, Sir Wilfrid Laurier, was adopted by the whole House, the members being unanimous in their decision that this was the proper course to pursue. In 1911 the Government called for tenders for the construction of cruisers of the Bristol type, and at the time they went out of power in 1911 tenders had been received from a firm in Canada which was willing to build these ships. No action was taken on these tenders by the incoming Government, and the whole matter was dropped for a year or two until Sir Robert Borden introduced a resolution to pay to Britain $35,000,000 to purchase three dreadnoughts, and, in a speech delivered by him, abandoned the Canadian navy. Some of the arguments which were used by Sir Robert Borden were that it would take fifty years for Canadian workmen to leam how to build these ships, and that we could not supply riveters. In view of the fact that for the last few years Canadian workmen have been turning out steel ships in different shipyards in Canada, the argument is refuted that -we could neither build the ships nor provide the riveters. Most of the work which has been done in the last few years by Canadian workmen is second to none and will pass inspection by either Lloyds or the American Bureau of Shipping.
At the same time it will be remembered that Mr. Winston Churchill informed us 139
that there was no land in Canada suitable for building these ships, a statement which at the time was laughed to scorn by every person but those who wished to damn the idea of a Canadian navy.
The Senate of Canada refused to sustain the vote of the House of Commons, and consequently the $35,000,000 never reached England, and the whole matter of a Canadian navy or of a contribution to the British navy died a natural death.
It is true that at this time we had at Halifax the Niobe and at Esquimalt the Rainbow, two cruisers which had been purchased by the Liberal Government. Up to 1911 the crews of these ships had been kept at full strength and had been used for training purposes so that young Canadians could take courses in naval instruction. Shortly after Hon. J. D. Hazen assumed the position of Minister of Naval Affairs the crews of these ships were disbanded, the boys sent home and only a few men kept on board to act as caretakers. It is just as well-perhaps, though it is not as well- that the gentleman who was then Minister of Marine and Fisheries is not here to-night to answer what I have to say. I may add that I do not lay any blame at the door of the hon. gentleman who to-day has charge of the Department of Naval Affairs (Hon. Mr. Ballantyne), because at the time he took charge, matters were in such a condition that it was impossible to remedy them. It is well, perhaps, that the gentleman who was in charge of naval affairs at that time now has a good, soft position in New Brunswick. A black eye was given the Canadian navy when the action of the then Minister of Naval Affairs showed that he was not in sympathy with any Canadian naval movement. Consequently, when the war broke out, the Niobe was not in fit condition to help protect the coast of Nova Scotia. Although immediately upon war being declared, orders were sent to Halifax to prepare the Niobe for sea and a part crew was sent from Esquimalt to man her, it was found that her boilers were in such condition that it would take several months to put her in a seaworthy condition. I make the statement here that if the Niobe had been ready to proceed to sea the morning that war was declared she would have succeeded in capturing prizes which would have p.aid the Canadian expenditure for war purposes during the first year of the war.
It was certainly humiliating for Canadians at Halifax to see this ship tied to her dock, grounded on her beef bones, weeks and weeks after hostilities had commenced



and also to know that the German-Hamburg liner Willehad, with a rich cargo on [DOT]board, worth millions of dollars, steamed down the gulf of St. Lawrence, proceeded along the Nova Scotia coast and sought refuge at Portland, while the Niobe was tied up with a chain at her port bow, a chain at her starboard bow, and two chains over her quarter deck so that she could not put to sea. It was also humiliating for Nova Scotians to know that the North-Ger-man-Lloyd steamer Princess Cecelia left Boston a day or two after war commenced with the most valuable cargo ever shipped from that port and with a million dollars of gold in her strong box, and that no effort could be made by the Niobe or by any Canadian cruiser to go out and capture that ship, although fishermen off Cape Sable reported seeing her steam down the Nova Scotia coast and leisurely turn back and make for Portland, Maine.
The Government awoke at last to the fact that something had to be done. They realized that the British Government required all their battleships, cruisers and destroyers to protect their own interests in the North sea and to keep the lanes oi commerce open; consequently they realized that they could not purchase or arrange with Britain for any of her ships. It became necessary for them, therefore, to endeavour to provide ways and means to protect some of the ports on the Atlantic and Pacific coasts, and they proceeded to waste money in the purchase of a lot of small boats which were utterly useless for defensive purposes. Orders were given to shipbuilding firms all over the country, and boats of the drifter and trawler class were contracted for and feverishly rushed to completion. A number of retired English officers were sent to this country to help organize a Canadian naval service. Naval recruits were asked for, captains and first mates were taken from the merchant marine service and held around Halifax for months drawing pay and doing nothing, for the simple reason that there was nothing for them to do. The story is a disgraceful one and should bring the blush of shame to every Canadian.
In the meantime there were being gathered at Halifax a motley collection oi broken-down tug-boats, gentlemens' yachts, second-hand trawlers and drifters and the new boats which were being launched. A few of these boats were used for gate purposes at Halifax and proved more of a nuisance to the shipping interests of the country than anything else. When it was
fMr. Duff.]
found that Halifax was full of these boats, a base was established at Sydney, and when the war came to a close some seventy-five boats of all kinds were tied up to the wharves in Sydney harbour. I have no hesitation in saying that the large expenditure of money for naval purposes at Sydney harbour was absolutely wasted; that no good resulted from having these boats in that harbour. Owing to their condition they were constantly undergoing repairs, most of them were unseaworthy and were not fit to go outside the headlands. It is true, that in this way they were given something to do. Some of these little gasoline patrol boats were sent out to Low Point and held up all Canadian fishing boats or schooners that came to Sydney harbour, instead of allowing them to pass without delay on their way in and out.
One of these boats known as the T. R. 30 was ordered to sea one morning, and on account of the condition of the boat's deck, seven of the seamen refused to proceed to sea unless the deck was caulked. Water had been pouring down the decks into the bunks of these seamen for several days. They reported the matter to their officer, and he reported it to the officer in command at Sydney, who refused to have anything done. These men were court-martialed and sentenced to eighteen months' imprisonment, and the mayor of Halifax protested against the sentence. I purpose putting on record the correspondence between the mayor and Mr. Desbarats, Deputy Minister of Naval Affairs. This item first appeared in the Halifax Herald:
Major Hawkins says there were seventy-one prisoners at Rockhead on Sunday.
Rockhead is the Halifax jail or penitentiary, where these boys were incarcerated:
He told this at the Board of Control meeting yesterday, and said further that there were there since August last a number of boys, some of them from good families and environment, who say that they complained at 'Sydney of unseaworthiness of a trawler on which they were serving, were tried there by court martial, brought here in irons and put in the city prison for eighteen months. The mayor said he had written the minister. Hon. Mr. Ballantyne, in reference to the matter. "Shipping laws are severe", said His Worship, "but it strikes me these boys got a raw deal from the Naval Department. They say no naval rules or regulations were read to them." His Worship' was informed that the boys had refused to go. to sea in the trawlers. If they had deserted,, they might have got but ninety days. They were ignorant of what they were doing, he said..
This item must have come to the attention of Mr. Desbarats, Deputy Minister of Naval Affairs, and he wrote Mayor Haw-

kins at Halifax the following letter on January 29, 1919:
Dear Sir:
In the absence of the minister I am answering your letter of the 21st regarding seven seamen from T.R. 30 who were court-martialed and sentenced to eighteen months' imprisonment for "wilful disobedience of lawful command."
I do not think there is much justification for the statement that these men were not fairly treated at their trial or were given a raw deal. The men were part of the crew of one of the .trawlers doing convoy work at Sydney in protecting the vessels sailing out of that port. These men refused to take the ship out when she was ordered for duty with the convoy and the mercantile vessels sailed without the protection of this trawler. The offence whs a very serious one and if the convoy had been attacked the absence of this trawler in the line might have allowed of the sinking of one or more of the convoyed ships.
That is the most ridiculous statement 1 ever saw put on paper by a responsible officer, and I say without hesitation there was not in Sydney a patrol boat, not to speak of the T.E. 30, which could convoy any vessel or protect any merchant or other ship. The letter continues:
There was no question as to the seaworthiness of T.R. 30. She is one of a number of similar ships which have proved to be thoroughly seaworthy and staunch. The complaint made by the men was that water leaked from the deck into their quarters and rendered them uncomfortable and insanitary. An inspection was made at the time by the Warrant Shipwright, who reported slight leaks but nothing of a serious kind.
So it is admitted there was some ground for the boys' compla'int. The letter continues:
Even supposing that there had been serious leaks and that a good deal of water leaked into the men's quarters, this would have been no reason for refusing duty and for preventing the ship to take her place in the line and do her share in protecting the convoy.
The men stated that, they were quite aware of the seriousness of refusing duty but notwithstanding this they took the action related above. If men on active service were allowed to refuse duty on acoount of uncomfortable surroundings there would be no need of any defensive or offensive warfare. The offence committed by the men was quite serious, they took the action with full knowledge of its gravity, they pleaded guilty to the charge of disobedience, they were tried in an open court and given every opportunity to present any defence which they might have, and there is no justification for a charge of unfair treatment on the part of the authorities.
These men can hardly be classed as boys, as their ages vary from eighteen to twenty-eight, with an average of twenty-three, and they are therefore quite old enough to realize their [DOT]responsibilities.	.
It is to he regretted that ilt should have been necessary to sentence these men to punish-
139i
ment but it does not seem possible to maintain discipline in a fleet if men are to he allowed to refuse their duty on the grounds of personal disoomfort especially as in this case the discomfort would hardly seem to have been of a serious nature.
I trust these explanations will show that there was good ground for punishing these men and that there was no injustice in the sentence which they received.
Yours truly,
(Signed) G. J. Destoarats,
Deputy Minister.
My understanding of the matter is that these boys were poor boys from the country who knew nothing about military or naval regulations, and if, as Mr. Desbarats says, they pleaded guilty, what
10 p.m. else could they do when they were before the court-martial? I suppose they thought the best thing they could do was to say whatever the court wanted them to say. This, letter of Mr. Desbarats did not satisfy Mayor Hawkins, and on February 1, 1919, he replied as follows to Mr. Desbarats:
Dear Sir,-In answer to your letter of the 29th ultimo, it is my desire that my letter of the 21st ultimo regarding the seven seamen from the T.R. 30, who were court-martialed and sentenced to eighteen months' imprisonment for "willful disobedience of lawful command," he placed before a responsible minister in the absence of the minister of your department.
_ There has been a good deal of feeling aroused in this community on account of the way ip which these seamen were treated ; the sentence imposed is looked upon as very much out of proportion, compared with other sentences of officers who have been court martialed.
The story of a certain Lieutenant Legatt, late commanding Officer of the II.M.C.S. Hoche-laga, who was court martialed and honourably discharged from service for cowardice, has been mentioned in the public press. It -would he interesting to know, as the court martial was held on these boys on the Hochelaga, if this officer had anything to do in passing sentence upon the offenders from the T.R. 30.
There are other instances where it would seem to show that there is a law for officers and another for seamen.
Yours trply,
(Signed) A. C. Hawkins,
Mayor.
In view of these facts, if these boys have not already been released, the acting Minister of Naval Affairs (Mr. A. K. Maclean) should draw the matter to the attention of the minister and have these boys released from jail immediately, and make proper restitution. An hon. member asked the Department of Naval Affairs for some information in regard to this trawler upon which these boys served, and it was necessary for him to ask the question several times before he could get very much in-

formation. Some of the questions asked by this member were as follows:
Was trawler No. 30 in the service of the Canadian Navy Department during the summer of 1918?
The answer was "yes."
If so, were any refits necessary to this boat during the summer of 1918?
The answer was "no." This is the summer the boys were sentenced to eighteen months' imprisonment.
On what date was this boat laid up for refits?
The answer was:
Answered by No. 2.
There were no refits, said the department.
Where was trawler No. 30 on August 9, 1918?
The answer was:
At Sydney, under routine lay-up.
If there was nothing wrong with this boat, why was it lying at Sydney under routine lay-up unless that was the excuse for having all the boats tied up at the wharves at Sydney? But I have absolute information that these answers are not correct, and I say that on August 14, 1918, the Sydney Foundry Company completed the work of caulking and pitching the deck of this trawler, the amount of the account being $284. This was the boat from which these seven poor seamen were court mar-tialed and sentenced to eighteen months' imprisonment, and yet within a fortnight after they were sentenced, this boat was laid up for refits and the deck caulked and pitched by the Sydney Foundry Company at a cost to this country of $284. Let us go a little further in this matter. Who were the gentlemen who court martialed these seven poor seamen from a fishing hamlet on the Atlantic coast? There was a steamer on naval duty called the Hochelaga, which was commanded by a certain gentleman and which was sent to sea on patrol duty. The look-out on this naval patrol boat one morning sighted a submarine; he reported the matter to the captain, and the captain, who was in charge of eight or ten small boats in addition to his own, at once put up signals to return to port, and instead of stopping and endeavouring to get that submarine or be sunk in the attempt, the captain of the Hochelaga deliberately turned tail and proceeded back to port. This captain is one of the three men who sentenced those seven poor Nova Scotia fishermen to eighteen months in the penitentiary. It is true that after the Hochelagf
fMr. Duff.]
returned to port and the naval authorities came into possession of the fact that the captain had acted in a cowardly manner they discharged him. But why in the name of common sense was he allowed to go with an honourable discharge, while these seven poor Nova Scotian fishermen were sen tenced to eighteen months at Eockhead? Is that fair play? Is that in keeping with the traditions of the British navy? No; and I say action should be taken to release these boys from Eockhead and make whatever restitution is possible.
We have endeavoured to get information from the Department of Naval Service this session with regard to some of the steamers it employs, but in nearly every case the answer has been unsatisfactory or contradictory. I think the truth of the matter is-that the Government are ashamed of the whole sorry mess of bungling extravagance and mismanagement of the naval affairs of this country since the war started.
To show the uselessness of the steamers composing this so-called navy, let me give one or two illustrations. On a fine summer day in 1918 the oil-tanker Lux Blanca, having discharged her cargo at the Imperial Oil works at Dartmouth, got up steam for sea. She was an American boat manned by American sailors and captained by an American ship-master. She proceeded out of the harbour and headed westward. When thirty-five miles west of Sambro island, the lookout sighted the periscope of a submarine. Let me say at this point that previous to this date the naval authorities at Halifax and Ottawa knew there was a submarine on the Nova Scotia coast, yet nothing was done. There were no patrol boats outside the headlands of Halifax harbour. When the lookout sighted the periscope of the submarine what did the captain of this oil-tanker do? Did he turn tail as the captain of the Hochelaga did? No. He had a gun forward and another gun aft, and he had these guns manned and trained on the periscope of the submarine. He gave instructions to the wireless operator to send a message to the Halifax station that he was attacked by a submarine and to send help. He turned his ship towards Halifax harbour and fought that submarine for three hours. The message was sent to Halifax about two in the afternoon, but, Mr. Chairman, not a boat left Halifax to go to that ship's assistance, and the result was that some of the crew of that oil tanker were killed, some were wounded, the ship was sunk, and the rest of the crew had to

[DOT]take to the boats. I admit that there were no ships in our naval fleet that could have sunk the submarine, but they could have done this: When that S.O.S. call came the naval authorities should have sent those boats to sea. I do not blame the captains or crews of those boats or drifters; I lay the blame on the men in charge of the naval base at Halifax, most of whom do not belong to this country, but were sent over from England after their period of usefulness there had,finished. Every man who knows anything about the business says that when that S.O.S. call came the naval authorities should have sent those boats out to sea because, whilst they may not have been able to sink the submarine, the minute the submarine sighted their smoke on the horizon, the good black smoke from Sydney coal, she would have disappeared and the oil tanker would have been saved. While this vessel was being sunk the naval officials at Halifax were trifling at pink teas and playing bridge whist. That is the way we were protected on the Nova Scotia coast.
Let me give another instance-I have five hundred pages here, and it will be impossible for me to give it all. The Lady Evelyn was one of the best boats in the patrol service. She had first class equipment; in fact, naval officers tell me that she was the only vessel in the fleet that could have engaged a submarine. While this submarine was off the Nova Scotia coast, the Lady Evelyn, the best equipped vessel in the fleet, was sent to the Magdalen islands to deliver six lead pencils to the wireless operator there. There were at this time some American destroyers also on our coast, and about the same day the Lady Evelyn went to the Magdalen islands to deliver the lead pencils, an American destroyer was off Cape Canso. This was twenty-four hours before the fishing vessels were sunk in those waters. This American destroyer received a call to return to Halifax. When the commander of the destroyer received the call he wired back that he had information a submarine was in his zone. Nevertheless, he was ordered back to Halifax on some paltry excuse, and when he got there he was sent out on convoy with the ship that was to take Prince Arthur of Cbn-naught to England. Whilst the fishermen were left to row a hundred and forty miles, this American destroyer was sailing out with Prince Arthur. Is that the way to treat the people of this country? That is what actually happened.
Let me'go a little further. Two German submarines came across the water last May. They operated first on the American coast. The Naval Department here knew all about them, and I might say that I sent several telegrams about the matter myself to Mr, Desbarats. These submarined sunk a number of American ships off the American coast, and gradually worked down the Bay of Fundy sinking vessels belonging to merchants of St, John, New Brunswick, some of them new vessels with valuable cargoes, The submarines next appeared off Cape Sable, then off Shelburne and proceeded down the Nova Scotia coast. In the town of Liverpool, at the time, three large vessels were preparing for sea. There were four or five in my home town, and several in the Lahave river preparing for sea, and to proceed to foreign ports These captains, notwithstanding the fact that they knew that the submarine was coming down the Nova iScotia coast, proceeded to sea on their voyage. They did not fear the submarine; they did not fear the Germans. No; it was the patrol boats and those others who were the ones that were making all the trouble. This submarine after destroying the Lux Blanca, proceeded down the co'ast off Canso. You will probably remember, Mr. Chairman, that the first ship she sank was a trawler belonging to parties in the constituency of the hon. Acting Minister of Naval Affairs (Mr. A. K. Maclean). While the American destroyer that was sent down by the United States to protect our coast was sent to Halifax to convoy a ship on which was Prince Arthur of Connaught, the submarine sank five or six Nova Scotia vessels and one American vessel, and the fishermen were ordered into their dories. Hon. members may not all know what a dory is. It is a small boat about fifteen feet long capable of containing only two men. These fishermen were given five minutes to leave the ship and take to their dories and then had to row for two days and two nights before reaching Canso. And this was the kind of protection we were receiving from the naval service of this country. The submarine proceeded down the St. Pierre banks and this is the time the Hochelaga turned tail, when the submarine was about 50 miles off Sydney harbour. As I say, she proceeded down the St. Pierre banks and several more fishing vessels anchored there were sunk. The crews had to row about 45 miles to St. Pierre and arriving there-I think there were about 110 men altogether-the Governor of St. Pierre realized that provisions were short and that it was advis-

able to despatch these men as quickly as possible, and cabled, I presume, to the Ottawa authorities, because shortly afterwards instructions were forwarded to Sydney to despatch one of the patrol boats to St. Pierre to bring the Lunenburg county fishermen to that port. My information is, and 1 believe it is correct, that on that occasion, because the boat was unseaworthy, the whole crew refused to go to sea and the captain had to get an entire new crew, except himself and the wireless operator. I do not know where he got them from, but I am informed that on the way back from St. Pierre to North Sydney, although it was not very rough, every man jack aboard the trawler was sick, except the captain and the wireless operator, and the fishing crew had to do the crew's work and help bring the patrol from St. Pierre to North Sydney. That is the kind of naval service we get in Canada.
Then they tell a story, and it is a true one, that when one of the fishing vessels was coming up in the fog off Halifax harbour the man on the lookout did not see the patrol boats, but he said he smelled ham and eggs, and shortly after the fog lifted there were about ten of these patrol boats in the shelter of Sambro Light. They did not come alongside the ship and tell them that there was a submarine in the vicinity, but allowed that vessel with twenty valuable lives to proceed on her way without notifying the captain of the danger. It seems to me that the least they might have done was to apprise him of the presence of the submarine so that the captain could put into Halifax harbour. Another method that was practiced was to get men for these ships by robbing the merchant marine. Every vessel that came to Halifax from a foreign voyage with crews that had been facing the submarine in the submarine zone in Spanish waters, in the Mediterranean and nearly every place else where the submarine was most in evidence, these men having faced these grave dangers for six, nine and twelve months, on arriving at Halifax they were arrested by the military police and put in jail. I know of one case-and I can . mention more-in which the mate of ,a ship called the Win the War was arrested and put in jail by the military police. The mate of a vessel that arrived in Halifax one Saturday morning was arrested and put in the lockup over Sunday, taken to Aldershot and kept in custody for a week until the owners of his vessel got him out. We are supposed to emulate the example of Great Britain, and yet this condition of affairs existed in spite of the fact that Great Bri-
LMr. Duff,]
tain, gave every encouragement to the members of the British marine. I have in my hand what is known as a notice to mariners for 1918 in which appears the following:
Maintenance of British Shipping.
Officers and Seamen of the Mercantile Marine (except Stewards on Passenger Vessels) are included in the list of certified occupations issued under the Military Service Act, 1916, as persons who are engaged in work of national importance and are entitled to exemption from Mil

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speakerposition: Minister of Finance and Receiver General
speechtext:
With regard to France, I may repeat to my hon. friend what I said the other night. The first country that we approached, long before the armistice and immediately after, in relation to reconstruction business was France. The matter was taken up with the French representative at Washington, and it was taken up overseas directly with the French Government by the Minister of Trade and Commerce and Mr. Lloyd Harris, and also, I may say, by the Prime Minister; and we offered her a credit of-well, we put no limit to it. What I had in mind was a credit of from $50,000,000 to $100,000,000. No question arises of France's future. We offered her such a credit as she might require for purchases in Canada. But I

think the position of France is this, she has her own situation in regard to industries and employment, and very naturally she desires, to the extent of her ability, to do her own restoration through her own manufacturers and to give her own people employment. Consequently up to date she has not felt it necessary to avail herself of the offer of credit which I can again assure my hon. friend and this House it would have been a pleasure to us to extend to her for making purchases in this country. I have indicated all the credits that have been extended, with the exception of those which we have been giving to Great Britain and which we shall have to give. I assure the leader of the Opposition that no one will be more relieved than I shall when free markets are restored for wheat, flour, and all other commodities, so that men will carry on their business in the way they did in 1911. The hon. gentleman seemed to indicate that he thought- we were blameable because we do not do business now as we did in 1911. But he has overlooked one very important	consideration

something	for
which William Hohenzollern is responsible, not myself- and that is, the war. The reason why we have to do business in this way is that since 1911 we have had the war and we have not yet been able, as a country, to get back to the normal manner of doing business as my hon. friend described it. My own view is that as soon as industrial conditions permit, as soon as business can be done through the ordinary channels, the Dominion Government should not make any loans for the purpose of facilitating the sale of our products. The natural way is to have them taken care of through ordinary commercial and financial channels. What the Government has done it has done for two reasons: In the first place, to provide employment for those in Canada who would otherwise be out of work and to keep our factories going; and, in the second place, to extend the export trade of the country.
With regard to the -placing of orders, a point was raised the other night about commissions. I made careful inquiry of Mr. Lloyd Harris over there; he knows nothing of any commission paid in respect of the business. I also served notice upon the Trade Commission here that it was not necessary that commissions of any kind should be paid, and that no orders should be placed with firms that were paying commissions or remunerations to any outside of their own employees or organization. This business is obtained in London. The

agents of, say, 'the Rumanian Government know what they want. They deal there through the Canadian Trade Mission, and with the representatives of the various branches of Canadian manufacture. They bargain as to the prices to he paid, and they see the samples-our men are in competition with others who are competing for the same business-and then the order is placed through the Trade Commission here, which is officered by very capable and honourable men. It seems to me that we could not devise any better means of getting business for all the manufacturers of Canada than we have devised by the establishment of this Mission in London and of its complement, the Canadian Trade Mission here. It is easy to criticise, and it is hard to construct and create. But this organization which we have built up and which at the time of its inception had the commendation of the people of Canada-it was a very live question here-is to-day keeping thousands of people at work, is promoting the industry and the commerce of the country, and, 1 submit, should be commended by hon. gentlemen opposite when they get to understand it fully. At the head of our Trade Commission here is Sir Charles Gordon, a very able and honourable man, as the member for Maisonneuve (Mr. Lemieux) said the other night. In London we have Mr. Lloyd Harris, who is well known, I think, to most members of this House. So far as I am aware, the Government's action is such as the Government should take at a time like this. Let us look forward to a period-I do not know how far distant; I hope not far distant-when the Dominion Government will not have to provide credits; thfen we shall have the benefit of all this connection that has been established with foreign countries. Our goods will get to be known, and an impetus will be given to all the industry of the country.
As to indebtedness on the part of one Government to another, that is usually a very honourable obligation of Governments and I have no doubt whatever that the advances which are being made by the Dominion Government, substantial sums as they are, will be repaid in due course, as soon as peace conditions permit these nations again to get upon their feet, and as soon as international exchange is restored.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speakerposition: Minister of Finance and Receiver General
speechtext:
I cannot say as to that; but these goods are being purchased by Governments, and Governments could no doubt arrange to have them go in free of duty. Our relationship is not with individuals in these countries, but with Governments. For example, we give the Belgium Government a credit of $25,000,000, and Belgium is going to send a mission out here to purchase. The Belgian Government, having borrowed the money from us, and being, as I believe, entirely responsible, will use its credit in this country to purchase to the best advantage. I think the Hudson's Bay Company has been doing some buying for the Belgian Government. I believe that Greece also will send a mission here to purchase. Of the Rumanian credit, $5,000,000 is in wheat, another $5,000000 is in raw material-that has not yet been purchased-and the ' balance is in manufactured products, such as clothing, woollens, textiles, agricultural implements, and, I hope, some railway equipment; in other words, what they need in order to restore their country.
Hon. gentlemen may say that Canada is taking some risk in this matter. Well, let us assume that we are. Having regard to the situation in which the country found itself in November last, facing this collapse in its industries, Canada is abundantly justified in doing what the United States has been doing on an immense scale, and what Great Britain is doing. This war has caused so profound a dislocation in the world, in finance, commerce and industry, that if during this year, which, in a sense, is a war year, because we have the consequences of the war with us, we failed in courage or in resource, the situation would be different in Canada from what it is to-day. I do not believe hon. gentlemen, no matter how well informed they may be, quite appreciate what 'the Government's financing has done and is doing for this country to-day. If you take the gratuity which we gave the soldiers; if you take the payments to the soldiers that the Minister of Militia has referred

to; if you take our shipbuilding programme; if you take the immense expenditures we are obliged to make for the financing of our grain purchases and our manufactured products that I have mentioned- hundreds of dollars-and then imagine the situation if the Government on November 11 had said:	"Now we quit right here;
the war is at an end; no more credits for wheat or meats or manufactured products; let private enterprise carry on the business itself. Well, I would be taking a ticket out of the country, because I would not desire to face the situation which would have resulted. Imagine the activities of this country, stimulated as they were during .the war, keyed up to a height that none of us believed they could attain, and then everything suddenly stop. If the Government had not come to the rescue as they did, with courage and resource, and provide the credits we did, there would have been a very serious situation in Canada.

speechtext:
The statements made by the hon. member (Mr. Duff) with regard to expenditures in connection with naval affairs in Canada are of such a serious character that we should at least have some explanation from the minister before this clause is adopted.	[DOT]
, We have the statement made here by . the hon. member, not as his own, but as a declared statement by an officer who was one of the men in charge at Esquimalt at the time, I believe, and who professes to make a declaration, equal to a statement on oath, as to what has been taking place in connection with the handling of the navy, not only on the coast of British Columbia, but at Halifax, ISydney and other

places. We have not, so far, had a word of explanation from the Government. There may be some minister or other hon. member who* can give us some explanation about this matter, but we have not had a word of explanation, and we are asked to vote $350,000,000, a large part of which is going to be paid out in connection with work of this class. While we are all anxious to get along as fast as we can with the business of this session, including the voting of money, this (Committee and the House and the country are entitled to some explanation as to the charges put forward in respect to the management of this very important department of Government. 'It is well known, in the part of the country from which I come, which is in the same province as the constituency represented by the hon. member (Mr. Duff), that moneys were simply squandered right and left; that every sort of a boat that would float at all was either purchased or hired, and that it was the sheerest mockery the piles of ships that were in each others' way in the harbour of Sydney during the last year or two doing nothing in the world except paying out money to men who were friendly to the Government and who had craft of this kind -to sell or hire. Without some departmental head here able to answer these questions, it would be useless to make-any further charges than those already put before the Committee by the hon. member for Lunenburg, and I do not wish to take up time of re-stating what has been so well said by him. But it is the duty of the Government, and particularly of the minister in charge of this Bill, if he cannot give this explanation himself, to let this matter "stand until the minister who is capable of giving the explanation is here and can tell us how many vessels were purchased or hired; from whom vessels were purchased or hired; what was the necessity of hiring vessels; how many vessels we still own; and what are they worth; and what the Government intends doing with them? I suggested to the Minister of Naval Affairs that such of the 11 p.m. vessels as are equal to the kind of work, should, if possible, be converted into fishing craft. The Canadian people would get more value and better results from those vessels in that way than in any other. I do not know that this is the occasion to discuss that, but I am mentioning it in the presence of so many ministers, that they may have at least one constructive idea in connection with the handling of those boats. I am told that [Mr. McKenzie. 1
many of the boats can be sold to advantage to fishermen who, perhaps, may not be able to pay the whole of the money at once, but a scheme could be arranged by which the Government would be sure of obtaining its money and a fishing fleet of fine proportions, well equipped, would be established on both the Atlantic and the Pacific. If this matter is inquired into at all, we shall be able to get some information from the minister on that score.
At an early stage in the evening, the hon. member for Pontiac (Mr. Cahill) made some statements in connection with the furnishing of money for trade purposes. The hon. member for Vancouver Centre (Mr. Stevens) thought that he was making a very clever answer when he told us that we were perfectly justified in voting J25,-000,000 of the people's money to Rumania, because Rumania was in debt to Great Britain and that we were in debt to _ Great Britain and the United States, and in order to square our bills with Great Britain and the United States, we should allow Rumania to become indebted to us. If that is a business proposition by which there shall be accorded any satisfaction in the payment of debts between Rumania and Great Britain, Great Britain and ourselves and ourselves and the United States, it is a system that I never heard of before and that I do not understand. The hon. member sat down absolutely satisfied with himself as having solved the whole problem and having justified the borrowing by Canada of $25,000,000 somewhere and passing that over to Rumania in order that Rumania might become indebted to us. If that is business, I shall be glad to have it more fully explained by the minister if he shall deem it proper to make any further observations in connection with this Bill.
There are different ways of promoting trade. When we were in pow'er in this country we promoted trade in the usual way. We wanted to have trade with people who. were willing to pay either in kind or in cash for our goods. In 1911, the situation in this country was excellent, but we wanted to make it better and we launched upon a comprehensive trade arrangement with the people of the United States and other countries where we could get proper trade and where we would have exchange of our goods for theirs or get their money for our goods. That was not good enough for the statesmen who are to-day in charge of affairs, and they turned it down. What have they given to us instead of it? They have given us an

absolutely new idea in trade, namely, that we are to furnish our own money and that we are to buy our own goods, and after we have bought our goods from ourselves, we are to pass them over without any security whatever to a foreign country. Will the minister explain how it is that we are going to get wealthy in that way? Supposing a man furnishes a customer with $5 to buy a pair of boots, the man comes in to his store and buys the boots and he passes over to the [DOT] merchant his own $5. The merchant has his 35 back in his till, but the boots are gone and he has nothing for them. I see many hardheaded business men sitting in front of me, and I should like them to explain how we are going to grow wealthy and expand and develop the country by such a system of trade.
The idea of a man lifting himself by his boot straps has always seemed the most ridiculous thing we could imagine, but I think such a feat is just as easily possible as the making of this country wealthy and prosperous upon the system of trade, and business generally, that is followed by this Government, and which is applauded by its Supporters as a new device which will overcome all the trade ills that the state is heir to. As a matter of fact, we have not got the money to give, but we are undertaking to find it in some way, and pass it off in the manner I have mentioned. 'I submit to you, Mr. Chairman, that whether or not this will be a bribe to the manufacturers of this country, to the big combines, the big friends who own the Government according to the Government's own friends, it is capable ol being a bribe. What is happening? The Manufacturers' Association and the men engaged in big business come to the Government and say: " We want more trade. We want more money put in circulation. What are you going to do about it?" The Government says: " If you can get anybody to buy your goods we will pay for them." That is a magnificent proposition. The manufacturer is not asked what his price is, where he will deliver the goods, or anything of that kind; he is simply told by the Government: "We care not what you produce, so long as it is a manufactured article of any kind. If you will pile it on the shore at Montreal, Halifax, St. John, or Vancouver, and get a certified account from somebody whom we will appoint at these places, we will put you in the way of getting a cheque for your goods." Is not that a magnificent layout for the manufacturers? They do not send travelling agents abroad; they are free from that expense. They do not bother
about insuring their goods and sending them across the Atlantic; they do not worry about transportation or freight or anything else. All they have to do is produce the goods, and then this paternal fraternity known as the Government will furnish the cash and take full responsibility for everything. If that is not a scheme by which men who have goods to sell are capable of being bribed, I do not know what scheme you could devise that would be more capable of being used for bribery. I am not saying that that is what the scheme is for, but it is an old saying that the sight of means to do ill deeds, has ill deeds done. It would be better to let the men on this side of the Atlantic who have goods to sell do business direct with the men on the continent of Europe who want to buy their goods, instead of the Government engineering the thing so that the manufacturers can sell their goods for what they like without the purchaser having anything to say about it. When this matter was up about two weeks ago, the complaint was made that there was no proper distribution of these orders. Some person said there was no such thing at all as orders of this kind, but the hon. jnember for Haldimand (Mr. Lalor) who, I believe, is a manufacturer or .interested in manufacturing, told us all about it. He said that the orders were distributed in the best possible way, that there was no discrimination, that everybody got a share. Nevertheless, the distribution of the orders is made by a combination of manufacturers who come together and fix their own price; they divide the orders up just as they like, and then the Government undertakes all the hard work of getting the money to pay for the goods. That is not a proper or healthy way of doing business, and the sooner we get away from it the better.
I submit that we have not been given the necessary information about this money which we are going to give to foreign countries for the purpose of stimulating trade in Canada. We do not know how much we are going to give-at least I do not; we do not know how it is to be handled; we do not know how the goods are to be bought; we do not know how they are to be conveyed from this country to their destination. When we are furnishing money in this way to help out foreigners, I submit, we should know something about it. There is all the more reason for this information because of conditions to-day, when the price

not only of foodstuffs but of manufactured articles is such that if the price were reduced to normal the sales of the manufacturers [DOT] could be doubled and trebled and our men kept at work without sending goods out of the country at all. I think that before we accept the proposition of the manufacturers, there should be the closest possible inquiry into the conditions; and the method which evidently has been adopted by the Government should only be resorted to in the last extremity when nothing else could be done to carry on trade and keep our men employed.
The information we particularly desire is in connection with the expenditure on naval affairs. We also require a little further explanation about the money we are going to borrow and pass over to foreign countries. It might be somewhat difficult for the minister to give this information to-night, but as we are entitled to it, if no other hon. member wishes to speak, I would suggest that at this late hour the minister should let the Bill stand in Committee.
