speechtext:
We should make the
principal liable for the fraudulent act of his servant or agent. Further, what are you going to do if the fine is not paid? Does the original Act provide for further penalty in default of payment? And what jurisdiction is to determine the conviction?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: Section 78 of the original Act contains a clause with regard to the recovery of penalties, and to procedure.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: What about visiting a penalty upon the proprietor for the acts of his servants or agents?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: If a sale is made by an employee, the principal would still be liable, because the sale is made by the employee on behalf of the principal.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: But in that case the principal does not sell it.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: Oh, yes; the principal sells by his agent.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: Not necessarily. The employee might do it in a fraudulent way, without the knowledge of the principal. The employee could not, perhaps, pay the fine, and might not be there to suffer punishment.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: An employee making a sale would make it on behalf of his employer, and, in law, the sale would be by the principal.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: Is this fine exigible whether dr not the selling party is aware that the goods sold are under weight?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
In section 8, the word " knowingly" is used. Why should it not
be used in this section, so that the provision would read:
Any person who knowingly sells, delivers or causes to be sold or delivered, anything by weight, measure or number short of the quan-. tity ordered or purchased, etc.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: Then the department would have to establish knowledge, and we would again be under the present disabilities of the criminal law.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: Put -the onus on the proprietor.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: The Inspection and Sales Act provides that such discrepancies as my hon. friend refers to- those due exclusively to different atmospheric conditions in different places, or to ordinary exposure, evaporation, absorption of water and so on-shall not exceed five per cent of the original weight when sold to the consumer.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: The railway rate would operate against those ports.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
There are every year complaints by the hundreds to the department that goods are sold short in weight. On the other hand, the officers of the department believe that short weight deliveries are due, in most cases, not to fraud and deliberate intent, but to carelessness, and they want to prevent this carelessness, and if possible, by this legislation, to compel dealers to give purchasers that which they bought and which they paid for. I hope this law will assist in making men more careful about the deliveries they make.
Amendment (Mr. Jacobs) agreed to.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: In view of that, I think the provision proposed would not cause undue hardship.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
I would like to have one further opportunity of impressing my views upon the minister, who is evidently not yet quite convinced. The member for Dundas (Mr. Casselman) said a few minutes ago, that owing to the fact that there might be habitual cases of carelessness on the part of merchants or their employees this clause, in his estimation, was all right. But I submit it is not the habitual offenders that will suffer and feel the consequent exposure most, but the casual offender. The person who has really committed an offence under this clause-not intentionally, not knowingly, not wilfully, but by mere accident; you may call it negligence, a term that the Acting Minister of Justice is very fond of

will be the one to suffer, although the offence may be an accident purely and simply, I think it is the feeling of those members of the Committee who have given the matter careful consideration that there should be some safeguard provided so as to protect a merchant against such imposition as has been referred to, viz: that a dissatisfied employee might, in order to get even with his employer, act in collusion with a friend who would institute a prosecution for short measure. There are a thousand and one ways in which a merciiant might not only be penalized, but exposed to the odium which such proceedings involves, although that merchant is a conscientious person who gives the public the best of service and full measure and full weight in the sales which he makes. Like my hon. friend from George Etienne Cartier (Mr. Jacobs), I am willing and desirous that the public should be protected to the last degree in a matter of this kind, and that every safeguard should be attached to purchases by the public; but you can make the penalties resulting from proceedings under the Act so irksome, irritating, and annoying to the persons interested that it will be a continual source of worry to them. From week-end to weekend, and from year to year they will always be in terror of suffering seriously by reason of a slight deviation from the exact line of measure. As I said before, in my experience in mercantile affairs, covering a period of forty years, I have found that the measures going over a counter, either in. yardage or weight, vary as often
one way as the other. In a hasty operation of the scale or the yard measure an employee, even with the best of care, is liable to give over measure or short measure. Now the employee who has given in one case short measure even to the extent of a hair's breadth, is liable to a penalty under this Bill. I submit that the minister will be well advised if he listens to reason, reconsiders his decision, and inserts in this clause some qualifying provision.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
I do not think
the cases are quite comparable. Whether or not a stamp was affixed to a package of patent medicines is a fact easily established; if it was not affixed, technically the offender is guilty. I do not think there is the same opportunity for abuse in this case as there might be in the case to which my hon. friend refers. I believe I may safely repeat, that all prosecutions under this section must necessarily be initiated by the officers of the department, and I trust they will always exercise their duties with some discretion.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
From personal experience, I can state that that is not usually the case with officers of Government departments, and I am not now speaking of this particular department. The point raised by the hon. member for Kent is well taken, and I regret to state that officers in this connection are not always, like Caesar's wife, above reproach. I have had similar experiences to that indicated by him. I know a case where an officer of the department visited the town of Renfrew and tried his level best to induce junior employees to
deliver to him packages without a stamp on them, and he knew they should have been stamped, but he endeavoured to induce the employees to commit an offence under the Stamp Act. I know that from personal experience. The same man operated in every store in that town on the same occasion along the same lines. I feel that no merchant would be any safer in the hands of an official of this department. This will be the last and final appeal from me in this regard. I have known cases where dishonest buyers tried to make believe that their measure was short. The merchant has no protection under this Bill in cases where customers take the goods home, remove a portion of them and come back to the store claiming that the weight or measure was. short.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
This indicates
again how difficult it is to prosecute, even under this section. The Act will never be invoked unless an officer of the department knows that a certain man is habitually given to short deliveries. The evidence can only be secured after a great deal of trouble, probably by the officer of the department being in the store when the deliveries are being made.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: I do not see, then, why the word "knowingly" should not be inserted after the word " who " in the first line.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: The word " knowingly " is used in section 69; why should it not be used in this?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv

speechtext: With reference to what my hon. friend (Mr. Baldwin) has said, the fact would have to be determined as any other fact is determined. It would be very difficult to secure a conviction for selling short weight if the purchaser took the articles to his home and kept them there for some time.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: Or two seconds, for that matter; it would be very difficult to secure a conviction in that case. There need be no apprehension, therefore, about anybody being injured by this law other than the person who has clearly laid himself open for prosecution.

The officials of the department state, that in practice they cannot secure a conviction, and they want some legislation enabling them to punish men by the imposition of a fine for failure to furnish that which a man has paid for.

Major-General MEWBURN: They are, included in the same lot.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: My reason for moving the amendment which I am about to submit is simply this: I think the Committee will agree that in most cases of bigamy, one of the parties is usually.innocent. Now under the clause as it stands to-day if, under those circumstances, a bigamous marriage was contracted, the innocent party would not only suffer from the results of that marriage, but would be liable as well to imprisonment. The operating words of the section are that either of the pa*ties "represents or pretends" that the man is the husband or the woman is the wife. What I say is that this should not be an offence unless the person who thus represents or pretends, knows that the statement is not true. Therefore, I would move to add to the end of the section, the amendment referred to. Then in a case of that kind the innocent party to the marriage contract would be protected.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speakerposition: Minister of Finance and Receiver General
speechtext:
I will make a
complete statement as to that, and I desire to say to the leader of the Opposition, and to hon. gentlemen to your left, Mr. Chairman, that I find no fault whatever with the question being raised, because an important Bill deserves serious consideration in Committee, and it is not my custom to withhold information if I can furnish it.
I desire to say to the hon. leader of the Opposition that we are in good company in what we are doing. The United States has loaned, during the war, and is loaning now, billions of dollars to the nations of Europe to enable them during the war to conduct military operations, and since to buy the products of the United States. The United States must continue to do that through her Government and her financial institutions if she is to get trade. To put it another way, if Europe is to be supplied with foodstuffs and manufactured products from this continent Europe cannot pay for them, and this continent cannot sell them unless the money is found on this side of the Atlantic. There is no business man on this side of the House who does not know that that is so. The United States has been pushing very strongly for business, as my hon. friend says, but she has been in the powerful position of being able to offer credits. Her wheat, her meats and all her other foodstuffs of every kind she can sell to Europe, but Europe cannot sell European exchange against New York exchange to pay for them; Europe has to borrow from the United States. That borrowing will he done partly from the American Government and partly by the ordinary operations between banks, and by the sale in the United States of securities of European countries.
Great Britain for many years had the greatest money market in the world in London, and foreign governments came there and sold their securities, which were taken up by British investors, and in that way the money was furnished in 'London for the purchases which were made in Great Britain. Now you have this situation on the North American continent. Our people and the people of the United States are not accustomed to buying the securities of foreign governments. The United States is
14D
very slowly becoming an international money centre because her people, until this war, had not been accustomed-as were the British people-to purchasing the securities of foreign governments. Whether they will become so accustomed to doing that as to constitute New York a great international financial centre like London, in which the securities of foreign governments will be dealt in, I do not pretend to say. It will take probably a long ' time before that is accomplished. But the United States Government has been furnishing immense sums of money to the European countries, as I have said, in order that they might purchase foodstuffs and the goods required from the United States.
I think the amount loaned to Great Britain alone is between four and five billion dollars for commodities so purchased. That was not loaned in gold and shipped overseas; it was a credit given at Washington, and Great Britain by means of that credit purchased in the United States the goods she required. She wanted the goods, and she could not buy them unless she got that credit.
With regard 'to Rumania, I would ask hon. gentlemen to bear in mind that she could have kept out of the war. She came into it at a very critical period and made great sacrifices for the common cause- 1 am not prepared to say that many thousands of Canadian lives have not been saved lby the intervention of Rumania. If hon. gentlemen will look at the map of Europe they will see that Rumania, is a; great salient projecting into Austria-Hungary, exposed to attack on both front and flank-Bulgaria to the south,. Austria-Hungary to 'the north and west. Rumania risked her all in coming into this war, and she lost for the time being, but she made the sacrifice. Sentimentally, therefore, I do not think we should be quick to reflect too much upon the credit -of Rumania, devastated as she has been by the war, prosecuted by her in common cause with the Allies. Rumania is not so strong financially, of course, as Belgium and France, but she must be restored. Her fields have been devastated, her cattle carried off; and her people need food and clothing and agricultural implements. How are they going to get them? If they do not get food they will starve; if they do not get clothing the consequences will be serious from exposure; if they do not get agricultural implements their tillage cannot be restored. Rumania is a very rich country, rich in her fertile plains, her splendid forests and her great oil resources, and she will get upon her



feet rapidly once she gets a chance- Now, who is going to supply to Rumania the wheat to feed her population, the clothing to protect them from the elements, and the agricultural implements and railway equipment required for the restoration of their tillage and their transportation facilities? There is an opportunity there for some nation. The United States have seized that opportunity. Since the armistice, to say nothing of before, the United States have roamed Rumania $25,000,000-I ascertained that from Washington-and all that money is being spent in the United States.
Now, our Trade Commission in London approached Belgium, France and the other nations of Europe requiring supplies of various kinds of food and for the restoration of their countries, and ascertained that there was a splendid opening for business in the Balkans, the business that I have mentioned, good for the time being to keep our factories going and afford employment to our artisans and work people, and good in its promise for the future. Rumania, as I have said, could not purchase supplies in Canada unless a credit were established; neither could France, nor Belgium; and I pointed out that even England could not purchase unless we gave her credit. We gave a credit of $25,000,000 to Rumania; we gave a credit of $25,000,000 to Greece, whose future is of the brightest; we gave a credit of $25,000,000 to Belgium, and I believe she will speedily recover from the effects of the war. Belgium is a very rich country, and is now assured of protection by the League of Nations and by the interest which Great Britain and France notably have in the preservation of its integrity.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speakerposition: Minister of the Interior; Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs
speechtext: The hon. gentleman's amendment is merely a negative. If he is opposed to the section as amended he Is at liberty to vote accordingly.

speakerposition: Minister of the Interior; Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs
speechtext:
I have not conducted1
negotiations personally, but the Parks Branch has for many years been under the-charge of Mr. Harkin, and I know he has been conducting negotiations, although unsuccessfully, with those three provinces. I know Mr. Harken is very grievously disappointed that he is not able to secure that provincial conformity in the Maritime Provinces that has been secured in the others, and the consequent enforcement of the law.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: This provision is something that I am opposed to on general principles.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
Does this mean that
the Nova Scotia Government would regard this as a hostile measure, and that there would be a conflict between their laws and this?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speakerposition: Minister of the Interior; Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs
speechtext:
A treaty was entered into between United States and Canada for the protection of migratory birds. That treaty was ratified by Act of Parliament, and its provisions were embodied in the Migratory Birds Convention Act. The provinces, of course, had their own game laws, and, in the main, were enforcing them; but those provincial laws did not go far enough to ensure the protection of migratory birds. The subject matter having been dealt with by international treaty, the Dominion acquires jurisdiction; but the Dominion thought-and the migratory birds legislation is based entirely upon this hypothesis-that provincial legislation would be enacted to bring the laws in each province into conformity with the several provisions of the treaty and to provide for their enforcement. That hope has, to a large extent, been realized. Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta have brought their game laws into full conformity with the Migratory Birds Convention; British Columbia, Ontario and Quebec have brought their laws into substantial conformity-for all practical purposes, into full conformity -with the provisions of the convention and are in a reasonable manner carrying out those laws. But we have not been able to secure from the Maritime Provinces the legislation desired. New Brunswick, instead of bringing its legislation up to the requirements of the Migratory Birds Convention Act, has repealed its legislation altogether and throws the whole onus on the Dominion, very much to the disappointment of those who have at heart the enforcement of our migratory bird laws. Nova Scotia has not gone so far as that. Perhaps, in order to be accurate, I had better read just what has been done in this connection:
New Brunswick has not amended its game laws to comply with the treaty, but has repealed all its laws protecting migratory birds, on the ground that that is a duty now devolving on the Dominion.
Prince Edward Island has not amended its laws to comply with the treaty, and has no warden service.
Nova Scotia has amended its game laws, but it has omitted protection for wild beasts and ducks-except black, wood and eider-

an'd the open season for Wilson snipe and woodcock does not meet the conditions of the treaty. Moreover, Nova Sootia say they have not an adequate warden service to enforce the Act.
That being the condition of affairs in the Maritime Provinces, it becomes necessary for the Dominion, having regard to its obligations under the treaty, so to amend its Act as to enable it to enforce the law in those provinces. We must take power, therefore, to pass regulations covering minor matters of enforcement to enable us to carry out the law-it having been originally intended that these minor matters should be taken care of, as before, by the provincial authorities. That is the reason for paragraph (aa) in section 1, as to power of regulation under section 4 of the present Act. The same reasoning applies to the Bill throughout. Section 2 provides for penalties for violation and for the bringing of the goods seized to a justice of the peace who has power to order confiscation. The last clause, to which the leader of the Opposition advances his general objection, is also made necessary by the very same cause.
The laws of the various provinces which are now enforcing the Migratory Birds Convention Act, provide for the allocation of the fines. The provincial governments appoint wardens and game officers who a/re not under salary, but who are entitled, where they secure a conviction, to divide the fines, and in that way the enforcement of the law is secured. As, however, Nova Scotia, New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island refuse to enforce the law-and this applies especially to Nova Scotia; the others refuse chiefly to pass laws-we must provide for some division of the fines as well, in order that a system of enforcement may be put into effect, without the necessity of our employing salaried officers for the purpose. That is the reason of this section. The hon. member will find that in his own province this very same law is in effect by provincial legislation. I read from section 108 of the Nova Scotia Game Act:
Every fine imposed and collected under the authority of this Act, shall be paid in full to the Chief Game Commissioner, who shall, except as elsewhere in this section provided, pay over the same to the Provincial Treasurer to be paid and applied to him as provided by section 104 of this Act.
(2)	When a complaint is laid and the information therefor furnished by a person other than a warden, the Chief Game Commissioner may pay one-half of the fine so collected to the complainant.
(3)	When the complaint is laid by a warden
under information therefor furnished by any other person, the Chief Game Commissioner may pay one-quarter of the fine so collected to such informant.	. i
So that the principle of the Nova Scotia' statute is merely being embodied in this. Bill to enable us to carry out the enforcement which apparently the province of Nova Scotia declines to carry out.

We could have charged six, six and-a-half or seven per
1404	i
cent, but we are dealing with Governments and we did not think that it was dignified to charge an extortionate rate of interest. We charge them just the rate it costs to raise the money here-five and one-half per cent.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: Most of these European countries are protective countries. Will the goods be subject to customs duties when they reach these countries?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext:
I wanted to know what was in my hon. friend's mind for the future in peace time. It is a relief to hear that he intends to live up to $4,000,000, but he will have to cut many frills.
Major-General MEWBURN:	At present
the problem of demobilization, not only bringing troops back, but clearing up all records, documents, etc., is an enormous one.
For instance, at the present time some one hundred and seventy thousand ledger sheets have been returned from overseas within the last few weeks-that is, ledger sheets of the individual troops that are *coming over as the men are demobilized. The work of checking and dealing with every individual man's' account is enormous. In addition, there are some five hundred tons of files being gradually returned from overseas to the Militia Departr ment here. That includes all the records *and documents that have been moved from General Headquarters in France back to JSngland, and the records and documents from the various Record Offices in England. It takes an enormous amount of labour and some staff to complete and get all these documents into shape. Furthermore, there is the file containing documents of every individual man with the Canadian Expeditionary Force, amounting in all to over six hundred thousand files. These documents, containing the medical history of every man, it is most essential should be carefully kept so as to protect this country in the matter of claims for pensions in the future. The Pension Department requires these files, also the Department of 'Soldiers' Civil Re-Establishment-when the men are discharged, which work has nothing to do with [Major-General Mewbum.]
the Militia Department-and the Land Settlement Board in connection with soldiers' settlement. Then there is the large problem of hospitalization. We are taking care of the returned soldiers-officers, noncommissioned officers, and men-in the various hospitals throughout Canada, and we estimate that by next February we should be through with the military hospitalization, but that is only an estimate. In November, 1918, the casualties of Canadian corps were something like 45,000. The difficult problem was to estimate the number of casualties or invalids coming back to Canada. We estimated, as well as we could, on information from the medical service, that somewhere about May there would be approximately 18,000 invalids still coming back from overseas. I am glad to say that we were generous on our estimate; that the patients in the military hospitals in England are being evacuated a little quicker than we expected and becoming convalescent cases. The last figures from France, I think, showed that there were about seventeen hundred still to be evacuated from that country. The total number of patients in England and France up to a week ago was slightly under 14,000, but many of these-

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speakerposition: Minister of Finance and Receiver General
speechtext:
I think I can give my hon. friend the information that he desires to-night as to the necessity of the constitution of credits for foreign export business for Canada, and as to the manner in which that business is placed- Before doing so, however, I think I should refer to the speech of the hon. member for Lunenburg.
He covered a very wide field. I had no notice that he would bring forward the matters he dealt with to-night. It would seem to me that they would ordinarily be brought forward when the Minister of Naval Affairs had his estimates before the Committee, but the hon. member was quite in order, because we were discussing the naval estimates for the coming year as embodied in this vote. This Bill which is now before the Committee is analogous to the Bills of last year and the previous year, only that the amount is smaller and its purpose is, as hon. members know, to provide for what we might call the remainder of our war expenditure, and particularly, as the war is in reality although not officially, over, for our demobilization expenditure and other outlays arising out of the war. The Minister of Militia has explained that so far as his portion of the vote is concerned, it is solely for demobilization purposes. I would suggest to my hon. friend the leader of the Opposition that as the Minister of Naval Affairs will be having his estimates before the House to-morrow or the next day,

he might deal with the statements made by the hon. member for Lunenburg on that occasion. I would submit that delay in answering the hon. member, because the minister had no notice that these matters would be brought up to-night, is not a sufficient reason for our not passing the section of the Bill referred to.
With regard to the general question of credits, let me make a rather comprehensive statement. I should like to say, first, that there is no man in the Dominion who would rather see a return to the former and normal modes of business than I. The furnishing of credits by the Dominion of Canada for the purchase of our agricultural and manufactured products is absolutely forced upon us by the exigencies of the financial situation due to the war. Take the question of our grain; I shall come to the manufactured products later. This year I had expected to have to provide a sum not exceeding $100,000,000, for the purchase of our exportable surplus of wheat and flour, but on account of the exchange situation between Great Britain and this continent by which it is impossible for Great Britain to purchase wheat in the United States and' Canada except from funds provided on this side of the Atlantic, and because no funds are available except such as we can provide in Canada, the Dominion Government has paid out up to date a sum in excess of $80,000,000, which has been loaned to the Imperial Government for the purchase ot our wheat, and it has undertaken to furnish a further $90,000,000 which will be required for the purchase of the balance of the wheat and flour products of this last year's crop. My hon. friend, I am sure, would not describe that as a bribe to the farmers. If the Dominion Government did not furnish that credit of $170,000,000-I hope it may be somewhat less, because it is a very heavy burden-then it would mean that the exportable surplus of the wheat of Canada and our exportable surplus of flour could not be bought. Under the old conditions, my hon. friend knows that the Government would not have to intervene at all, and I should be perfectly delighted if the old conditions prevailed, so that the sellers of wheat and flour would simply send forward bills of exchange with the documents attached and get their money in New York exchange. If they were able to do that there would not be to-day a 3 per cent rate of exchange against Canada as between us and the United States. So much for wheat and flour. My hon. friend would not say that we were bribing the

farmers and that we were doing, anything a government should not do at a time like this, in furnishing money which alone makes it possible for the Canadian farmer and the Canadian miller to sell their wheat and flour, and for the rest of the people of Canada to get the benefit that comes to them from the sale of those commodities.
Then as to manufactured goods. I am sure my hon. friend will not object if I ask the Committee to consider the situation with which we were confronted immediately upon the conclusion of the armistice in November last. It has often been said that preventive ability is never appreciated. People see results, but they are not aware of the cause. I have no hesitation in saying that if the Dominion Government had not faced with financial courage the situation which confronted us in November last, we should have a very grave and serious situation in Canada to-day. I believe there would have been thousands if not tens of thousands of people out of work, and I would not like to state what might have happened in Canada in consequence. If my hon. friend will go back to November last, he will realize that the entire community was greatly excited over what would happen once the war came to an end and all our war industries ceased. Directly and indirectly there were 200,000 people, men and women, engaged in munitions work and in the supply of other war material, and in other enterprises connected with those industries and in industries basic to them. That was the situation with which the Government was confronted. We had to find not only the credits with which our wheat and flour, our cheese and meat products were to be purchased, but we also had to face that very acute industrial situation which caused the utmost anxiety to the labouring population in Canada and to business generally, and to all the people interested in the welfare of the country and in the preservation of order in the community. Faced with that situation, and knowing the international financial conditions to which I have referred, the Government, at the instance of the Prime Minister (Sir Robert Borden), appointed an Overseas War Mission headed by Mr. Lloyd Harris, who did such successful work as head of the British War Mission at Washington in obtaining orders for Canada, and whose work was referred to by the President of the Privy Council in connection with his estimates the other evening. The Prime Minister went overseas himself, and accompanying him were Mr. Lloyd Harris, Mr. Frank Jones, Dr. Robertson, formerly of the Department of Agriculture, and Mr. Draper. The three important national interests, mercantile, labour, and agriculture, were represented.
Those men have been working over there most assiduously since November last, and I am surprised now to hear the hon. member for Maisonneuve ('Mr. Lemieux), although he paid the absent Minister of Trade and Commerce a compliment on the personal side, find fault with the minister whose work, to my knowledge, and on the reports which I have received from men who have been over there, ihas been of the most efficient kind for the benefit of Canada. The Minister of Trade and Commerce has really done admirable work in connection with the important question of finding markets for Canada's grain and meat products and other supplies, and the representatives of the Western Grain Growers and the Western Grain Exchange, ,who went overseas last fall, paid the highest tribute to the work done by him in connection with the important matters in which they were interested.
The Prime Minister has given the closest attention to the subject of the promotion of Canada's trade overseas. I have been in constant cable communication with him, and hundreds of cables have passed relating to matters of shipping, and to the general trade of Canada and its extension to Europe at this time. The purpose of the' Prime Minister in constituting that commission to London was to obtain business for Canada, and to take up the slack of the factory production which was interrupted by the cessation of the war. Hon. gentlemen can picture to themselves what effect the closing of these munition plants, on the scale that we had them in Canada, and of the allied industries immediately affected, would have, and what the result would be, unless we could replace that business by an equal, or at all events a large, volume of export trade. Remember we were manufacturing what we needed for ourselves and our productive capacity for munitions and war supplies bore relation to our export trade. Therefore, unless we could substitute export trade for what we had here, only one result could ensue, and that was that our industries could only run on partial capacity, and that tens of thousands of men would be out of work all over Canada. Mr, Lloyd Harris, as head of the Canadian Mission in London, has not only been doing his utmost to obtain trade for Canada, but has from the very first urged and insisted that Canadian industries

should send their own representatives over there in order that they might not only assist him, and have the benefit of the cooperation of himself and his office, but at the same time push to the utmost for business themselves; and I understand that some two hundred representatives of practically all the industries of Canada are in London to-day on the summons of Mr. Lloyd Harris, and working in co-operation with him for the benefit of our export trade. I think it is a mistake to say that that export trade is for the benefit of a few manufacturers; it seems to me .that it is not a fair statement of the situation. We often play politics in this House, but is it a fair statement to say that the promotion of the export trade of Canada is for the benefit of a few manufacturers? There are hundreds of millions of dollars-

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: I saw the agreement that was made for Rumania, and it seems to me it is all for the manufacturers, except one-fifth.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speakerposition: Minister of Finance and Receiver General
speechtext:
I will come to that in a moment. I make no objection to my hon. friend raising the question, because I am the last one to deny information on public affairs. This is an important Bill, and I desire to satisfy my hon. friend by making a very full statement: There are hundreds of millions of dollars invested [DOT] in important manufacturing establishments in this country. They employ hundreds of thousands of men whose families are maintained by their wages, and they in turn by the expenditure of their money , promote the business of the country. So that the getting of export trade for Canada for our manufactured goods, as well as for our grain and natural products, is not for the benefit of a few manufacturers, but for the welfare of the people of Canada as a whole. If, as .1 said before, we did not push for that trade, and if we did not get trade of that character for Canada, we should have a very grave situation on our hands to-day.
Now we come to the question of the credits which we shall extend. In the first place- and hon. gentlemen opposite I take it assent to that-we shall have to continue to make extensive loans to Great Britain for the purchase of our foodstuffs and the timber and other products which Great Britain will want from this country. In case some hon. gentlemen may not understand the situation, let me say that the burden on us this year is going to be very heavy because we are demobilizing in Canada, and con-

sequently. we have a higher expenditure in respect of our men coming upon the Treasury here than we would have if those men were overseas, and we were borrowing money from Great Britain for their maintenance in the Old Country and in France, and setting off that expenditure against the advances which we make to 'Great Britain here. I have explained that with respect to last year's wheat crop, we have found, or undertaken to find, no less a sum than $170,000,000, and I have no doubt that with regard to foodstuffs we shall have to make further advances to Great Britain, although I am glad to say that free markets are being established as quickly as possible with respect to all our commodities. Now we have the wheat crop of this year coming on, which we hope will be a large crop, and I do not know to what extent Europe will have to rely on us for credits for the purchase of that. But no matter what we have, we certainly must, and will, ensure the financing of the exportable surplus of the wheat crop of Canada for this year. My own view is that that should be the first demand to be satisfied, it is of such great importance to the entire country. Now we come to these other credits. There was common talk here in November of last year that Canada should strongly push for a portion of the re-construction business in Belgium, France and other devastated countries of Europe. Europe must be restored. Not only will food be required to maintain the population, but raw material and partly manufactured, and manufactured goods of various kinds, in which Canada can compete I think with any other nation, will be required on a vast scale. Now I submit that if the Government had not taken the step which it did in establishing the War Mission and providing credits, hon. gentlemen opposite, headed by my good friend the leader of the Opposition (Mr. McKenzie) would to-night be most severely censuring the Government for not having done precisely what the Government has done. They would have very much better reason for censure in that case, because the conditions in this country, if we had not done what we did, would have been so serious that Opposition criticism would have counted very much more than it does now. Now I beg my friend the leader of the Opposition to take my word for it that we are not doing anything on the other side in the way of financing that we can avoid doing if we are to get the business.

On section 2-Contents of French foot.
Mr.'A. K. MACLEAN: On the first reading of the Bill the object of this clause was explained very fully. The change proposed is cbnsequent upon the recommendation of the International Bureau of Weights and Measures to secure what is expected to be a more accurate definition of the French foot. So far as Canada is concerned, the French foot is employed only in the province of Quebec, and in connection with land surveys. The French foot as at present defined contains 12-79 inches, and the correction only amounts to -001. I understand this change is approved of by the Incorporated Society of Surveyors in the province of Quebec, and I do not think there can be any objection to it.

No, this clause
merely provides for the transfer of the administration of weights and measures from the Inland Revenue Department to the Department of Trade and Commerce, which transfer was made some months ago. Further, the clause gives a definition of the word " Inspector." I think perhaps my hon. friend's question refers to another clause.

speechtext: I consulted the law officer of the Crown, and he thought it was quite proper to have that section. I do not think it will repeal whatever is applicable in the Criminal Code. It is practically impossible to invoke the Criminal Code in these matters. I do not know whether my hon. friend has had any experience himself in the prosecution of offenders under the Act; I have not myself.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: It does seem to me that a trader who sells goods under weight should be prosecuted to the full limit of the law. He is committing theft, he is obtaining money by false representations, and the public ought to be protected against such dishonesty in the most careful manner. But I think we are simply putting a premium on crime by abrogating the provisions of our criminal law which deal in a proper way with these cases. In the poorer parts of the larger cities people of modest circumstances should be protected by legislation of a vigorous kind. As I said before, the trader will take his chances and sell goods under weight when the only risk he faces is this trifling fine of $25. It seems to me it is a dangerous departure, and as far as I am concerned I would be in favour of striking that clause from the Bill.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv
speechtext: The intention is to have the law directed or levelled against the principal, not against the agent.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_07.csv

I do not know
that there is any objection to the amendment moved by my hon. friend, although I very much doubt the wisdom of expecting observance of the law by the imposition of an increased penalty for second and subsequent offences. I hardly think that frequent prosecutions and the imposition of excessive penalties would bring about the desired result, but if the public know that a dealer has been fined for delivering short weight goods, those practices would, I think, very soon cease.

When that is enacted, we shall have complete legislation requiring all containers to have on the label the exact contents of the packages. _

If this condition continues, eastern manufacturers will lose their trade in the western market. There is no reason why they should be allowed to defraud our people, for that is what it amounts to.
