Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
I am pleased to find that the minister is taking every reasor able step to meet the views of these men. I do not profess to be a military or a naval man, I am only ' an ordinary lawyer; but if this document were dealing with ordinary-commercial business, I would have to say that it dates from the signing of the armistice, because hostilities did end on that date. Whether the man who drafted it meant that or not, that is 'the language of the Order. I understand that the contracts that men sign in the infantry contain the expression " six months after the end of the war." "The end of the war" and "the cessation of hostilities" are separate and distinct things. There have been no hostilities since the armistice was signed, and unless there is some peculiar interpretation of naval and military contracts, those men have the right to believe that their six months commenced to run from the 11th of November last and will expire on the 11th of this month. Those men are Canadians and are deserving of our best attention. They are not rebellious. They interpret their contract in a certain way, and it is quite possible that they got the opinion of some legal gentleman in Halifax in regard to it. I would like the minister to take positive action, so that those men will see that they are not treated as if they were nobody, that "they can mutiny if they like and they will see where they are going to land." I do not want them to have that idea; I want them to feel that the minister is concerned about their welfare and will see that they are properly treated. If they do hear something from the department before the 11th recognizing their position,
I presume they will be pleased and there will be no trouble; whereas if they are ignored, if nothing is done beyond the stereotyped reply that the minister makes to me across the#floor, we may have another Kin-mel situation on our hands. We do not want anything of that kind; rather we desire our naval as well as the rest of our military operations to end properly, for we may want those men again. That was mentioned in one of the letters addressed to me, that naval and military men may

be required at other critical stages of our national life, and it is well not to leave any stings or heartburnings in connection with their demobilization. I hope such action will be taken that those men will realize that they are treated as Canadians who have rendered good service to their native country and in whom the Government feel a deep interest.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
If the minister will say: " Within a few days," that will be of great importance to the district.
Major-General MEWBURN: If, as my hon. friend apparently thinks, the demobilization of these men were simply a matter

of walking out and locking the door, I would be very glad to have it done, but there is a little more required in. the way of cleaning up matters than the hon. member would imagine.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
I wish to support what the hon. member for Westmorland has said as to the demand from all over the country, not only from Western Canada but from Eastern Canada as well, for the release as soon as possible of the men who are required on the farms and in the industries of this country.
I rose more particularly to refer to the statement made by the Acting Prime Minister last evening as to the accounts of Canada. He gave a very complete account of our war expenditure, but did not give the statement that I more particularly required as to the exact financial position of the country. However, as we are led to believe that the Budget will be brought down shortly, .1 suppose that the Minister of Finance intends to give that statement then.
The Committee is no doubt aware that the vote of $350,000,000 now under consideration represents a sum greater than the total debt of Canada prior to 1914. The Government at this session are asking for enormous credits, and I am not sure that the country fully realizes the magnitude of these credits. The Estimates that have already been brought down provide for an expenditure of $437,000,000 odd; this item is $350,000,000; the level crossing Bill calls for an expenditure of $200,000; highways about $20,000,000, and housing $25,000,000. A total of $832,000,000 is asked for, and we are yet to have Supplementary Estimates, judging from the statements made by the different ministers. Hon. gentlemen on this side of the House do not intend to criticize this vote so far is it relates to defence and demobilization. We have supported during the war all the votes the Government has taken for war purposes.
Last evening as I listened to the Acting Prime Minister I could not help thinking that he was setting up a man of straw for the purpose of knocking him dawn. He was trying to make the country believe that we on this side of the House were not in favour of encouraging the manufacturing industries of this country. The facts are quite to the contrary. The Liberal party has never discouraged the manufacturing industries of this country. In fact, the manufacturers as well as the farmers of this country enjoyed their greatest pros-

perity during the fifteen years of the late Liberal administration. It never was, and is not to-day, the policy of the Liberal party to do anything to injure the manufacturing industries of this country. We wish to help them, and we believe that the best way to help them is by removing certain restrictions which to-day are an incubus upon them, as well as being very harmful to the agricultural interests of this country. We believe that the larger and the wider the market we can obtain for our agricultural products, the better it will be for the manufacturing interests of this country.
Last evening the Acting Prime Minister laid great stress upon the rate of exchange and the adverse trade balance against Canada. I wish to say to him that he and his Government are in some measure responsible for the adverse trade balance against Canada at the present time. I would remind him, so that he may deal with the matter when he brings down his Budget, that his action in connection with the pulp and paper industry in this country did very much to create an adverse trade balance against us. Had he treated properly the pulp and paper industries of this country, had he allowed them greater freedom in exporting their product, it would have been better for Canada and better for that industry. If that had been the policy of the minister, instead of the trade being curtailed, it would have expanded.
Now let me give a case in connection with agricultural products. No later than last fall this Government put an embargo on dairy products going out of this country. They fixed the price on the products of butter and cheese factories. The farmers all along the international line'-the embargo did not apply for the whole length of the international line because deputations came here from Manitoba and Saskatchewan protesting against the embargo -these farmers, when the price of butter and cheese was fixed began to ship their milk and cream to the United States. So the Government put an embargo against dairy products entering the United States. When we buy corn from the United States for our dairy herds, we are ready to pay for it with butter and cheese. Otherwise, we must pay in money. That is another reason why we have an adverse trade balance, and this Government have largely contributed in bringing it about.
The hon. member for Centre Toronto (Mr. Bristol), whose voice I regret we

do not hear oftener in this House, referred to a condition that prevailed on the lower St. Lawrence in connection with some ship at Seven Islands. He made the statement that a mill at Seven Islands had been offered a 10,000-ton ship which they could not use, but that had they been able to get a ship of lesser tonnage they would have been able to avail themselves of it. That reminded me that the Government, who boast that they are trying to do so much for Canadian industry, have again come in and crippled a Canadian industry in Ontario. That story of the Seven Islands brought to my mind the fact that there is at Thorold a very large paper mill, which I understand is controlled by the Chicago Tribune. They manufacture pulp at Seven Islands. This company own their own vessels which for several years have been carrying pulp from Seven Islands to Thorold, and which are under American register. Sometime early this spring the American Lake Shippers' Association convinced their board at Washington that it would be a good thing to cancel the reciprocity in trade that existed between the United States and Canadian vessels on the Upper Lakes, and the Canadian Government retaliated. The result is that boats of Canadian register are not now allowed to trade from one United States port to another, and our Government have brought in regulations preventing boats of United States register from trading between two Canadian ports. This mill is unable to get boats to carry pulp from Seven Islands to the mill at Thorold, and no later than last Saturday a representative of that company, whom I accidentally met at the Chateau Laurier, told me that unless they could obtain vessels somewhere the mills at Thorold were going to be closed down-. This is one example of what our Government are doing to " assist " Canadian industry- assist in crippling it. Let that same condition be protracted until the fall, and when we commence moving our grain and wheat crop from the head of the Great Lakes the farmers of Western Canada will be at the mercy of a combine of shipowners in Canada. These shipowners will fix the rates and the western farmer will have to pay the piper. But he will not have much reason to complain because his representatives in this Parliament support a Government that is responsible for these conditions.
Last evening the hon. Acting Prime Minister made much of the important

duties that Mr. Lloyd Harris was discharging-what he had done for Canada at Washington and was now doing at London. I could not help thinking of the position that Mr. Lloyd Harris occupies. Mr. Lloyd Harris, a very good personal friend of mine, left the Liberal party because that party wanted to obtain wider markets and trade with the United States. That was his only reason. Now how can we hope to get extended business for this country when we send as a representative a man who only a few years ago was absolutely opposed to export trade, and whose policy was the home market and only the home market? If my information is correct, we in Canada are suffering from an unfortunate condition of affairs in England. I am making this statement publicly, so that the ministers may interest themselves in it, because the matter to which I am about to refer is common gossip in London, England, and in Canada. The statement is that in London the secretary or some of the officials in the High Commissioner's office and some of the officials in the Trade Commission are not on speaking terms, and that when communications from Canada, intended for certain of these officials in London, go to the other officials, instead of being mailed directly to those in London for whom they are intended, they are sent back to Canada and have to be re-mailed to the proper parties. The sooner that sort of thing is straightened out the better it will be for Canada. These conditions prevail, not amongst the men higher up- I have no fault to find with Sir George Perley or Sir Edward Kemp; they are suffering from the incompetence of understrappers who are running the office over there to the detriment of Canada-and the sooner this Government instruct their representatives over there to get rid of these understrappers who are causing injury to the trade of this country, the better it will be for Canada.
I am sorry I have taken up so much time. I do not intend delaying the passage of this Bill, but there is another matter to which I wish to draw the attention of the Acting Prime Minister so that he may be in a position to make a statement in regard to it when he brings down the Budget. Or perhaps the Minister of Railways (Mr. Reid) may deal with it when he has his estimates before us. During the past few years we sold a great many rails which had been ripped up from the railways throughout Canada. Those rails were sent overseas, and I have never seen in any of the printed statements any account of
them. I think the people would like to know who owes us for those rails and if we are to be paid for them, or if they are taken into consideration in the accounts that will be filed of the indebtedness to us by Germany and those who owe us.

speakerposition: Minister of Finance and Receiver General
speechtext:
Yes, but there might have been some borrowing power in respect to the previous year. The hon.

gentleman knows that in connection with the Appropriation Bill every year when the general estimates afe passed there is a provision that the borrowing power of the Dominion is so much. Sometimes that is rather arbitrary, but it is put in just to ensure that the Dominion has the borrowing power necessary to raise the money provided in the Appropriation Bill. That is a point that has to be watched by the Finance Department. I asked my deputy to give attention to that in connection with this Bill so that we should not find ourselves without legislative authority in respect to all the amounts which we might have raised by loan in excess of actual borrowing powers at the time. It would not happen in ordinary times, but during the war it did happen that we slightly overborrowed.
Mr. MicKENZIE:	We had power last
year to borrow 3500,000,000. That loan brought to the Treasury 3650,000,000. There is therefore $150,000,000 for which we have no authority under the former Act. Is that to be regarded as part of this $350,000,000, or are we going to borrow out-and-out $350,000,000 under this Act together with the $150,000,000 standing over from last year?

As to section 4, I have looked at it more closely since my hon. friend (Mr. Fielding) spoke, and I would direct his attention to this:
The Governor in Council may, in addition to the sums now remaining unborrowed. . . . raise by way of loan, .... such sum or sums of money, less any amount borrowed in excess of the amounts authorized by any war appropriation Act, as are required for the purpose of making any payment authorized by this Act.
Does my hon. friend see the force of the last few words there? That is to say, this section authorizes us to borrow in any event the amount required for making any expenditure if authorized by this Act. That is the way I would construe those last words:

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, there is a matter of extraordinary importance to the consuming public that I wish to draw to the attention of the Acting Minister of Trade and Commerce (Mr. Maclean). A report appears in yesterday's Toronto Globe in reference to the high cost of butter. An investigation was made by Dr. Hastings, medical health officer of the city of Toronto, who states that:
The demand for export butter at 80 cents per pound governs the price to the local consumer, and this demand has recently increased particularly in the English and United Slates
markets. On the other hand, Dr. Hastings can And no justification for the " enormously high price of oleomargarine."
In another part of the paper it states: Margarine, whidh has been selling in Great Britain at 25 cental a pound, is now 16 cents. Here the manufacturer's price is about 33 cents, with the dealers in some oases getting almost 50 cents.
And it wants to know why there should be this difference. We allow margarine to come into this country free of duty and if the manufacturers are extracting an unfair profit from the consumer an injustice is being inflicted upon the public and the matter is one that should receive the attention of the Government.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
["With regard to
future borrowings, the policy should be to borrow for shorter terms. No one can foresee what interest rates will be. My own view is that 'they are not likely to drop materially for a considerable time; I do not see how they can. What I have said is subject to this:	in putting out loans
one has to consider the financing that has already been done and not have his loans in large amounts too close to the present time. Let me illustrate. Suppose the Dominion Government during the war had been fearful of the comparatively high interest rates and had resorted to short-date borrowing, which is all right for comparatively small amounts in times of high interest rates. And suppose the Minister of Finance had to face within the next five years, let us say, the raising of five, seven or ten hundred million dollars; that would be a very serious matter. The amounts expended in this war, the debt of Canada and the debts of all nations, are so vast that funding is not possible as it would be in normal times. One of the advantages of our situation is that our loans are distributed over five, ten, fifteen and twenty years. I know precisely what my hon. friend has in mind-that we shall have to pay high interest rates over a period of fifteen and twenty years. That is true in respect of certain of our loans. But I do not see what advantage it would be to us within the next five or ten years, having regard to the loans we have to meet before ten years are over, to be in a position to recall the other bonds, because the financial operations would not be possible to

enable us to retire them and replace them with further issues at lower rates; it seems to me that the transactions are too great. I do not like, any more than my hon. friends, the idea that the Dominion has to pay that rate of interest over so long a period. But short-date borrowing is almost fatal in war time, because you get accumulations of debt ahead of you and when you need fresh money you are confronted with maturities coming due, and a very serious situation results."]

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speakerposition: Minister of Marine and Fisheries; Minister of the Naval Service
speechtext:
No, for the forty-five ships; all that are under contract.
I stated in the House a year ago that it was the policy of the Government to utilize only existing s'teel shipyards. But there existed at Prince Rupert a large shiprepairing plant and floating dry dock, and considerable pressure was brought to bear upon the Government, especially as the war was proceeding at that time in a way that did not look favourable to us, and tonnage was very badly needed, to place some orders out there. I took the ground that the Government were not investing money in shipyards, but that if any firm would come along with the necessary capital the Government would be! willing to give them a share of their business. That accounts for the placing of orders for two ships of 8,100 tons at Prince Rupert
Victoria, B.C., likewise did not have a modern shipyard. The Victoria Machinery Depot had a small place there, and our Victoria friends, especially the late Premier
fMr. Ballantyne.]
Brewster, were very anxious that we should give the city of Victoria part of the Government business. We therefore placed an order with the Victoria Machinery Depot for two ships of 8,100 tons each
Enterprising capitalists of Halifax, Captain Norcross and R. M. Wolvin, said that they were prepared to put $5,000,000 into a modern shipyard there if the Government would give them some business. I shall not weary the Committee with an account of all the interviews that I had and of the requests that these gentlemen made and which the Government could not see their way clear to grant. They wanted us to allow them to bring in free of duty what plant they required; I told them we could not agree to do that. They also wanted a very large order for ships, as their capital expenditure was great; but I told them that all we could do would be to give them an order for four ships, which we have done. When that yard is fully completed- and it will be completed shortly, because the keels of two vessels have already been laid there-it will be one of the finest and best equipped shipyards in the country.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speakerposition: Minister of Marine and Fisheries; Minister of the Naval Service
speechtext:
This is a little different from the statement in a newspaper article that I have before me. I did not want to take up the time of the House, but if it will bear with me for a moment I will just refer to it. Mr. Hurley, the chairman of the United States Shipping Board, says that they have built 555 ocean-going steel ships, that they have contracts for 1,336 similar vessels yet to be built, and that when the programme is finished they will have 16,732,700 tons of shipping. Mr. Hurley's proposal, which he is going to submit

to the American Congress, is that the United States Government shall sell these ships to private persons. Mr. Hurley goes so far as to say that he is willing to recommend to the American Government that they be sold, not at the cost of construction to the Government, hut at the cost of construction at the time the sale was made.
He also, of course, states that he hopes the American Government will he able to control rates; but I do not see how they can very well do so. He further states that they are going to set aside the large sum of $15,000,000 for what he calls a Merchant Marine Development Fund, so that if any of their ships are on a trade route that does not prove to toe profitable, the American Government will come to their aid. He also states that the United States is striving to be the leading maritime nation of the world; and consequently we must recognize the keen competition that we are going to have from the States.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
I would like to get information on two points. I understand from the minister that he does not intend to carry out the proposal made in the report of the Marine and Fisheries Department. In that report at page 15 I find that the Government puiposed *o build annually
200,000	tons of merchant shipping at an estimated cost of $40,000,000 to $50,000,000. The minister to-day does not seem to hold the same view, because, if I understand him correctly, he says that when the present orders are filled, the shipbuilders will have to look out for orders elsewhere-I would like him to explain if there is really a change in the policy of the Government in that regard. I quite understand that when this policy was inaugurated ships were very scarce and the policy was justified on account of the war. The criticism of my hon. friend (the leader of the Opposition) is quite pertinent, however, when he says that the Government were very slow, that they allowed three or four years to elapse before they did anything, and then when prices were almost as high as they ever will be and when the war was nearly over they embarked on the shipbuilding programme. When this report was issued I understand the war was over, but in it I find, as I have said, that there is a proposal to go on with this shipbuilding programme.
The minister has told us that the programme is justified in order to afford ocean freight facilities for our railway system. We are undertaking the management of an enormous railway system, and of course we hope to have a great deal of traffic for export to deliver at seaboard. But I think the minister has undertaken to build the wrong class of ships, if he expects them to make connections with the National Railway system- He mentioned that the Government were following the policy of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company. That company has never embarked on the building of tramp vessels. It has built liners that make regular trips, connect with its railway system, and undertake to route goods to certain places and to deliver them on certain dates. That does not seem to be what my hon. friend is doing. He is building a large fleet of slow tramp vessels that are not suitable, and never will be suitable, for that class of work. He tells us that the speed of a certain class is 8 knots, of another class 11 knots, and of the highest class only 13 knots. Well, my hon. friend

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
The statement of the
eminent authority quoted by my hon. friend is that the British yards are booked for two years and that the contracts on which they are working are on a cost plus ten per cent basis. How, therefore, can my hon. friend say in the same breath that the cost is $115 a ton?
iMr. J. H. 1SH1NICL1AH1B: The hon. gentleman is quite correct. We must make that allowance. We cannot produce ships at that rate in Canada. My hon. friend is not able to show that we can logically go on with the building of ships in Canada at the price we are now paying. Of course, we may be able to do it with Government assistance; that is how we are doing it now. But we could not do it without that Government assistance.
This programme is not a shipbuilding programme at all; it is a ship-owning programme. The Government is ordering ships at practically $200 a ton and they are bound to lose part of the money by the time they get through. If the Government arrived at some policy that would
enable private' capital to build the ships, they would be doing something worth while for Canada; but when the Government stop pouring out their money, the shipbuilding will stop. My hon. friend hinted a while ago that the Government did not intend to go very long on this policy of building ships and that the shipbuilders would have to look out for themselves. Well, that is a very poor prospect for any person who wants to put his money in a shipyard. If the Government really want to assist shipbuilding, what they should do is not to buy tramp vessels at enormous prices, but find some means by which the Canadian investor can put his own money into shipbuilding and compete successfully in that business with the outside world.
The minister is simply buying ships at a very high price, a price that will enable any builder to build them for him, but he is not doing anything to make it possible later on for a Canadian to build ships himself and to enable the Canadian people to become maritime ship-owning people. That is really a matter that the Government ought to tackle. The shipbuilding efforts of the Government have so far not been very successful. The trawlers, about which the hon. member for Victoria (Sir Sam Hughes) spoke a few minutes ago, were built in the yards of Vickers, and Poison's.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
The Canadian
Pacific, I understand, never owned tramp steamers as such. They have some old passenger steamers which they are using for carrying freight, but they are not in the tramp steamer business.
I was referring to trawlers that were built by the present Administration in connection with the war. I have been looking over the accounts for the construction of those trawlers, which accounts any hon. member can find in the room where the Public Accounts Committee meets, and I find that the seven trawlers that were sold at

Halifax recently cost $704,955.51. It would appear from the information that we get from questions answered by the minister that they all had to undergo repairs very shortly after they were built; that they were built in such a haphazard way that they were unseaworthy. According to the Public Accounts, $134,917.22 was expended in repairs. Those trawlers were sold a few weeks ago.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
The Committee were told last night that this was a matter that would come better from the Minister of Naval Affairs, and that an opportunity would be given to-day to discuss this very [DOT]important matter. I was surprised that the Minister of Naval Affairs took his seat without making any reference whatever to the serious charges brought before the Committee last night by the hon. member. There were charges of incompetence, of extravagance, of injustice in regard to the employment and handling of men, and although some of them were very serious charges no reply to them has yet come from the Minister of Naval Affairs. We were told that a certain warship called the Lady Evelyn was well equippeu and well officered and was in the vicinity of a German submarine at the time the latter was sinking fishing vessels off the coast of Nova Scotia.
But instead of being employed, as she was intended to he employed, in protecting the vessels and the fishermen from the German submarine, she was sent to the Magdalen Islands with half a dozen lead

pencils and some packages of paper. I believe it is true that the log of the Lady Evelyn shows that on the very day the German submarine was sinking Nova
Scotia ships off Ganso the ILady Evelyn was within 80 miles of 'the point where the submarine was operating.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speakerposition: Minister of Marine and Fisheries; Minister of the Naval Service
speechtext:
The item under discussion is a vote of $30,000,000 for the building of the Government merchant marine.
I am sorry that an engagement prevented me from being in the House last night when the hon. member for Lunenburg made his long list of charges in regard to naval affairs. II have not had time to read those charges yet, but I shall do so at the first opportunity, and when the Naval Estimates are under consideration I shall reply to them. I think, Mr. Chairman, the hon. gentleman should confine his remarks to the item before us, which has to do with marine, and not with naval affairs.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speakerposition: Minister of Marine and Fisheries; Minister of the Naval Service
speechtext:
It is rather difficult for me to follow the hon. member. He refers to the Government merchant marine ships as tramp ships. If these ships are tramp ships, then all cargo vessels that ply the various waters are also tramp ships. The hon. member goes on to say that unless a ship is a passenger ship she cannot make time from one port to another. For the life of me, I cannot see why a ship, we will say of eleven knots sea speed, leaving the port of Montreal for Liverpool should not make her schedule time just the same as a passenger ship can. My hon. friend is a business man and he realizes that cargo ships are necessarily for carrying cargoes, and that it would not be an economical policy for the Government to build palatial passenger vessels to carry the cargoes that these ships are designed to carry. He goes on to say that there is no difference between the freight ships built in the United States, in England, or in Canada. He must know that there is a vast difference in the design, speed and types of ships, just as there is in the various kinds of automobiles that are made.
I cannot understand the hon. member when he classes all freight ships together, as regards cost and design. He is at a loss to 
know what particular use the Government are going to make of their merchant marine ships to co-operate with the railways, and suggests that instead of having these freight ships we should have passenger ships plying on the various oceans. Every one knows that a passenger ship has not as much available space for cargo as a cargo ship, and therefore the policy of the Government is a sound business policy. These ships were never designed to carry passengers at all, but were designed and are being built to carry cargoes. They are what the Canadian National Railway Company wants, because the government ships will carry freight from the Orient to Vancouver, and the Canadian National Railway System will carry the freight to whatever point in Canada it may be destined for.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
It could hardly be understood as being for the transportation of troops, because it is for " the promotion of trade and industry and the transportation facilities therefor." We could hardly be expected to provide for transportation facilities outside of the building, buying of chartering of ships. How could we expend money under this Bill for the promotion
of transportation facilities except through the Department of Marine and Fisheries or Naval Affairs?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext: Hon. members need not be in such a hurry. The section will be carried when we are through with it, and not before. Some hon. members do not seem to appreciate the importance of this clause, and we shall discuss it as long as we deem it necessary to do so. I am not quite satisfied with the explanation given by the Acting Prime Minister. The scope of this clause is very wide. This is for carrying out any measures deemed necessary in consequence of the war, not for the prosecution of the war, because the war is over. How far will it go? Where will the Government stop? Now that the war is over, are we, by this Bill, going to have government by Order in Council, just as during the past five years? I do not think the people of this country would be satisfied with such a condition of things.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speakerposition: Minister of Finance and Receiver General
speechtext: It is not always wise to state precisely how one intends to raise money, but I think I said in the House a short time ago that it would be necessary to have a domestic loan this coming fall, possibly in September. We have some borrowing to do in New York between now and August next, but the borrowing under this Bill will be by way of a domestic loan. I shall not state to what amount we shall borrow, because I am unable to state that accurately. It might be that we would borrow temporarily from the banks and make a loan for the remaining amount. I say that because interest rates are pretty high, and it is advisable to limit the amount of the loan to as low an amount as possible, in order that we may not have to pay a high rate of interest over a period of years.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speakerposition: Minister of Finance and Receiver General
speechtext: That is a frequent clause in company legislation and arises out of a decision-some of the lawyers in the House will recall it-under which it was held that if securities had been pledged*, and the amount of the loan paid off and the securities got back again, they could not then be sold, that they became extinguished by virtue of their redemption; hence this clause, which, I believe, is usually inserted. Supposing the Dominion had issued bonds with the intention of selling them outright but in the meantime had borrowed against them from the bank-which the Dominion now seldom does-and paid off the loan to the bank, and then desired to sell the securities, it is advisable that they should be able to sell them without getting fresh borrowing powers; in other words, that they should not be deemed to be extinguished. Frequently loans are effected for the purpose of carrying securities which it is intended to sell and repay the loan from the proceeds so obtained.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
I desire to direct the attention of the Minister of Militia (Mr. Mew-burn) to a matter that is important in the passing of this measure, because a certain portion of the money that we are voting in this Bill is to be expended in demobilizing the different military depots throughout Canada. Since the armistice was signed, there have been kept in military district No. 7 at St. John, N.B., some two or three or four hundred men. iSome have been released from duty at different times so that I cannot say exactly how many men are at present engaged in this garrison duty, whatever that may imply, at this military depot. Quite a large number of these men are farmers' sons who have been kept there during the winter month's when they were much needed at home to look after the farm work and provide wood and other fuel for the winter as is always customary in country districts. Some of them whom I know well, are married men With farms of their own. I have given this particular matter a great deal of consideration; I have visited the place on several occasions; I have talked with the officers,
[DOT] and, in my judgment, theTe is no reason for keeping two or three hundred men at St. John doing garrison duty when they do not want to remain there. If they were returned men waiting to be discharged who wanted to remain there, then I am prepared to say that they are entitled to re-cieve their per diem allowance and whatever is necessary to keep them there.' But these were men who were called for duty to St. John after the armistice was signed and who have been kept there ever since at the expense of this country. They are doing no good either to this country or to themselves; they are absolutely idle around this military garrison or depot or headquarters, or whatever may be the correct military term, and I * would suggest to the minister that these men should be allowed to return to their homes, thus saving the country the expense of keeping them there and permitting them to render valuable service on the farms, as is demanded by the men who own farms 
and by the fathers of those who are not farming for themselves. It has been suggested to me by one of the men and one of the officers that the only good reason for keeping these men at St. John is because the officers who are there .must have some excuse for remaining. I asked an officer whom I know very well what they were doing at St. John and why it was necessary to keep these men there. I had been down there and examined the situation, and the men were apparently not doing anything. This officer turned round to me and said: " Copp, what do you expect us to do?" Hon. members can draw their own conclusions. I have not the slightest objection if the officers who are there are returned men and it is necessary to keep them there in the pay of the Government. If that be the case I hold up both hands and say: Do so. But it is not necessary to keep two or three hundred men at St. John who do not want to stay for that -purpose. I have had communications; I have had correspondence with the officers in regard to the matter, and this is a mere case of keeping men there against their will; it is doing the state no good; it is an expense to the country, and it is causing a hardship to the farmers, because the men ought to be engaged in the work of greater production. I would, therefore, urge the Minister of Militia as strongly as I can to look into this matter and release these men from further service.
Major-General MEWBURN: There are eleven military districts in Canada. The hon. gentleman refers to Military District No. 7, St. John, New Brunswick, where we have maintained a very small garrison unit which is considered, from a military standpoint, absolutely necessary for a certain period during demobilization. We gave the men who have seen service at the front the first privilege of discharge, and some men were retained there, but after the armistice was signed nobody was taken there except some men who volunteered. The men are being released as rapidly as possible, and I am glad to inform my hon. friend that, on account of the opening of navigation in the St. Lawrence, very few troops now disembark at St. John and most of that unit will be demobilized -within a few weeks.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext: Where do we get the steel plates?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
It is true. Now, a Government ship was sent from Canada to the West Indies under special conditions and my hon. friend (Mr. J. H. Sinclair) complains that the ship came back from the West Indies to New York with a cargo. Did he want her to come back empty. The hon. gentleman is a shipping man; he owned three of the poorest ships that ever crossed the Atlantic. My hon. friend criticises the Government for taking up shipbuilding. Are we to wait until the time when shipbuilding will pay? Was the building of the Canadian Pacific railway delayed until every one was sure that it would pay? No, we built it in order that it would bring returns to the country and afford transportation facilities, and that is the policy I hope the Government will carry out in respect to shipbuilding. There are many reasons for believing that at Sydney Harbour we can procure the cheapest pig iron in the world; why, therefore, can we not produce the cheapest ships in the world? The only advantage that the Old Country has over us in the matter of shipbuilding is the advantage of wages-and surely we do not wish to curse this Dominion with cheap labour. About twenty years ago we built a ship at Three Rivers-it was either the Montcalm or that other little ice-breaker we have down there-and it did not cost so very much more than it would have cost to build it in the Old Country; the difference was simply the higher wages, which is the cost of labour, I repeat that we do not want to curse this country with cheap labour.
We have at Sydney Harbour blast-furnaces, open-hearth furnace and a plate mill in course of construction. We have a rail mill that has sent from Sydney Harbour around the Horn to British Columbia rails at a lower price than that at which you could send them by rail from the Sault.
We have opportunities for the greatest shipbuilding in the world. Even if within a decade, even if within our lifetime, it should cost a little more to build ships, why should we not be anxious to develop the shipbuilding industry. The member for Maisonneuve (Mr. Lemieux) and the member for Antig-onish and Guysborough (Mr. J. H. Sinclair) are simply trying to stand in the light of this country and to stamp out an industry that represents one of Canada s greatest possibilities. We have our coal; we have our coke; we have our iron; we have our steel; we have our blast furnaces; we have our open-hearth furnaces; we have plate mills in course of construction; we have a rail mill from which rails have been shipped in competition with England to be used in railway construction in the north of Ireland, Tight in Belfast. In view of these facts it is too bad that prominent public men should try to throw cold Water upon Canada's greatness. All we want is more people, more money, and more development, and the sooner we get it the sooner shall -we see in Canada ships built as cheaply as they are built on the Clyde or at Belfast.
The only insurance that it in any way high in Canada is the insurance applicable to the upper reaches of the St. Lawrence, and that is quite natural. It is a large inland waterway that must be piloted for six or seven hundred miles, where ships without skilful pilots are in danger of being run ashore. But we do not know of any heavy insurance in respect of the ocean ports of Nova Scotia, New Brunswick or Prince Edward Island. When you come to run six or seven hundred miles on the upper St. Lawrence or to the upper reaches of lake Superior, which is 2,500 or 3,000 miles inland, what can you expect? Insurance must be heavy; pilotage must be heavy. From the time you leave Cabot strait, between Nova Scotia and New Brunswick, you must have two, three, four or five pilots on each ship. Shipping in Canada is one of the big questions, and the sooner we give encouragement to a Government that is prepared to go ahead with a bold policy in the matter, the sooner we shall become a shipbuilding country.
It is not many years ago; it is within the lifetime of almost every man in this Chamber that Nova Scotia built the County of Yarmouth, the largest wooden ship that ever floated on the seven seas of the world. I can remember when she ran ashore on a ledge in Sydney harbour. Is there any reason for believing that Nova Scotia can-

not build the largest steel ship in the world, when she has the men and the coal, when* she has the steel and every other commodity that enter into the building of a ship? That is the situation, and I say: All power to the Government that goes ahead with a real, good, strong, forcible shipbuilding policy, and let the Government give us the largest plant in Sydney harbour it possibly can.

On the Preamble:

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
government .shipbuilding programme
-STATEMENT BY HON. MR. RALLANTYNE MINISTER OF MARINE
The House again in 'Committee of Supply, Mr. Boivin in the Chair.
Public Works-Marine Department-Government Shipbuilding Programme:-Amount required for the construction of vessel® in accordance with Government's programme-$30 000 -000.	.	(ii
Hon. CHARLES C. BALLANTYNE (Minister of Marine): Mr. Chairman, before we take up this, item in a general way, I think it would toe fitting for me to give to this House all the details that I possess in regard to the Government shipbuilding programme. A year ago I had the honour of introducing the Government's merchant marine shipbuilding policy. A great many changes have taken place since the armistice has been signed, and it seems to me to be an opportune time to furnish to this House all the information that I have on the subject for which the vote is now asked.
I think it would be well for us to look for a moment at the shipping conditions of the world, and particularly as they existed in Canada when the Government deemed it wise to embark on its shipbuilding policy. Up to about February or March, 1918, the Imperial Munitions Board were occupying all the vacant steel shipyards in Canada building ships for England. I believe that the Government of Great Britain is to be congratulated for its energy and foresight in not only having ships built to the fullest capacity of the immense shipyards of the United Kingdom, tout also for utilizing all the available yards in Canada.
But, Sir, when I became Minister of Marine I could not see what particular value the steel ships that were being built in Canada for England could be to our own country, and after considering the matter from every point of view I thought the time had come when Canada should have her own merchant marine. Therefore I had the honour and privilege of recommending to my colleagues in the Government that we should utilize our own yards to build up a national merchant marine, and, much as we admire the old country jand desire at all times to render her every assistance possible, more particularly when she is engaged in war, I con-

sider that we were doing not only our full duty to Canada, but also to the Empire when we took that course.
It will be remembered that there was an immense total loss of shipping at that time, about 15,000,000 gross tons, the war being at a very serious and critical stage, and the success of Great Britain and her Allies depending very largely on the extent of their merchant marine. So pressing was the need for tonnage that all Canadian ships under Canadian register and all ships plying in Canadian waters under British register were commandeered by the British Ministry of Shipping, a fact which left Canada devoid of a merchant marine.
At that time, Mr. Chairman, all of our Allies, with the exception of our neighbour to the south, were coming to me constantly to know if I would allow them to build ships in our yards1-I refer particularly to France and to Italy, and also to Norway, one of the neutral powers. I had to reply to the overtures made to me that the policy of the Canadian Government was to utilize to the fullest extent our own steel shipyards, and that therefore we could not look with favour upon building ships for them. It was not so much a matter of price. Many of our Allies' were willing to pay from $20 to $25 per ton more than this Government was paying for the ships it was having built under contract.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
Preamble agreed to.
Bill reported.
On motion of Sir Thomas White, the House adjourned at 11.45 p.m.
Friday, May 9, 1919.

speakerposition: Minister of Marine and Fisheries; Minister of the Naval Service
speechtext:
Yes. I wish to explain why the Government found it necessary to pay British Columbia shipbuilders $10 per ton more than eastern shipbuilders. First of all, I endeavoured to place contracts with British Columbia shipbuilders at the eastern prices, but they pointed out. that the labour cost was $7 per ton more in British Columbia than in the East, and that freight rates were very much higher. After a great many interviews, extending over some months, the Government agreed to pay the British Columbia shipbuilders $10 per ton more than the eastern price for a similar type of ship. For instance, if an 8,100-ton ship was being built by Vickers of Montreal for $180 per ton, the price for a similar ship in the British Columbia yards would be $190 per ton.
There has been some criticism of myself, especially by the British Columbia ship-

builders, because I would not allow them to take foreign contracts. When the war was on, France, Norway, and Italy were urging us to allow ships to be built here for them. I would gladly have consented had we been able to get sufficient ship plates, marine engines, boilers, and the other necessary equipment for our own needs, and at the same time have a surplus for ships to be built on foreign accounts; but unfortunately, notwithstanding the fact that we had an agreement with the United States for 80,000 tons of plate; up to the time of the signing of the armistice we had only been able to get some 6,000 tons. So I could do nothing else than say to these gentlemen that Canada could not afford to delay her own shipbuilding programme by building ships on foreign account.
With regard to the slowness of the construction of some of our ships, I admit that the yards have taken very much longer than I anticipated, but the delay has been unavoidable owing to the shortage of skilled and unskilled labour, and the great difficulty in getting shipbuilding plate from the United States, as well as engines, boilers, and other equipment. The ships are coming along more rapidly now than when the war was on. Before I leave the subject, I might say that quite recently there has been a great demand for space. Our ships are going to be operated by the Canadian Government Merchant Marine Limited, and naturally manufacturers and firms who have large orders for shipment abroad halve been coming to the Marine Department to know whether or not they can get the tonnage. I have been approached, for instance, by the Dominion Coal Company, who told me that all their ships had been requisitioned by the British Minister of Shipping, and they wanted tonnage to send t*000,0(X) tons of coal to Montreal. They said that unless the Canadian Government could provide the tonnage they might have to close down their mines, which would be almost a catastrophe. The steel men, the pulp men, the sugar men and the general produce merchants all want to know what tonnage the Canadian Government can provide. The British ships that are plying from 'Canadian ports at the present time have seventy per cent of their available cargo space reserved for the British Minister of Shipping, which leaves only thirty per cent for the Canadian export trade.

speechtext:
I had only half
finished my sentence when the minister interrupted me. With regard to the shipbuilding programme of the Government, I have no doubt whatever that the ships we haVe built have cost us altogether too much money. Furthermore, I have no doubt that the situation is very largely due to our tariff policy, which makes it impossible for us to build ships in Canada at a price to compete with the ships built on the Clyde and other points in Great Britain. There may be other factors. The cost of labour, for instance, is a very important item, but that cost has gone up very much in Great Britain during the last year or two. I am told that it is ninety per cent higher in Great Britain than what it was two or three years ago, so the chances are that the cost of labour in Great Britain and Canada will come to be about the same. I think the Canadian workman can do just as much in a day as the British workman, and perhaps more. Our great handicap is our high protective tariff. Something could be done to relieve the situation by
bounties, and bounties have been granted in other countries. Germany and France have both given bounties to shipbuilding. France, indeed, paid bounties not only on the building of ships, but on the running of the ships after they were built. French ships a few years ago, in order to help them compete with British ships built in a free trade country, were paid so much a mile for every voyage made, and we had the ridiculous situation of French captains steering the most crooked course in order to make the longest possible voyage. During all this time Great Britain has held her own, because she has acted on the principle that the cost of the material that goes into the building of the ship is the main thing, and that ships can be built cheap only in a free trade country. The difference between Great Britain and Canada in the cost of the material is enormous. The Financial Post says:
At present, ships built in Canada are costing about double what they cost in the United Kingdom. This its due to the high cost of material which, in turn, is due to the high cost of labour mainly.
Steel plates have been available to buiders in Great Britain at a price of approximately, fifty-five dollars a ton. Compare that with the following schedule, showing the delivered cost of steel per long ton from Pittsburg and Chicago to different points in Canada:

If the man in Vancouver has to pay $102.25 a ton for the plates which the British shipbuilder can get for $55 a ton, how can his ship compete with the ship built in England ? The economic law is very simple. The British and Canadian .ship are both competing for the same business.

speakeroldname: Hon. C. C. BALLANTYNE (Minister of the Naval Service):
speakerposition: Minister of Marine and Fisheries; Minister of the Naval Service
speechtext:
The other day, -when this matter was brought to the attention of the House, I stated that the total number demobilized amounted to 3,490 out of a total establishment of 5,468. I can quite understand these naval men. who are probably tired of the service and anxious to get back to civilian life, all writing that they have nothing to do. But I can assure the hon. member (Mr. McKenzie) that they would not be kept in the Naval Service if they had nothing to do. There has been a great deal of talk in regard to the Niobe. We have altogether a total down there of 779 men; on the Niobe 231, guards in the dockyard, etc., 99; troops in reserve 206; on vessels at Liverpool, Nova Scotia, 40; in hospital 80; to be demobilized this week, 123. The Naval Department cannot let every man in the service go until we can enlist enough civilians to perform the .duties that are necessary ion board the Niobe. -Seamen returned from overseas, boys from the Niobe and members of the accounting staff are kept busy with the details of keeping accounts, discharge, etc., and it is necessary to accommodate on the Niobe both Canadian and Imperial naval men who are returning to Canada. Then, we have to .keep men with the large number of. drifters and trawlers owned by the Imperial Government, and until such time as we can enlist a sufficient number of civilians to take charge of these vessels we could not allow every man to go. Allow me to assure the hon. member that energetic steps are being taken constantly to demobilize these men and to see that this week alone we have demobilized 123. I hope that before long they will all be demobilized. Whoever wrote that letter considered that he was free from service six months after hostilities ceased. I do not claim to be a naval authority, but I know that no man is free from the Canadian Expeditionary Force, and no man is free from the navy, until six months after the War, which means six months after peace has been finally declared. While we do not want to hold these men unnecessarily, it would be very ill-advised, indeed, for any one to be absent without leave on May 11 because I hold that the men are n,ot_ free until six months after the war., But, in any event, I am as anxious as any one else to have them demobilized as rapidly as possible. I am .urging it every day. Just as soon as I can get civilians to take the places of these ratings I will do so. I will have something 
more to say upon the navy when I answer the hon. member for Lunenburg (Mr. Duff), but I regret to note that there always seems to be a tendency to malign our little navy and to say that our men are not doing anything when as a matter of fact they are doing good work and have performed very satisfactory service for King ana country.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext: 1 quite understand that prices vary from time to time, but they have not been going down very much so far. I admit there has been a slight decrease in United States prices- I was saying that the economic law is very simple. A ship -I am speaking of freight vessels-that is built in Halifax or Quebec at $200 a ton cannot possible compete with the ship that is built on the Clyde or the Humber at $100 a ton. If there is a cargo of wheat to carry from River Platte to Liverpool both these ships have a chance at the business, and the ship that costs the less will in the end beat the other. If the Minister of Marine intends to do anything permanent and satisfactory in the way of establishing Canada as a ship-owning country he must adopt a low tariff policy. Give the ship-holder of Canada a fair chance and he will fight his way and win.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
As the clause gives the Government power to determine under what conditions the loan is going to the floated, I think it is proper to draw the attention of the Government to the bitter criticism Which has circulated among the public against the floating of tax-exempt loans. There is, it is true, the question of dollars and cents to be kept in view,-whether the discount that you will lose on the taxable bond will be equalized by the amount that the public exchequer will receive from the taxation on this bond. But there is also something else than the dollars and cents aspect of the question, there is a question of principle; and T say it is not democratic to have bonds floated which are tax exempt. There is a great deal of criticism of the action of the Government in floating tax exempt bonds. It allows those who have made a lot of money during the war, by profiteering or otherwise, and financial and banking institutions which have a lot of money to dispose of, to place that money in tax-exempt bonds. They were either as patriotic as they pretended and boasted they were during the floating of these Victory Loans, in which case they would have subscribed as freely whether the bonds were tax exempt or not, or else some of the feathers should be taken off their caps-and I think the Acting Prime Minister has done that to-night in stating that in his opinion the last loan would not have been as freely subscribed had it not been exempt from taxation; we would have received a certain amount but not have quite as much as we have received by issuing tax-exempt bonds. I had some knowledge of the floating of the last Victory Loan in the district of Quebec, and in that district the exemption did not influence very much the people who subscribed to that loan. They subscribed because an appeal was made to them to do so on the ground that it was necessary, for the successful prosecution of the war, to help our industries and to help the Government to carry on, to accomplish the task which they had on their hands. I believe that if a proper appeal had been made to the people of Canada at large the response would have been equally as good whether the bonds were taxable or exempt. There is a great deal of unrest and criticism among the labour classes at the present time. I have heard a lot of it in Montreal, Toronto and Quebec. The labouring classes contend that we owe great sums of money as a result of our domestic loans.
TSlr Thomas White. 1
To whom do we owe them? We owe them to those who have made money during the war either by war contracts or toy profiteering on the necessaries of life-and we have examples high up. They contend that not only do we owe the capital of our domestic loan to those people who made their money sometimes by the sweat of the working classes, but that those people have taken care that the interest they are going to derive from the money they have loaned to the Government will be tax exempt, and that it will toe the wage earner and the small man who will have to pay the greatest part of the amount which the Government has to raise to meet our expenditures and our liabilities. And thereby we invite to a great extent the criticism which is now so prevalent throughout the country. I believe the better practice would have been even to pay a higher rate of interest or a discount on the floating of our bonds. The true democratic principle is that every one should pay his proper share of the country's expenditure, and if I might be at liberty to offer a little advice to the Government it would be this, that in future when floating loans they should not make them exempt from taxation.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
I will take any suggestion whatsoever and be glad to co-operate with my hon. friend in getting information that this country and Parliament should have. But I would suggest to my hon. friend that it is treating the Opposition rather cheaply if he delegates to one who is supporting the Government on many subjects the duty of the Opposition. I should advise him to readjust his ideas about what the duty of the Opposition is in this House. My suggestion was not made to my hon. friend. It was made to the leader of the Opposition, who, at least, will be able to deal with my point in his own way and at his own time. There has been something said about the price of steel plates in war time, at the present time and before the war. My information, Mr. Chairman, is that the price of steel plates and the price of freights are both tumbling at the present time-tumbling fast-and it will be a good thing- for -the poor people of all countries if the prices of ordinary articles of use in the household tumble at the same time. I think the Government should have something to do with that "tumbling" and should do something not only to relieve the high cost of contracts but to relieve the high cost of living. That is the information we have about both freights and steel plates at the present moment and if it -is correct I think that it is a very good reason why the Government should go very slowly about further extending this shipbuilding programme of theirs.
The minister has asked how we will get our wheat out unless we have ships to carry it. I should like to point out that if we are going too far along the line of high tariffs we will be landed in the situation of keeping both the wheat and the ships. We shall only be able to sell the wheat that we produce when we are up against the competition of the world again if we carry on trade in the way I believe it will be done in the very near future. We can only sell a certain amount of wheat in the world in competition with other countries that are producing it if we take the proper method of building up international trade and you cannot build up international trade or operate ships successfully unless you reduce your tariff in this country.
What is happening on the high seas of the world at the present moment? I am

glad my hon. frend the Minister of Finance (Sir Thomas White) is in his seat because I want this last breeze to reach him before he brings his Budget down which will be fateful in its effect both in regard to the political conditions in this country and to the prosperity and progress of Canada and our ability to take our proper place in the commerce of the world.
I am credibly informed that within three weeks of the armistice British ships laden with cargoes of dry goods from Lancashire and with other merchandise were heading their way, after having done nothing but war work for four years and a quarter, to South America and to other parts of the world. And I want to ask my hon. friend (the Minister of Marine) in regard to this difficulty of getting wheat out, what he thinks those ships would do when .they discharged their cargoes? Why Mr. Chairman, inevitably they would load up with wheat, if it was to be had, and if not, they would load up with some other return cargoes to pay for those dry goods and other merchandise. But we have indulged in the folly of trying to foster a cotton trade in this country; which the biggest man in the cotton trade has said never should have been attempted-that this country is not adapted for it. As we refused in a large measure to take excellent Lancashire cottons-I am talking of pre-war prices-at half the price we have to pay for them in a country where there never should have been a cotton industry, naturally the vessels go elsewhere, and of course they do not take our cargoes babk.
I am glad my hon. friend from Guys-borough raised this question. The trade question is at the root of shipping. The instinct of shipping is in the very blood of Britons, because for centuries they have gone down to the sea in ships. And to try to build up a shipbuilding policy in this country while we maintain a high tariff, is a contradiction in economics, a contradiction to common sense, and diametrically opposed to all commercial history. I wanted to say that on general principles. I wanted to show how, and how alone in my judgment, shipbuilding can be promoted in Canada. I wanted to impress upon the minister (Mr. Ballantyne) and the Government that unless the fiscal policy of the country is changed this shipbuilding policy will be a white elephant, and all the subsidies you may grant, and all the artifices you may use to make it otherwise will fail. I do hope my hon. friend the Minister of Finance has been listening to me, because
this has a most important bearing upon the reconstruction of Canada in which we are all interested, and which we wish to see taking place upon a proper basis and with every chance of this country being the country it should be amongst the nations of the world.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext: Will the Canadian Government ships carry cargo at current market rates?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext: Well, the province is not so great, and'my hon. friend is always well acquainted with everything that is going on in Nova Scotia. His information about Nova Scotia is not confined to what goes on in Cape Breton. We know the encyclopaedic nature of his knowledge, and I do not use the word in any sneering sense. We all admire the hard work that he does on behalf of the Opposition which he leads in this House, and we would be glad to have from him information about this contract between the Government and a company which has its main works in the province of Nova Scotia.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
I want to say just a few words upon this part of the Government's programme and I want those words to be words of moderation. I suppose that shipbuilding in this country was undertaken under the pressure of war time, and as the war is over I trust I shall keep within the bounds of moderation when I express the hope that the Government will very carefully consider this business before they give a very wide extension to it. I was very much interested and edified by the remarks of my hon. friend from Guysborough with regard to the operation of tariffs in relation to shipbuilding. As a matter of fact this shipbuilding programme of the Government is only one more illustration of the extraordinary things which people do when they are under a protective tariff. As my hon. friend indicated, we in Canada are under a very high protective tariff-not the fault of either party. With the exception of the war-time addition to the tariff, the present tariff of Canada was a bequest to the present Government from the previous government. I do not think that is capable of successful contradiction. There has been practically no change, except for war-time additions, from the tariff which prevailed practically from 1896 to 1911. If one comes to think of it, it really seems a ridiculous thing to want to build ships and do commerce at sea under high protective tariff, because a tariff is to prevent the taking of goods into your country, and when a ship goes across the sea with a cargo from Canada, it can only do successful business by bringing back a cargo. So that there is an absolute incompatibility between high tariffs and successful shipping. They do not go on together in the world to any great extent. If you make your tariff high enough you may meed penitentiaries and jails and all sorts of institutions within your country, but you will not need many ships, and if you build them you will not be able to use them. That is not only a matter of sound economic study, as my bon. friend from Guysborough (Mr. Sinclair) has indicated, but it is a matter of history.
There has only been one great shipping country in the world and that has been the
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland under free trade. I promised to use the language of moderation and perhaps I am putting that a little too absolutely, but how near it is to the truth will be brought home to every one in this Committee when we reflect that before the war sixty per cent of the ships of the entire world were being built by and were owned by Great Britain; with her two little islands which occupy less than half the area of the province of Alberta. In the face of that single fact, I think it is scarcely the language of exaggeration to say that there has only been one great shipping country in the world. We hear sometimes about Germany being a competitor with Great Britain in shipping before the war. Before the war more work was being turned out on the Clyde than in the whole German Empire. Germany, to do the work she did do, had to adopt free trade up to a certain point because everybody knows who knows anything about this question that Germany for years was allowing in free of duty all articles entering into the building of ships. For that reason the Committee will understand why I feel that I should be just a little cautious in advising the Government to Embark upon a very large shipbuilding enterprise in Canada and a little cautious about supporting them if they do.
But, as I say, this thing was done under the pressure of war time and from that point of view I should desire to make my criticism of the policy as moderate as possible, especially having regard to the fact that the minister has been suffering from a very serious illness. However, I should not be doing my duty to the Government or the country if I did not say that I do not believe that under her present system of tariffs Canada can compete for one moment with the Old Country in shipbuilding. I do not believe it is a possibility.
I am afraid the Government made a mistake in taking this work out of the hands of the Imperial Munitions Board. We are all familiar with what has been stated openly in the public press about that, and I fear that unless we have a very careful contradiction of these statements we will have to admit that the Government made a mistake in taking this shipbuilding business out of the hands of the Imperial Munitions Board, even during war time because we know that war time produced all sorts of fads, such as shipbuilding, daylight saving, and any number of other nonsensical things which will die a natural death. I do not mean that shipbuilding is a nonsensical proposal;

it is only nonsensical when you attempt to make it a success under a high protective tariff. I would like to make that qualification of my statement.
It is also said that, in the work which we have done in connection with shipbuilding in Canada, we have entered into very unprofitable, if not ruinous, contracts. I do not know much about the Dominion Iron and Steel Company. I suppose we should look for light in connection with this subject from my hon. friend who leads the Opposition (Mr. McKenzie). He must know something about it, as these works are in his constituency, and he will no doubt enlighten the Committee as to the figures which have been published in the daily newspapers, as to the contract that has been entered into between the Dominion Govern- -ment and the Dominion Iron and 'Steel Company and as to the price paid for steel plates. I am sure, from the deep interest that he takes in matters concerning his own constituency, he will give us the benefit of his information and of the accurate statistics which must be within his reach on such a question.
