speakerposition: Minister of Marine and Fisheries; Minister of the Naval Service
speechtext:
I said a moment ago that the Government had not decided what form of aid should be given to the shipbuilders. The matter has not been

considered by the Government, but naturally when the shipyards complete the building of the ships that are ordered by the Government now, and a few more that will be ordered, it will be a problem that the Government will have to deal with, as to whether they will let these shipyards go out of existence altogether or give them a fair amount of protection the same as other Canadian industries are enjoying and have been enjoying for some years. That is all I wish to say on the shipbuilding policy and programme of the Government.
But I want to say something in reference to ship plate contracts. Over a year ago the Government entered into a contract for
250,000	tons of ship plates at $4.15 per hundred pounds based on the price of steel billets at $25.50, and as the price of steel billets would go down, so would the price of ship plates. From time to time the Government will place their auditors in the steel company's plant in order to check up their costs. The total amount of plate tonnage that we contracted for was 250,000 tons. What caused the Government to give this contract was the scarcity and the impossibility of getting ship plates from our neighbours to the south in order to carry on our shipbuilding programme. No one at that time could foresee the end of the war. It might be a year or more before the conclusion of hostilities, and when a country is at war, as Canada was, it is necessary to prepare for an indefinite continuance of war conditions. The shipyards at that time were paying for plate all the way from 4 cents a pound up to 10 cents. The ruling price in the United States, outside of the plates required for the Government ships, was from 4 to 54 cents. I called into competition the great United States steel companies, besides inviting all the steel companies in Canada to tender, and the best price I could get was $4.15, the United States steel price being 4i cents per lb. Since the letting of this contract the armistice has been signed, and the price of steel plates has dropped to 2J cents in the United States and may possibly go lower. I therefore recently interviewed the officials of the steel company and pointed out to them that this was a war contract that we had entered into with them, and that in view of the price of steel plates -having declined so much in the United States, and for other reasons, I wanted to negotiate with them for a modification of the existing contract. I met the President and the Vice-president of the Dominion Steel Corporation, who could not have met me in a

more broad and patriotic spirit than they did; and while they said that they were sorry to lose such a contract if they had to, they were prepared to make any modifications that I, as a responsible minister would care to propose with the approval of the Government. These negotiations are being carried on at present, and the contract will either be modified or be entirely cancelled. The Government have not yet got the necessary information before them to decide what action they will take, but I am free to state now that we can modify the contract or, if we prefer, as they have met us in a very broad spirit, we can cancel it.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
Is there a clause to that
effect in the contract?
*

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speakerposition: Minister of Marine and Fisheries; Minister of the Naval Service
speechtext: No.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext: Did the Dominion Steel Company have all their plant erected?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
The Order in Council of 26th March 1918, clause (j) reads:
That all the machinery, plant and material of whatsoever nature or kind refined in the construction of the necessary mill, power facilities, steel making equipment, etc.to produce the steel plates covered by this proposal, shall be admitted into Canada free of all customs duties.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext: Why not assist in developing that trade by encouraging a corporation here to go into the business? Would it not be well for the Government to assist them in building ships?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext: As the Government railways are under the control of the Railway Commission as to rates, tolls and tariff agreements, is it the intention of the Government to place the ships under the same commission in regard to rates and tolls?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speakerposition: Minister of Marine and Fisheries; Minister of the Naval Service
speechtext: That would be a matter for Mr. D. B. Hanna and his board of directors- to consider more than it would be a question for the Government. It would be a very difficult problem for any Government to undertake to control rates for ocean traffic. But if it is at all feasible, the Government wmuld be willing to join in with the others.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext: My hon. friend will have an opportunity; I will be finished in a moment.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext: Did I understand the hon. member to say that the Canadian Pacific do not own or did not build tramp steamers?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speakerposition: Minister of Marine and Fisheries; Minister of the Naval Service
speechtext:
I do not wish to
curtail the discussion in any way, but the hon. member is referring to trawlers which were built for the British Government, and which have nothing to do with the subject under consideration.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
They may have
been built nominally for the British Government, but they were really built for the Canadian Government. The Canadian Government paid for them and they appear in the Canadian Government accounts which we are now examining in the Public Accounts Committee, so that I think I have a right to refer to them. I find those trawlers were sold for $270,000. They cost including repairs $839,872.73, so that they were sold at a loss to the country of $569,872.73. The extraordinary thing to me is that the minister or somebody in the Department of Marine and Fisheries did not think of utilizing those trawlers on the coast for fishing purposes. The price at which they were sold is a mere bagatelle compared with what they cost, and it would surely have been profitable for some enterprising Canadian to use them on our coasts in developing our great fishing industry. I find also that 65 per cent has .been allowed Vickersby the minister for what are called overhead charges. I am not very familiar with manufacturing, and I am not going to say that that is an extortionate rate, because I am not sure, but it looks large to me. For example, I find, for labour in connection with the construction of those trawlers in Vickers' yard in Montreal, an account dated August 29, 1917, amounting to $10,790.86. The builder is allowed to add 65 per cent to that for overhead charges, or $7,014.08, making a total of $17,804.94. Sixty-five per cent looks large to me for overhead charges, and has the appearance of profiteering. But this account is certified that the prices charged are fair and just, signed by Mr. James A. Wilson, Director of Stores. Another certificate reads:
I hereby certify that the prices are according to contract.
(Signed) L. J. Beausoleil,
Chief Accountant.
It appears, therefore, that the minister must have made a contract by which he allowed Vickers Limited to charge an overhead charge of 65 per cent in addition to the cost of labour. Take another account:
War appropriation vote-6 steel trawlers.
Labour	$5,491.23
Commission,	65 per cent	 3,569.30'
Total	  $9,060.53
I should like the minister, if he does me the honour at any time of replying, to explain to the Committee if he regards that 65 per cent overhead charge as reasonable.
Last night some very serious charges were made against the Department of Naval Affairs by the hon. member for Lunenburg (Mr. Duff). They were so serious that the leader of the Government (Sir Thomas White) decided that he would not go on any further with the estimate, but would give an opportunity 'to the Minister of Marine and Fisheries (Mr. Ballantyne) to answer the hon. member for Lunenburg.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext: No, I did not say that. I said that the Canadian Pacific were building a different line of vessels altogether that were capable of carrying their freight from their railway terminals to the markets of the world.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext: What I understood the hon. member to say was that the Canadian Pacific does not own any tramp steamer or did not build any.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext: I had no knowledge of the minister's intentions. I had supposed that in his speech he would deal with both naval and marine affairs. I was very much surprised that the minister made no reply at all to the charges of the hon. member for Lunenburg. When the minister interrupted, I was pointing out that the Lady Evelyn was in the vicinity at the time-

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
Order. The minister
has risen to a point of order.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext: I only want to correct my hon. friend in me statement that he has made. I would be very proud to have that industry in my constituency, but I must not take something that does not belong to me. It is not in my county.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext: No, not the Dominion Steel Company.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
I am sure that the Committee will agree with me unanimously when I express my own pleasure at seeing the hon. minister (Mr. Ballanlyne) back in his seat after a very serious illness.
. Some hon. MEMBERS: Hear, hear.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext: What is there old about the story of vessels going to South America as soon as the armistice was concluded? That was up to date.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
The moon is made of green cheese. That is no argument. That is only a question of the length of the ships. Other nations could have brought their ships in here. The Germans, for instance, could have done so. The canals were free to any nation in 'the world. The question of free trade versus protection was not involved, in this subject at all. My hon. friend knows very well what is the fact to-day, that all the material entering into shipbuilding can be brought into this country free of duty. There is no duty on bars, plates, or anything of that kind, that enter shipbuilding, and for that reason shipbuilding can be carried on in this country regardless of tariff and should be encouraged.
What was the reason that we wanted to get into a shipbuilding business, and why were these contracts given for ships? We all know that with the advent of the submarine the economics of war, as I might say, underwent a great change. The world found that ship after ship was being lost, that there was a great shortage of ocean shipping, and that the goods of this country might not find their way abroad. As a matter of fact at the present moment there are millions of dollars worth of goods in the warehouses of Canada awaiting shipment to China, Japan, and other foreign countries, and we cannot get the bottoms to ship them out- The absurdity of standing up and opposing a programme that will give us a few ships to carry on this foreign trade shows to my mind the ignorance of

those men who speak on topics they do not know anything about. If you go to any Canadian manufacturer to-day you will find that his warehouses are filled with goods for export to South America, China, South Africa and India, and that he cannot find any shipping for them. For New Zealand they will not take a car of stuff from any station in Ontario to-day until ships are provided, and there are no ships for the thousands of dollars worth of merchandise lying in our warehouses waiting for shipment to that country.
Hon. gentlemen who discuss questions affecting the commerce of the country should post themselves a little better in the matter. The world is moving; conditions to-day are not as they were twenty years ago. The wheat of the country should be taken out on our own ships. Every nation to-day is jealous of its shipping. At the very moment that the Government gave its first contract for the building of ships the Japanese Government established a programme, to extend over seven years, for the purpose of absorbing every pound of plate they could get in Canada or in the United States. If the Minister of Marine wants to sell his ships, he can sell them to-morrow to the Japanese Government at ten or fifteen dollars a ton more than he is paying for them. There is no lack of market for ships to-day throughout the world. The contracts were not improvident.
The hon. gentleman quoted the Financial Post as saying that plate was selling at $55 a ton. With pig iron selling at Lancaster at $50 I do not see how you can get plate at $55. The quotation given in the Post is an absurdity. Plate is really selling higher to-day in England than it is in Pittsburg; the Government absorbed the difference. If we do not have our own ships during the next five or ten years we cannot carry on business with any foreign country, because each nation has taken hold of its shipping as a national business and will not allow its ships to be used in the trade of any other nation. Great Britain has absolute control of its own shipping; a British ship cannot go to a foreign port without getting authority from the British Government to do so. During the war embargoes were placed on shipping as against foreign countries. For nearly a year foreign shipping was not allowed to go to Norway because Norway would not allow its ships to be used by the Allies, and thousands of tons of freight were lying in the harbours of New York, Boston and Montreal awaiting shipment to Norway. A short time ago the United States placed an embargo on

the products of Canada going to Norway through American ports. It will be only a matter of weeks before the United States Government places an embargo on any Canadian products going out in United States ships, because they want all that trade themselves, just as every other country wants its own trade.
As to the cotton industry and the shipping industry of Great Britain and free trade, school boys who do not know anything about history might say that free trade built up the shipping trade of England. But every one knows that the shipping trade of England originated in the navigation laws of Cromwell, which were a most effective form of protection. Great Britain put the old navigation laws into force during the war, and made them more rigid than they ever were. She would not permit any foreign neutral nation to carry trade to belligerent ports. Is that free trade? That is the condition we ourselves are up against; we want our own ships to carry our own cargoes. I will give an illustration of how Great Britain desires to curtail the trade of the world. A Canadian firm had a cargo of goods for consignment to Calcutta. The goods had been manufactured in Canada and had remained in stock a considerable time awaiting shipment. The man who manufactured the goods asked the Canadian Pacific Railway Company if they would give him a freight rate to Calcutta, and they did, quoting him a rate of something like say $70 a ton via the Pacific. The manufacturer tendered this rate to the British firm which had the goods here, and they said that the goods had to go via London, and that the freight to London was over $60 a ton and only $7 or $8 a ton from London to Calcutta. This shows what steps are taken by the British Government to control traffic to and from British ports. If you are going to build up this country; if you are going to make Canada a country which does business all over the world, you must start out in a proper way. Before the war Great Britain's most prominent competitor was Germany. How did Germany carry on her foreign trade? How was it that she went into the foreign market and took one-third of the trade away from Great Britain inside of fifteen years? The reason is simple. She bonused her ships and shipbuilding. It is absurd to say that the plates and material that entered into the manufacture of German ships were made in Great Britain and taken over to Germany and fabricated. That is not so. When the war came Germany had more plants manufacturing steel
plate than Great Britain had. Moreover, they had purchased many of the steel manufacturing industries of Great Britain and moved them over to Germany. When the waT broke out not one firm in Great Britain was manufacturing cold rolled shafting, because they had been accustomed to get it cheaper from Germany. During the great pageant at Quebec I had the pleasure of visiting one of the greatest ships of the British fleet, and when I set foot on the deck of that warship I saw that the plate on the side was stamped "Krupp steel," presumably made in Germany. That indicate what the condition of affairs was before the war; and that is the condition of affairs that an adoption of the policies advocated by free traders would bring to any country. Free traders would bring about a condition in which the nation would be only a jobbing nation, not a -manufacturing or producing nation. That might do for Great Britain, but not for Canada.
Germany built up her maritime and foreign trade by subsidized shipbuilding and encouraging shipyards. Before the war, when the shipbuilders had gone on strike in Great Britain, the emissaries of Germany were at the Clyde, at Newcastle and other places in Great Britain, offering these skilled workmen big inducements to go to work in Germany. Many of them went over, and a shipbuilding industry was established in Germany such as we are trying to establish in Canada with the same class of men. The greatest ships of the world were built in these German shipyards previous to the war. The supremacy of speed on the ocean was successfully contested by German shipbuilders as against British shipbuilders. Now, what was at the bottom of all this shipbuilding? There was a desire on the part of Germany to get the trade of the world. You cannot get the trade of the world by simply making the stuff; the secret of getting the trade of the world is to provide the necessary transportation. If we left it to the people of the United States to build up our railways in the West, how far would our West have gone? It is the old story of the lark and her young ones; if you want to do anything properly you must do it yourself and then you will know that it is done, and as you want it to be done. If you want to carry on foreign trade you must provide the transportation for it; otherwise you are at 'the mercy of all foreign nations and traders, w,ho will absorb your profits. Germany realized that. She established lines of trading ships between

German ports and all the leading ports of the world. Moreover, she provided that all inland manufacturers in Germany should have the benefit of the same rate to any of the ports of the world as that paid by the manufacturers on the seaeoast. In other words, a manufacturer in Leipsie could get the same rate from Leipsie to Smyrna as a manufacturer in Hamburg could get. All manufacturers were on the same footing in that respect. The same policy should be adopted by our National Steamship Company so that manufacturers in all parts of Canada will have the same freight rate to all parts of the world. The Germans established a freight rate from Germany to other countries which (was fully one-third less than the freight rate from Great Britain to other countries; and they made a profit on the return trade. For instance, the freight rate to-day from New York city to Calcutta, as established by the United States Government, is $20 a ton. The United States control their shipping, and a United States ship may not carry a cargo to a foreign port without a license or charge more than this rate. That is what we are going to be up against, and if we have no ships of our own -we shall not be able ito get a pound of any commodity out of this country unless we pay exorbitant freight rates. If this country could give a freight rate of $18 per ton to Calcutta, we could secure the business, so closely is international business mixed up. With ocean rates the freight rate is the controlling element. That is the whole question in a nutshell, and if I had my way *-I do not know whether my voice will be heard in the councils here any more than that of the hon. member for Red Deer (Mr. Michael Clark) -I would suggest this. We as a young country must make up our mind that we have to take up our task as Empire builders. We have all the raw material for Empire building; we have the farms, the fields; we have the power; we have the workmen; we have the finest men in the world to undertake the task, men who have gone through the war and acquired discipline and training. If we are to be, a great country, we must put our shoulder to the wheel and make up our minds that we are to be Empire builders. Germany was a protectionist nation, and was the one nation in the world that successfully contested the supremacy of England in matters of foreign trade, and we can remain a protectionist nation and we can follow out a similar policy. We must establish a number of 
steamship lines. We must establish a steamship line from here to the East Indies, where there is a very profitable trade, where we can send manufactured goods of our own and bring back in return tea, jute and other articles that are brought in to this country now in foreign ships, and that might very well be brought back as a return cargo in our own ships. Before the war this enormous trade with India went to Germany. Besides we are going to get an Imperial preference. We must not, because the war is over, lie down and go back to our little five acre lot and say: Oh, well, we are done with the war, we want to revert into our shell again. We have taken a place in the sun and we must now stay in the sun. We should have a line of steamers to Australia and New Zealand. At the present time the New York manufacturers and traders are lying awake in bed at nights wondering what preference we shall have with Australia and New Zealand. They are all wanting to open branch offices in the cities here in order to see if they cannot get a share of that trade. There are many things we could bring back from New Zealand. We could bring back a return cargo of hides and wool to Great Britain, and then we could bring back from Great Britain a cargo of other things which we need. The hon. member for Red Deer may wonder what we require from Great Britain, but there are many things which we need which Great Britain could supply just now, but she cannot furnish ships to send them here. There is no lack of demand in this country for British goods; 'the only thing we really lack is shipping.
In South America there is a market for all the goods we manufacture, such as hardware, furniture, clothing of various kinds, cottons, goods of all descriptions, and we could bring back coffee and hides. " Oh," but the hon. member for Red Deer says, " That is a contradiction to your policy of being a protectionist. Why should you bring back hides? Your policy is to produce hides here." That's true, but we can get only hides for fully fifty per cent of the leather we turn ou't in this country. We are large manufacturers and exporters of finished leather, and if we endeavour to get hides from South America via the port of New York, as we do now, we are liable to be tied up by the United States Government. They will say: We will allow you only so many hides, as if we were an " adjunct." Therefore, if we had our own ships, we would not be under the necessity of looking to them for favours. We could bring

the hides hack here in our own ships, so that the New York merchants would have no control over our trade and would not be able to milk the profit out of it as against the Canadian manufacturer.
In these countries we have traded with during the war and established a market for our goods, and we did not have to furnish a national credit. They have plenty of gold. Unless steps are taken to establish lines of shipping from Canada to these various countries we shall have lost all the advantage of trade during the war, and Great Britain, France and the United States will have gone into these countries and secured the business which we had.
The hon. member for Red Deer spoke the truth when he said that the ink was not dry on the armistice when English ships were going out laden with goods to capture the trade of the world. Before the ink on the armistice was dry Canada should have been ready, too. In fact, we were doing a large amount of that trade which Great Britain could not do before the war. But, knowing a certain phase of trade from the ground up as I do know it, I would say to the minister that the worst thing '.that this country ever did in the matter of shipbuilding was when it lent money to Great Britain to build ships for the so-called Imperial Munitions Board, in order that those ships might go into competition with the ships we own ourselves. There was no necessity for that, and all those ships should have been held by us, so that we could control our own shipping and trade, and do something to adjust matters that the freight rates on our Western wheat would not be so great and would not bear so unequally on the man who lives in the shadow of the Rockies, so that he would have an equal chance in the markets abroad. These ships were built for the Imperial Munitions Board; Canada lent the money to Great Britain for them, and no sooner were they launched into the waves and sailing out on the sea than the fleet was turned over to the Cunard and other lines that have been milking this country for many years on the Atlantic. If we had those ships, they would have assisted us in carrying on our foreign trade, and I make this prediction that before four years aTe over this country will realize it has not enough ships to carry on its business.
Let me say a word in reference to the price of steel plate- Everybody knows the price of plate and other steel commodities was very high, and when the minister made the contract for the steel plate for ships
it was almost impossible to get plate for any work whatsoever. Shipping was all under control and the whole world was tied uip, and I think the contract that the minister made was a very easy contract at that time, because, comparatively speaking, the price was low, and it would have been a good thing for this country if, during the war, we had had two or three firms making plates, as there was a great shortage of plates in the world. But the economic war is not over yet and I am going to make another prediction, namely, that before many years are over the minister will find that he has not made a bad bargain in the matter of plate mill. The shelves of the world are empty so far as iron is coneferned, and while at present there is a halt in the purchase of such goods, the fact will very soon be realized that there is not sufficient of these goods available and prices will rise accordingly.
The Saar valley, which was a great mining field where the Germans got their iron ore and which furnished forty per cent of the steel materials that went into the foreign trade of their country, has been put under international control. Germany has lost the Saar _valley where all her great iron mines were. Her furnaces and steel mills are in Westphalia where her coal mines are, but where there is very little iron, and it looks as if the products of those mines are going to be out of the market for the next three or four years until France can build blast furnaces that will take that iron and smelt it and roll it. The result is that there will be a shortage of steel, while the trade of the world which has languished during the war will, within a few months after the Peace Treaty is signed, increase by leaps and bounds and be far greater than it ever was before, because people are trading and doing business abroad who never did any trade of any description before-
As to the influence on shipbuilding of free trade or protection, I trust that the minister and the Government will realize that there is nothing in that story; it does not affect shipbuilding to the extent of a five-cent piece. Every hon. gentleman knows that the materials that enter into the building of a ship come into this country free of duty; at all events, the duty is rebated. We could not build ships unless that was the case, as the British ships would simply be brought in here. I think that when war broke out there were on the Great Lakes ninety large cargo carriers which had been brought here from Great Britain. All of them went to sea when

war broke out, and possibly sixty or seventy per cent of them were destroyed by submarines, and many of the crews gave up their lives in the service of the Empire. The officers and men of the merchant marine of Canada have no need to be ashamed of their record during the war. I trust that the people of this country will support those who are endeavouring to keep alive the maritime traditions of our race. I can assure the minister that the manufacturers of this country and the farmers who need the ships to carry their products abroad will support him in any measures that he may take for seeing that this country is not divorced from shipping as it likely will be within six months or a year if we do not have shipping of our own. Trade will expand Iso rapidly and the scarcity of shipping will become so acute that foreign countries will control their ships just as the United States and Great Britain are doing now. The United States has fixed the freight rates between New York and every foreign port. Great Britain is controlling her ships in the same way, and Canada's voice is very small in the counsels of these nations when our trade comes into competition with theirs. If we are to compete in foreign markets we must have ships of our own, and we would not be progressive if we did not adopt this policy of establishing a merchant marine.
Progress reported.
At six o'clock the House took recess.
After Recess.
The House resumed at eight o'clock.
LT.-COLOtNE'L GEORGE HAROLD BAKER, M.P.-PROPOSED MEMORIAL.

speakerposition: Minister of Finance and Receiver General
speechtext: Yes, $350,000,000, and to any amount for which we have not borrowing power, but which we have borrowed.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speakerposition: Minister of Finance and Receiver General
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, with reference to the message that has just been read from the hon. the Senate, I beg to move, seconded by Mr. Reid-the consent of the House being necessary-[DOT]
That Sir Sam Hughes, Sir Herbert Ames, Messrs. Boivin and Kay, he appointed a Special Committtee on behalf of the House of Commons, to confer and act with the Committee of the Senate and House of Commons, who have in charge the building and arrangement of the new Parliament Building, in order thait there may foe erected therein a suitable memorial of the late Lt.-Colonel George Harold Baker, M.P., for Brome, he being the only member of Parliament who lost his life on the field of battle ; and that a message foe sent to the Senate to acquaint their Honours (therewith.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
I wish to bring to the notice of the Acting Prime Minister a communication which I have received from Halifax concerning the men engaged in the naval service during and since the war. The largest number of men engaged there did not much exceed 3,000, and there are still, I understand, 900 men on the pay roll, about 2,000 having been demobilized. The cry among those who are still on is that demobilization is proceeding too slowly and that there is no occasion for keeping them there. They are doing nothing, and in letters I have received they assert that they are simply kept there by the officers as an excuse for the latter to retain themselves in office. The statement is broadly made both in the newspapers in Halifax and in the communications that were sent to me, that all the officers on the Nio:be, in the higher ranks at all events, are English naval officers who were loaned 'to the Canadian Government for this service, and that when they came to this country they were promoted in rank from what might be regarded as petty officers to a higher grade, with a consequent increase in wages, and, as it is remarked in these letters, promotion in social standing, and so on. It is asserted that they are having an excellent time and good pay and are just keeping it going in order that their salaries may be continued. The men appear to be highly dissatisfied and write me that they believe their time will be up on the 11th of this month, that

is, six months after the termination of hostilities, when tney are entitled to leave. I was anxious to bring this matter to the notice of the authorities to-day so that we would avoid if possible the disagreeableness and, to some extent, the disgrace of having any trouble among our men, and in order that the most effective and speedy action should be taken by the Government to meet any brewing difficulties among them. They have sent me a copy of a general order issued by W. Oswald Story, Admiral Superintendent of that service at Halifax. It reads:-
In view of the misunderstanding which appears to exist, with regard to demobilization, attention is called to the fact that ail officers and men are liable to serve for a period of six months after cessation of hostilities. As some officers and men will be required volunteers were called for, in order that, so far as1 possible, those retained might he volunteers, but it must be understood that others will also he required, if insufficient volunteer, and will be retained as necessary.
Those who do not volunteer to continue to serve will be demobilized after cessation of hostilities as thpir services can be spared.
W. Oswald Story, Admiral Superintendent.
November 23, 191>8.
The men in the service interpret this Order to mean that hostilities ceased on the 11th day of November. They had a contract to stay in the service until the cessation of hostilities and for six months thereafter. When the armistice was signed on the 11th of November, these men, it appears from the tenor of this Order, wanted to get away at once, and this Order was made then to make their position clear. They understood by it that those who volunteered were bound to remain for six months after the cessation of hostilities, or up to the 11th of this month, and they want to get away at that date. I have here copies of newspapers that are friendly to the Government-the Halifax Herald and the Halifax Evening Mail, both of them strong supporters of the Government, speaking editorially-I shall not take up the time of the Committee reading it-they sustain exactly what I have said. They put forth the same theory, that these officers are unnecessarily prolonging the time of demobilization. The Mail is jusit an evening edition of the Herald, both being owned by the same people, and both issues set forth, as an argument to show the unreasonableness of the time that is taken in dealing with these men, that 150,000 men have been brought home from England and disbanded and dealt with by the authorities in the military service.
While this has been done there are only 2,000 demobilized altogether and about 1,000 on the hands of the officers doing nothing, according to the report that comes to me.
I think it is quite proper for me to read a letter I received to-day:
Halifax, N.S., May 4, 1919.
Dear Sir:-I have been delegated on behalf of the Boys from the Lower Deck to direct a letter to you, asking you, if you would take up our case which is stated below, in the House of Commons.
We men have resolved, on or about the' 11th of May to discontinue our services in the " Canadian Navy " and demand that we be demobilized forthwith, on the grounds, that our contract as far as the Canadian Navy and Government is concerned, is completed, observing, that we have carried out our duties 6 months after the cessation of hostilities. We further base our claim on the General Order, which I enclose, dated November 23, 1918, ....
That is the general order that I read-

and signed by Admiral Storey. Will you, on our behalf ask in the House of Commons the following question: "What date, after November 11, 1918, do the contracts, signed by the Canadian Naval Ratings become void? In the event of the men refusing duty after the 11th of May, what stand will he taken by the Government?"
The letters which I enclose, published by the Halifax Herald express the feeling of every Canadian sailor in the service. We have stood everything during the war, and when war ended, to our great surprise the Government had no policy formed, as to dealing with our demobilization. We have waited our six months, and even to-day they have not declared themselves in regard to the ultimate date of our demobilization. We are all anxious to get back into civilian life as soon as possible, in order to get re-established in our civilian occupations.
That is the substance of the complaint made by these men, together with what I have already stated. I think that it is not necessary to keep them there, and that the officers are simply making jobs for themselves. That is not my language; it is what is communicated to me by these men, and I think it is my duty to represent the matter to the Government so that such action may be taken as will prevent any difficulty between these men and their officers.
I trust that immediate action will be taken upon these facts, as I believe them to be facts. I would have some hesitation perhaps if I did not have exactly the same story in the form of an editorial signed by the editor of the Evening Mail. He puts his own name to the statements which appear in his paper, and I feel confident that a paper of the standing of the Evening Mail would not give its countenance to these , statements by publishing them if the editor did not believe they were true.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext:
The minister no doubt desires to give correct information, but when he tells me that it was necessary to keep these men at St. John doing garrison duty I doubt it. I do not profess to be a military expert, but I visited the camp, or drill hall, or armoury, or whatever it may be called on several occasions; I inquired of military men and I have-never yet found a military genius, so far as wc have them in the province of New Brunswick, who could give me the slightest reason or excuse for keeping the men in the city of St. John for any length of time they have been kept. The minister says the garrison will be demobilized in the next few weeks-
MajorJGeneral MEWBURN:	Possibly
sooner.

I am not opposing it, because it has been in previous Acts and no harm has come of it; but it strikes me that that is a very broad power indeed, and I cannot imagine anything done by the Governor in Council under it that would not be deemed legal-

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speechtext: I cordially agree with the hon. gentleman that the War Measures Act was a necessary and proper Act. During the war, owing to the patriotic feeling of the country, people were not critical; you -could get pretty nearly anything that was asked for in 'the name of the war or for the purposes of the war. But the time has arrived when the people will be more critical, and if we continue war measures at a .time when there is no longer any war, there will be keener inquiry and more criticism. I do not object to the passing of the Act, but I think it is just as well that we should begin to adapt ourselves to the condition of peace which is happily upon us.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speakerposition: Minister of Finance and Receiver General
speechtext: I entirely agree with my hon. friend.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speakerposition: Minister of Finance and Receiver General
speechtext:
The question as to the value of the rails which were removed from the tracks of the Grand Trunk Pacific, and, I think partly from the National Transcontinental and some other lines, is under adjustment at present between the Dominion Government and the Imperial Government. My hon. friend will understand that after a war of such long duration there must necessarily be a number of items subject to adjustment, and it will take considerable time before the transactions can be closed up. I said last night that 1 would make as comprehensive a statement as possible upon the occasion of the Budget speech with reference to the national debt of Canada, especially its increase during the war, and our estimated expenditures for the coming year, our borrowings of last year, and our proposed borrowings for the present year, and would aim generally to lay as fully before Parliament as I could the facts relating to our financial position, in which, I know, all members of the House and citizens of the country are specially interested at this time.
My hon. friend has referred to the state of exchange between Canada and the United States. It is quite unfavourable to Canada, almost to the extent of 3 per cent. The hon. gentleman is a business man and will not have failed to observe that exchange between Great Britain and the United States is still more unfavourable to Great Britain, approximating 5 per cent. It is not correct that we have an adverse balance of trade to-day, as stated by the hon. member. Our balance of trade is favourable and has been exceedingly so during the last two or three years of the war. All the products .that Canada is selling to-day outside of our own borders are being paid for by outside money, that is to say, by what we call technically, exchange. To ascertain a country's real exchange position the whole world position must be taken into account.
I stated last night that one reason why exchange was unfavourable was that by having to provide so much money here in Canada to pay for our products which, in normal times, would find outside money and thus redress our exchange, we neutralized for exchange purposes that amount of our exports. If Great Britain was able to find exchange outside of Canada, that is to

say credits in New York, or if she could buy in London exchange for our wheat, flour and other products which she purchased, our Neiw York exchange would speedily rectify itself.
My hon. friend referred to a matter that I do not desire to enter upon at any length to-night, but which has been discussed on more than one occasion in this House, and that is the action taken by the Dominion Government in regard to newsprint. He drew the inference that on account of that action our exchange was not as favourable as it might otherwise have been in the United States. My hon. friend is no doubt aware that the amount of newsprint consumed in Canada by Canadian publishers is only about eleven per cent of our entire output, and therefore, I submit that the regulation of the price in Canada with respect to that eleven per cent has not any vital hearing upon the question of exchange between Canada and the United States.
The action of the Government was taken, as my hon. friend knows, for the purpose of providing, in a very critical time, newsprint at reasonable rates to the Canadian publishers who were very hard hit by the war, especially during the first three years. I am quite satisfied that when the matter comes up for more extended discussion, as my hon. friend indicates that it may, I shall be able to carry the judgment of the House and the country in favour of the proposition that the action of the Government was well advised and in the national interest at the time it was taken. The control of newsprint has continued down to the present time; it will continue until the end of the war, and until, I think also, the Paper Tribunal, which has been created by the Government for the purpose of hearing an appeal from the Newsprint Commissioner, renders its decision. There was submitted to it the question of the price of newsprint for the period since-I am speaking from recollection-July 1 of last year. No Government likes to take, even in war time, any action by way of restriction. It is a very unpleasant thing to do. It is done only from considerations of national duty and the national interest, and these were the motives inducing the Government, in connection with newsprint, to put into effect the Orders in Council and regulations referred to by my hon. friend.
The action of the Government is not singular in that regard. I believe that in Norway, which was a neutral country, such action was taken quite early in the war.
	'
In the United States, which takes the largest portion of our newsprint production, there was regulation, as my hon. friend knows, of the price of newsprint. There is regulation in that country to-day. I think my hon. friend is scarcely fair in his criticism of the Government for taking that, what we regard, very necessary action. My hon. friend also referred *0 the regulations which were in effect some little time ago prohibiting the export of butter.
Mr. ROiBB : The embargo.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_08.csv
speakerposition: Minister of Finance and Receiver General
speechtext:
I am inclined to think my hon. friend is right. I would point out to him that, in 1914, when the war commenced, Parliament passed the War Measures Act, which practically devolved upon the Government the legislative powers of Parliament. It was an extraordinary power, implying great confidence, and I have always felt that the Government should exercise that power keeping that fact in mind. Speaking generally with regard to the War Measures Act, I believe that almost more than any other single thing except the patriotism and courage of our soldiers, that Act enabled Canada to achieve the degree of success in the war which she did achieve. I have heard men in the United States-where the system was not nearly so flexible until they had been in the war for some time, when the entire executive and, I think, legislative power was vested in the President-refer to this War Measures Act and the extraordinary power that it gave to the Government to deal quickly with questions as they arose. It would be quite impossible to provide in Estimates, or by legislation in advance, for all the multitudinous cases arising during

the war; and this War Measures Act, while it did give the Government extraordinary power and was concurred in by the Opposition, and, as I say, implied the reposing of great confidence in the Government- which for my part I have always recognized and gladly acknowledged-enabled this country to do what it could by no means otherwise have -attempted to do in the carrying on of the war. I wish to say that, and I would like to draw my hon. friend's attention to the powers devolved upon the Government by that Act-powers which would never have been given, and never should have been given, except in war time.
The War Appropriation Acts of the past two years and this War Demobilization Act are intended to give the Government power to deal, as to expenditure, with all matters arising out of the w-ar. It is very wide, I admit. I am a strong believer in the Government bringing down estimates in detail rather than in blanket votes, -showing as far as possible the purpose for which the expenditure is to be made. That is a sound principle, in ordinary times -at least. This year I took up in my office the question of what amount we should provide in this Demobilization Bill. The instructions I gave were that the estimates of my own department and of all other departments to which the request was transmitted should contain . practically all the items we could specify, and that the Demobilization Bill should cover only the war gratuity, demobilization expenditure, and other items that could not be specified with accuracy in an estimate. I do not know how far we have succeeded in doing that, but we appreciate the confidence expressed in the vote and will endeavour to administer it as trustees should.

On section 14-appointment of trustees:
(Mr. GUTHRIE:	I moVe that the words
" and he may in his discretion revoke any such appointment made " at the end of subsection (1) be struck out. Section 31-K of the Interpretation Act gives power to remove, pertaining to all appointments.

On section 20-powers exercisable by trustee with permission of inspectors:
iMr. GUTHRIE: It has been pointed out since this section was adopted that there is no provision in it with regard to what estate a trustee can convey. Of course, it is assumed that he can convey all the estate of the debtor. It has been suggested that a declaration to that effect be incorporated in the Bill. It has also been drawn to my attention that there is a difficulty in the province of Quebec in regard to trustees' deeds; they do not operate in that province quite in the same way as they do in other provinces. It
4 p.m. seems that liens, mortgages, hypothecs and the like are not removed by trustee's deed and a clear title cannot be conveyed. Several prominent members of the Bar of the province of Quebec have directed my attention to this fact and have suggested an amendment so that we might give to a trustee's deed in that province the same effect as is now given to a sheriff's deed. Personally I see no objection to inserting a clause to that effect, if it is the desire of the Committee. I move that the following be added as subsection (3):
All sales of real estate made by the trustee shall vest in the purchaser all the legal and equitable estate of the debtor therein.
That will be the general clause. Then I move that the following be added as subclause (a) of subsection (2):
(a) In the province of Quebec a sale of real estate made by the trustee shall have the same effect as to mortgages, hypothecs or privileges then existing thereon as if the same had been made by a sheriff in the said province under a writ of execution issued in the ordinary course, and the title conveyed by such sale in the said province shall have equal validity with a title created by sheriff's sale and the conveyance of the trustee shall have the same effect as a sheriff's deed in the said province.
Mr. JACOB'S:	The section is much improved by the amendment suggested by the Solicitor General.

It is not $8, $16, or $24 per ton. The manufacturer may sell 100,000 tons of a certain brand but he will only be charged $24. It will not afford any substantial proportion of the. cost to the department of the administration of the Act. I do not think it is a burdensome tax or that it will meet with any opposition from the consumer.
Mr. MeCOIG: This seems to be a very simple matter to take up the time of the House with. As other matters come before the House, as commissions and officers are appointed, the department itself provides for defraying the expense, but when, it comes to such an important question as fertilizer is to the producers of this country and also to the consumers, it does seem ridiculous that a little cent or two cent tax has to be collected to defray the expenses of the officer who administers the Act. I do not see why the department does not assume the responsibility itself and pay the expenses of the administration of the Act instead of having some officer pulling a cent or two cent tax or a hundred pounds out of the purchaser, of the fertilizer and administering the Act at his expense. In the department there are men who are being paid by the Government to look after matters of this kind without penalizing the consumer by collecting a cent on every hundred pounds or twenty cents on every ton. They will have to keep a lot of bookkeepers to keep track of the administration of this Act and the distribution of the stamps. It is going to involve a lot of unnecessary expense.

speechtext:
I would ask the Committee to refer to clause 55. I have given a good deal of thought to it, having regard to the discussion which took place on the question of absconding debtors. It will be remembered that at the last meeting of the Committee considerable discussion took place as to what provision we should insert. I_find that the dictionary meaning of the term " abscond " is:
To remove one's self from the jurisdiction of the court; to place one's self in hiding.
In my judgment, and it has been confirmed by the conferences I have had with some very prominent lawyers both from

Ontario and Quebec, I think the section would be improved if we inserted the words " from Canada " after the word " abscond ". The section would then read: " Abscond from Canada." It must be remembered that the Act has Dominion wide application. The mere fact that a debtor goes from one province to another would hardly in my judgment constitute absconding; he is still within the jurisdiction of the bankruptcy court, and he is not in hiding.
Therefore I move:
To amend! section 55 by adding the words "from Canada" after the word "abscond" in the twelfth line of the said section at p. 44 of the Bill.
It will then read:
If, after the presentation of a bankruptcy petition against him, it appears to the court that there is probable reason for believing that he has absconded, or Us about to abscond from Canada, with a view of avoiding payment of the debt in respect of which the bankruptcy petition was filed, or of avoiding appearance to any such petition or of avoiding examination in respect of his affairs or of otherwise avoiding, delaying or embarrassing proceedings in bankruptcy against him.

A housewife living on one side of the street may be able to get along with half as much electric power as that used by a housewife on the other side of the street; yet it would be hard to convince the second housewife that she could substantially reduce her electric light bills. It is just so with public officials.

speechtext:
Yes, Mr. Chairman, this is a restriction. We have not at the present time a uniform law in all the provinces in regard to this matter. In the province of Ontario in case of assignment we allow the landlord one year of past due rent as a preference, and also three months future rent. I understand that in the province of Quebec the landlord can legally claim one year's future rent, and I think varying sums are permitted in the other provinces. The Committee which had this Bill in charge last year paid a great deal of attention to this section. It was urged that if we interfered with landlords' rights landlords would insist on stiffer terms when leases were negotiated, and that the rent probably would become payable in advance. However, a body representing almost thirty thousand retail merchants of this country, who ara the great tenant class among the merchants, appeared before the Committee and specifically approved the enactment. So far as they are concerned they are not afraid of the terms which may be imposed upon them by landlords in the future. This section provides that when bankruptcy proceedings take place the landlord's right

to a preference over other creditors shall be for rent for the last three months of the term, and it will be a first charge upon the estate. A landlord can always protect himself; he does not need to let his rent get three months in arrear. He has special privileges which other creditors do not possess; he can distrain the goods of his tenant and can realize at almost any moment. He is negligent if he allows his rent to become more than three months in arrear; and for the protection of the general creditors the Committee thought that three months was a fair and reasonable amount of rent to allow as a preference over the claims of other creditors. It was with that view that this section was drawn as it now appears. Of course, he is not deprived from claiming for all the rent due, but for anything beyond the three months he can only claim as an ordinary creditor. The Committee thought that was pretty fair treatment for the landlord, and it would be a good thing to make it uniform throughout Canada.
We must bear in mind that landlords have always been creatures whom our legislation and British legislation have favoured from time immemorial. Our present law of landlord and tenant is a relic of the feudal system and was made when landlords sat in Parliament, but tenants did not. Up to fifty or sixty years ago the law was so onesided in favour of the landlord that it was practically a disgrace. Gradually the hardships have been ameliorated by legislation; but to-day in Ontario a landlord is permitted too large a claim, in my humble judgment, when he is allowed one year of arrears and three months advance rent in the case'of assignment. I do not know what view the Committee will take of the clause, but in my judgment it is a very fair one.

That clause is an innovation and goes farther than any legislation I am aware of up to the present time. It is open to the same objection as was section 31 subsection 3. After considering the matter and having the benefit of the best legal ability I have concluded that the clause should be struck out and a new clause substituted therefor almost identical with the clause that now appears in the Ontario Assignments and Preferences Act. The clause which I beg to move to take the place of clause 32 is as follows:
Nothing in the next preceding section of this Act shall apply to any bona fide sale or payment made in the ordinary course of trade or calling to an innocent purchaser or person ; nor to any payment of money to a creditor, nor to any bona fide conveyance, assignment, transfer or delivery over of any goods or property of any kind which is made in consideration of a present actual bona fide payment in money, or by way of security for a present actual bona fide advance of money, or which is made in consideration of a present actual bona fide sale or delivery of goods or other property where the money paid, or the goods or other property sold or delivered bear a fair
and reasonable relative value to the consideration thereof.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_15 (1).csv
speechtext:
In reading over this
clause it seems to me to impose a hardship on a married woman whose husband has been adjudged 'bankrupt and who has obtained a loan of money from her. If she has an estate separate from it-hat of her husband why should she not receive the same consideration as lin the case of any other separate estate? For instance take the case of a married woman who has inherited property from her parents, which is entirely separate from the estate of her husband, and has advanced money to him to carry on his business.
I fail to see the wisdom or the fairness of the change. I think the wife is just as legally entitled as any outsider to rank as a creditor of that estate. Her money and her property are her own in that case, and she makes the loan as a purely business transaction so far as she and her husband are concerned. It seems to me, not looking at it from the legal aspect, but from the ordinary business aspect, that the woman should have the protection of the court for her estate as against her husband, and that he on his side should have similar protection against his wife.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_15 (1).csv
speechtext:
It is the experience of all lawyers in the courts of this country that there is no door quite so open to all

kinds of manipulation and of wrong-doing in regard to financial matters, and particularly as they pertain to creditors, than the relationship that exists between husband and wife. I call my hon. friend's attention in the first place to the fact that this section applies only to the future. So that husbands and wives will know after this Bill becomes law that if they loan money one to the other for business or other purposes they are taking chances under this section, and their claims may be postponed to those of otljier creditors. The reason for the section is that in the majority of cases of assignment a husband or a wife prefers a large claim against the estate. It may be that the claim is perfectly valid in most cases, but there are many cases in which the claim: is decidedly invalid and should not be allowed to prevail as against the creditors. Such fictitious claims are so easily made and so hard to defeat that you must in some way protect ordinary creditors against them. To do so we must enact something such as we have attempted by section 48. That section has been largely used in England, and it will be used in this country, too, in future, I am sure. Case after case comes up when not only does the husband or the wife prefer a claim as a creditor for money loaned, but in addition a claim for wages. Those claims may be proper enough, but in future, if this Bill becomes law husbands and wives must take notice that such claims will only be paid after the claims of other creditors. If with that notice staring them in the face they allow their claims for wages to accumulate they will have to take the consequences. It is in order to defeat the large number of fictitious claims which are presented in cases of bankruptcy, that it has been found necessary, I think, in every civilized country which has a bankruptcy law to include a clause of this kind. If it had a retroactive effect I would not support it as I do; but it only applies to the future.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_15 (1).csv
speechtext: We had quite a discussion on this matter in Committee and since then I have not heard of it. In Ontario, we have a law regarding limited partnerships, but in my experience I have never come across any. The clause will have a very limited application and is inserted in case anything in the way of limited partnerships should arise.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_15 (1).csv
speechtext: In Quebec, limited partnerships are quite common. A man may want to invest, say $10,000 in a business. Under a limited partnership, he may invest that money, but he must not have any dealings with the affairs of the business; his name must not appear in the firm, and he must not be engaged in any way in the business. He simply puts up his money as if he were investing it in a joint stock company. If anything goes wrong with that company, the individual, who has lent his money in the way indicated, should not be subject to the provisions of this legislation.

He is dealt with just
as he would be in England. We have copied this section precisely from the words of the English Act. He is protected from everything the English statute would protect him from.

On section^-application of part 1.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_15 (1).csv
speechtext:
I desire to move .an amendment to this clause. I object to the application of Part I of the Bill to non-traders. This is the first time that there has been brought into the House of Commons of Canada a Bankruptcy Act which includes non-traders in its application. The Bankruptcy Act of 1875, which was repealed in 1879, and the Bill introduced in 1897 by Mr. Fortin, who is now judge of the Superior Court, did not apply to non-traders. I have gone carefully over legislation on bankruptcy of different countries, and I believe the only countries in which Bankruptcy Acts apply to nontraders are Great Britain and the United States. In Prance, Belgium and other countries, the Acts do not apply to nontraders. My principal objection to the extension of the law to non-traders is this: The enforcement of a bankruptcy law is a serious matter; it means a searching investigation into the affairs of a man by his creditors. It is encroaching on private rights. It allows the creditors to find out private secrets of all kinds and, in fact, it is a grave violation of property rights. The debtor ceases to have charge of his business and his creditors take his place and as Thallier says in his study on bankruptcy, only the most important reasons can justify such an action. The necessi-
[Mr. Jacobs.)
ties of trade afford Parliament an opportunity of adopting such measures, although this is clearly odious to private rights. Credit requires such legislation, such violation of the liberty of the proprietor, and business cannot dispense with it. In what position would a trader be if he could not obtain credit from his banker or other creditors? That is the reason for a bankruptcy law. The law should give the banker or other creditors the assurance that if the debtor should fail, a trustee will be named who will take charge of his assets for the benefit of all creditors, present or absent. Otherwise, without this law there would be no protection for the creditors in contingencies against which no one can be safeguarded. In business relations many creditors now reside far away from their debtors, while other debtors are more easily accessible. If the insolvency law were abolished, creditors living near the debtor and being consequently more in touch with him than those who are distant, would seize his assets first, to the prejudice of those living far away; and without insolvency legislation there would be this further effect, that only cash sales would be made. There would be no more credit, and in consequence practically no trade. This consideration, however, does not, I submit,
. apply to non-traders. The judge, the doctor, the lawyer, or the professional man lives on his income or his salary, and has no justification in living beyond his means. His profession should preclude the necessity of speculations inherent to trade, and if he obtains credit it is not on the guarantee of any assets but merely on his personal promise to pay, and his creditors will wait until he receives his income. Unlike the case of the trader, to whom credit is a business necessity, society is not interested whether the man who receives a salary gets credit or not. Admitting that the non-trader contracts debts, it is highly improbable that his creditors will either be so numerous or most of them so far distant that some living in proximity to the debtor will reap all the benefits to the prejudice of the others. Besides that, there is a constitutional viewpoint to consider. I will grant for a moment that the law of bankruptcy in regard to the trader, even if it touches civil rights and property, as it necessarily does, is within the province of the federal power. But I contend that subsection 21 of section 91 of The British North America Act evidently conferred such power, because it pertained to the trade and commerce legislation, which is exclusively within the purview of the Federal

Government. I am sure, however, that the intention of the legislators in reference to subsection 13 of section 92 of the British North America Act, which gives the province control of legislation in regard to property and civil rights, was not to extend the bankruptcy legislation to anything outside trade and commerce, and it would undoubtedly go beyond their intention if this law -were made applicable to nontraders. I therefore move, seconded by Mr. Jacobs:
That subsection 1 of clause 8 be amended by striking out all the words after the first line of said section, beiing line 21 of nage 8, and substituting the following words: " non traders."

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_15 (1).csv
speechtext:
The motion raises a
point upon which there might be considerable argument. There is no doubt that in the Insolvency Bill of 1375 an attempt was made to confine the operation of that Act to traders, and one of the objections to the Act always was that it was so confined. It is contended that there is a large class of non-traders who are 'debtors and should be treated as ordinary citizens of the country, amenable to the ordinary laws, whether of bankruptcy or otherwise. Another difficulty is to give anything like an adequate definition of the word "trader." The definition in the Act of 1875 was certainly defective, but it covers almost two pages of typewritten matter, defining almost all classes of business enterprise we know in Canada. But still it would not suffice for a definition at the present time, because we have a great many avenues of trade and commerce today that were not in existence then. So that it would be extremely difficult to define just who were and who were not traders. In England the experience has been that the Act should apply generally to all classes. I think that about fifty years ago, in the sixties, the Act was limited to traders, but after an experience of some years, that Act was extended, and the British and the United States Acts to-day both apply to all classes of the people in regard not only to obligations created by the Act, but to the benefits which are conferred upon the honest debtor in the way of obtaining his discharge. I know, however, that in France, Belgium, and one or two other continental countries the bankruptcy Acts are still confined to traders. Having heard from as many public commercial bodies as I could upon the subject, and having heard a long discussion in the Special Committee by a great many interested classes, I concluded, and the Committee concluded, that this Bill, in order to have a fair chance of
operation, should be made general in its application. For instance, it was urged by the very large association of retail merchants which has a membership in Canada of some 30,000, that it was unfair to them to put all the imposition on their shoulders and allow them none of the benefits. As it was pointed out that one of the great debtor classes was professional people, the question was asked, why should they not be included? and the Committee took that view. My o-wn view is that if you are to give the Act a fair chance of success you must extend it beyond the trading classes. If it should prove to be burdensome or to be an undue imposition upon the people, within a year of its operation there would be a demand for its repeal. But I do not think it will be burdensome. On the contrary, I think it will be a great benefit to both the debtor and the creditor classes, and I certainly support the present generality of its terms.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_15 (1).csv
speechtext: Why not include the farming classes?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_15 (1).csv
speechtext: A special case was made out on behalf of the farming classes. It is said that the farmer is very much more subject to unforeseen accidents than any other class of people in the community. He may be solvent to-day, with bright prospects for the coming year, and when everything looks promising he may experience a disastrous accident. He could be put into bankruptcy by reason of his inability during a season to meet maturing liabilities, and he might be sold out and his farm taken from him. But in the ordinary course, if he were given another year or two, he would have big crops and be on his feet again and be re-established. He might be the victim of natural causes beyond his control, and for that reason the Act was not made to apply either to the farmer or to the small wage-earner.

Later in the Bill it is proposed to establish, an Advisory Council Section 7 A (2) will provide:
The advisory hoard shall have power to prescribe what shall be deemed a sufficient medication of medicines containing alcohol in excess of two and a half per cent to make them unfit for use as beverages.
There is a considerable agitation in all the provinces in connection with the sale of patent medicines and the fact that they are too high in alcoholic content. Any patent medicines containing over two and one half per cent of alcohol must be approved by the Advisory Council before they can be sold. I wish to amend this section by inserting after the word "registration" on the second line the following:
Or any medicine containing more than two and a half per cent of alcohol or containing any of the drugs mentioned in or added to the schedule of the Act.
We are not amending the schedule, which contains a list of dangerous drugs which can be used only with the consent or permission of the Advisory Council. Two and a half per cent is fixed by reason of the fact that in no province is that alcoholic content in drugs or patent medicines prohibited.
I wish to amend the subsection further by striking out the words "essential formula and composition of such medicine" and inserting in lieu thereof the words "quantity of alcohol or of such drug or drugs contained in such medicine." This will put the Advisory Board in a position to determine whether the alcoholic content is in excess of two and a half per cent, and will also give information as to the drug or drugs contained in such medicine. The section as it now stands requires the disclosure of the essential formula and com-



position of the medicine. It was deemed possible that that would be unfair, because it would compel the proprietor to disclose all knowledge relating to his property.
Amendment agreed 'to; subsection as amended - agreed to.

speechtext:
I will withdraw that and I will say it is' to prevent manufacturers from flooding the country with patent medicines.
Mr. A. K. MACLEAN; The manufacture of patent medicine is either a fair business or it ought not to exist at all. You cannot fairly and justly treat it as being different from any other class of business. True, in its very nature, it must be carefully carried on. There must be safeguards. That is one of the purposes of amending the Act this session. But we have no right to endeavour to reduce the manufacture of patent or proprietary medicines by restricting it in any way by taxation. That is not a good business and not good legislation, and I cannot accept the amendment whatever be the view of the Committee. If my hon. friend means that we should get more revenue from it, then I say that is the duty of the Minister of Finance. I have not a very intimate personal acquaintance with the patent medicine business. I have no doubt it is of use to some extent and serves purposes, and particularly for poor people. There are a nymber of people who really think that the manufacture of proprietary medicines plays a very important part in the life of the country.

speechtext:
The Bill does not propose to impose a tax; my hon. friend has a mistaken notion of its purpose. It provides that every manufacturer of a proprietary or patent medicine shall register the same at Ottawa, so that the department may know what patent medicines are being sold to the public, and the technical officers of the department can investigate concerning the ingredients and qualities of their medicines. If on investigation a patent medicine is found to be one that should not be sold it would be put on the forbidden list, or to deal with it may require an amendment of the Act. The purpose of the Bill is that all men should register any patent medicine they make. Upon what principle can we say that the ordinary druggist should pay less than the

wholesaler or the manufacturer? If the manufacturer makes more money than the retailer, as he probably does, the revenue of the Government should get some of that money in the shape of income tax. If we are not getting enough now from that source then the income tax should be raised.

Mr. JOHN A. STEWART: The remarks of the hon. gentleman (Mr. Steele) are very likely to create a misapprehension in the minds of the members of the Committee. When he states, as he has done, the volume of the goods manufactured the inference might be drawn that that volume of business comes under the provisions of the license which has to be taken out under the Bill. But under the provision of the Proprietary and Patent Medicines Act the manufacturer of a patent or proprietary medicine has two courses open to him. He may put upon the label of his goods the formula of the contents. If he does not do that he must register it as a proprietary or patent medicine. The only preparations which will be subject to this license, as I understand it, are those which are registered. Now a very small proportion of the business referred to by the hon. member (Mr. Steele) represents a registered business. In addition to those patent or proprietary medicines which do not contain the formula upon the label and which come under the license, there is a /very large volume of preparations which are manufactured for dispensing-preparations which are manufactured for the druggist and dispensed upon the prescription of physicians. All that business does not come under the necessity for a license, as I understand the Bill. It would therefore be a very great mistake to imagine that anything more than a small proportion of the
[Mr. A. K. Maclean!
volume of business concerned will come under license at all. In fact I may say that some of the largest selling proprietary medicines on the market to-day are sold with the formula on the label and are not registered.
