Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
This item deals with the ''sale and trade in food and other products." Does that imply that the department has to do with cold storage cars, for instance? Does the department furnish cold storage for the transportation of fish and other perishable products which are carried from one place to another?
This matter is of the greatest importance The fishermen along the coasts of Nova Scotia, New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island complain that while there are cold storage cars they are very poorly equipped and a very large percentage of fish and other products put into cold storage become unfit for human food before they reach their destination. It is necessary that fish should be kept cool and well iced from one stage of transportation to another until it is finally disposed. It has been complained that this matter is not attended to, and that the ice which is provided when the food leaves the point of shipment melts and is not renewed, the fish being destroyed. If this item is intended to cover [DOT]that particular phase of transportation and bring it within the scope of the Department of Agriculture, I would seriously press upon the minister the necessity of having the most complete system that can possibly be devised. Attention should be given not only to what forces itself upon the department, but every encouragement should he given to see that proper care is exercised in transportation with a view to obtaining the best and most profitable results. I have always thought-and I have brought the matter to the attention of the Govern-

ment several times-that in addition to provision for the proper care of food on transit in cars, there should be a suitable place of reception for the cars themselves when they reach their destination, some sort of cold storage shed where the car might be kept free from contamination until the freight is finally unloaded. These cars, I understand, are sometimes allowed to stand in the yard uncared for and in many cases valuable food such as fish decays and becomes unfit for consumption, and has to he thrown away. I am not quite sure that this comes within the purview of the Department of Agriculture, but the item seems to suggest that it does. If it does, I cannot too strongly urge upon the minister, and in any event upon the department which may deal with the matter, the great importance of this phase of the transportation question.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
This item covers only
transportation of dairy products and fruits; it does not include fish, which is covered by an item in the Marine and Fisheries Department. Assistance is given to promote, and also by way of investigation to ascertain, the advantages to the producer from the use of proper refrigeration service in the transportation of these perishable commodities. I quite agree with the leader of the Opposition that the matter is one of very great importance. The advantage of cold storage and proper refrigeration, not only in rail bui in ocean transportation, has not, I venture to say, been fully recognized by the producers and the people generally. To assist in this work the Government, as has already been stated in the House on previous occasions, have made provision for the erection of a public cold storage plant on the harbour front of Montreal under the control of the Board of Harbour Commissioners for that port. Thi9 is to accomplish the very purpose which the leader of the Opposition refers to, namely, that commodities may have a suitable place of storage pending their further shipment. A portion of this grant is used for cow testing in the ordinary dairy herds. We have a staff of inspectors, and farmers are encouraged to test the milk production of their various animals. Very remarkable results have been obtained, and many farmers are weeding out unprofitable animals. There is also provision for cargo inspection in the shipment of perishable commodities overseas. There is a cargo inspection not only at the port of landing but also in the United Kingdom. Self-registering thermometers are used in the storage
compartments of the vessels, and complete records of temperatures are taken on the way across, which records are preserved in the files of the department. Further, there is some small provision for the drafting of plans of suitable dairy buildings. Very often inquiries are received from creameries and cheese factories and persons interested in the dairy business for suggestions as to suitable buildings to meet their requirements, and we are endeavouring to provide-for these necessities'. These are the matters that are mainly covered by the items included under this head. The development of our dairying industry in Canada is of. great importance. Great Britain imports about 500,000,000 pounds of butter annually and Canada supplies a very small portion of that, not more than a few million pounds. Britain's annual imports in eggs are also enormous, but Canada supplies only a few millions of dozens. In order to take full advantage of that market and to hold it we have to do two or three important things. First, we must secure the bost possible standard of quality in our product, and in the various activities of the department we are endeavouring to impress that fact on producers. Second,-and this is of equal importance-there must be proper facilities for shipment. If you ship a carload of butter from Montreal, Halifax or any other port and leave it standing on the wharf for a day or two in hot weather, deterioration sets in and the original quality of the butter can never be restored. Therefore, proper cold storage facilities and proper refrigeration service on vessels are of the greatest importance. The business of this branch generally is to study that field, and by experiment, investigation and inquiry, to discover the best possible methods that can be used to achieve these results.
Mr. McKENZIiE: Have we succeeded in Canada in obtaining a perfectly safe refrigerator car for the transportation of perishable food such as butter or fruit? The difficulty has been that although we have been reputed to have refrigerator cars suitable for the carrying of such goods, the cals used have been altogether inadequate, and great losses have been incurred by the use of them. Is there any experiment or improvement in this matter? Are we advancing any nearer the goal of our ambition to have a perfectly good refrigerator car?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Experiments have been
conducted with ice-cooled cars and brine-tank-cooled cars, and the result would seem

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Can the minister give
any information about the amount of oleomargarine that has been manufactured and sold in Canada?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
The dairy commissioner
informs me that 14,000,000 pounds have been sold in Canada since the prohibition was lifted in October, 1917, of which about 8,000,000 pounds was manufactured in Canada.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: What firms are manufacturing it?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I suppose this oleomargarine is being sold under strict regulations ?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: One dollar a year.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: The number of cows tested last year was 27,000.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: Where?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
All over Canada, but
mainly in the great dairying provinces of Ontario and Quebec. This work is being carried on in conjunction .with cheese factories and creameries where the cheese-maker or the buttermaker has the expert 
knowledge necessary to carry out the test successfully.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I understand some
change is being made in the system of cowtesting. A year or two ago there were certain districts in charge of representatives of the department who carried on the work. Is the operation now being carried on as successfully as it was under the old system?	-

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: The work was carried out formerly by inspectors appointed by the department but that was abandoned and the department now is endeavouring to have the cheesemakers and buttermakers do the work of the inspectors. The department pays the cheesemaker or buttermaker a small fee per cow tested. That supplements the revenue that he gets from his work, and we find that the work can be extended to a greater degree with less cost than under the other system.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: What success have you had in getting the cheesemakers to do the work?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
First class.
Towards the encouragement of cold storage warehouses for the better preservation and handling of perishable food products, $25,000.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: What is this item?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: In 1908 by legislative enactment, provision was made for bonusing the building of cold storage warehouses throughout Canada. The regulations provided that the Government, where suoh warehouses should be built, would provide thirty per cent of the cost of construction. This was spread over several years. A total of over $650,000 had been paid out from the time of the inauguration of this policy until the commencement of the war. Since 1914 no new subsidies have been paid with the exception of a contract that had been made prior to the commencement of the war.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: Where?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: In Saskatoon. The matter has been under the consideration of the department and recently a decision was reached and embodied In an Order in Council, passed under a provision of the Act, that we will cease giving assistance to the development of private cold storage houses. There is a provision still that assistance may be given in the case of a municipally owned cold storage warehouse and in future the aid will be confined to such.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Did the Government
retain any control over the cold storage warehouses for the 30 per cent of the $650,000, which was given to the proprietors?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
There was a measure of
control over the storage rates charged by these warehouses. As a matter of fact, the system has not worked out very satisfactorily from the point of 9 p.m. view of the public. Generally the persons or the companies building the storage were engaged in the business themselves and it was somewhat difficult to regulate them under the provisions of the Act. We are considering now the passage of regulations providing for the licensing of cold storage and a little closer control in so far as returns are concerned.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I would suppose that some of this cold storage would be reserved for the public use. Could a farmer require a company to give him space or could the company sell the entire space to one or two parties?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Farmers or others can
get space if it is available. But there is no provision that these cold storage warehouses shall .keep a certain amount of space available for ;the public land the result is that generally the private dealer who owns the storage uses the whole of it. As long as there is space available the public can get it.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I think in framing the
regulations it would be proper to provide that a certain portion of the space should be reserved for the public. I believe that would very effectually break up the scheme that is being carried out at the present time.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
As a rule the public get
what they want, but I doubt if the Government has any such power of control as the hon. gentleman suggests should be exercised.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I think it should have that power.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: How many cold storage warehouses are there in New Brunswick, and where are they situated?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: There are two in New Brunswick to which we are paying a subsidy, one at Woodstock and the other at St. John.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
The policy of giving
subsidies to private cold storage plants has been abandoned, and I gather that the
minister is not very much in favour of it. What is the Government's present policy now with regard to cold storage plants in Canada?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: As I stated this afternoon, the Government has provided something over $1,000,000 for the erection of a cold storage plant on the harbour front at Montreal. As to further developments, while the Government's policy has not been definitely decided upon, my own personal view is that the plan adopted in the case of Montreal should be extended to other shipping points.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: Do you think that it will be extended?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I think eventually that it will. There is great merit in the idea that it would be better from the point of view of public cold storage-at any rate so it seems to me-if municipalities would undertake the erection of municipal cold storage plants.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
The Government has
adopted public ownership in regard to railways, and I would ask if it is intended to adopt the same policy in respect of cold storage plants. I think if the Government did that, government ownership would be much more profitable and beneficial to the public generally than it might possibly be wherf applied in some other directions.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
That has already been
done in some Western towns. I recall New Westminster as one in particular, where the corporation of the city and the council of the adjoining municipality have combined for the erection of a mufiicipal cold storage plant which shall be available for the merchants of the city, and the farmers from the adjacent county who want to take advantage of it.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Does not the minister
think that if the duty were taken off cold storage plants it might facilitate the establishment of numerous plants throughout the country? Does he not think it would be an advantage to do that?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: What a question !

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I think it might possibly help.
Air. J. E. iSINCLAIR: Do I understand that this item we .are considering relates to all classes of food commodities, including fish?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: No.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: The item in the Estimates speaks of cold storage warehouses " for the better preservation and handling of food products," but has no reference to fish?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I stated in reply to the leader of the Opposition (Mr. McKenzie) that it applied only to fruit and dairy products. Fish is provided for in the fisheries
estimates.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: To what extent does the Government exercise supervision over cold storage plants? For instance, the hon. member for Maisonneuve (Mr. Lemieux) yesterday drew the Government's attention to the large quantity, in fact tons, of foodstuffs that had been destroyed in the city of Montreal. Would not prevention be a much better plan than destruction in such cases? If the Government has the right to supervise the cold storage plants of the country, would it not he wisdom on its part to insist that the owners dispose of the products in cold storage before they become rotten and have to be destroyed ?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: The hon. gentleman raises a very broad problem. In the particular case to which he refers, I believe the goods were out of condition before they were stored. I have not the slightest hesitation in stating that if it were not for the existing cold storage plants in Canada probably the loss and deterioration of food stuffs would be very much greater than it is. Whether the Government should exercise that control over food commodities which the hon. gentleman suggests is, at any rate, a debatable question. These cold storage plants, as I understand it, are subject to municipal regulations in that respect, and personally I think it always well for the municipality to deal with such matters rather than apply Federal control to them. In other words, it is better on principle to have the municipal power invoked, wherever it can be done successfully, rather than the Federal power in a matter of that kind.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I understand that under the terms of the vote we are considering, the Government exercises a certain control over these cold storage plants. Is it not a crime to allow good food stuffs to go to waste, and should not the Government step in and compel the owners of the plants to dispose of those food stuffs before they become unfit for human consumption and have to be destroyed ?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I have already stated that the Government has commenced by providing for the erection of a public cold storage plant at Montreal. I stated also that I was not in a position to say what the general policy of the Government in the matter would be.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
A certain control has
been exercised, but, as -I have already stated, it has not been found very effective, particularly after the subsidies have been earned, for the reason that the private owner of the cold storage plant very often requires this space for himself. I think that in the main, however, the public have been very well served. As to the other point which the hon. gentleman raises, and urges upon the Government, namely that it *should take the power to order the sale of commodities at certain times, it has no relation to the item under discussion, and

is a question upon which I am not prepared to express an opinion.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Under the Act 'under
which assistance was granted towards the construction of these various cold storage plants, that aid was given to only one plant in each locality, a policy which has not met with the expectations of the Government. I would like to ask, would the existence of that one plant in a municipality be a barrier to that municipality getting the aid that will be extended under the present scheme?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Offhand, I would not
care to give a definite answer at the moment.
Mr. 00WAN:	I hope the minister will
take that point into consideration.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: Are we to understand that in the case of publicly-owned plants the Government intends to grant subsidies as it has heretofore done in the case of private companies? For example, suppose certain municipalities want to open cold storage plants, does the Government intend to give them assistance to the extent of thirty per cent of the cost of construction, or will it assist them at any time?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Is it the intention of the Government to erect a cold storage plant at Halifax or at some other suitable place in

the Maritime Provinces? Such a plant would toe of great assistance in building up an export trade, il understand the farmers in the Maritime Provinces are labouring under a severe handicap, as they have no cold storage plant and have to ship their products very long distances, such as to Montreal, at heavy expense, with the result, in many cases, that their live stock produces only about half as much as the same live stock would sell at on the Toronto market. If a cold storage plant were built at that point it would be a great help to the live stock industry in that part of Canada.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
The suggestion will receive the consideration of the Government. No decision has been reached to erect a cold storage plant at Halifax or any other Atlantic port other than Montreal, where we have made a start.
Mr. LBGE'R: I would favour the idea of a Government-owned cold storage plant in the Maritime Provinces. With that I would urge the Government to have a good inspector to visit it frequently. If I am well informed, there are throughout Canada many cold storage warehouses, full of foodstuffs w.hich are held for higher prices. These cold storage warehouses should be visited by Government inspectors and the foodstuffs should be sold instead of being kept there to enhance prices. In that way the poor people of Canada would be benefited. These trusts or combines get together and fill up these warehouses with foodstuffs which they hold until the price goes up. As was said by an hon. member, a large quantity of foodstuffs was wasted in Montreal toy being held in cold storage for higher prices. The cost of living is getting so high that it is almost impossible for the poor people to live, and the Government should take steps to cause cold storage warenouses to -be emptied at a certain time of the year instead of being kept full of foodstuffs the year round, thus keeping the price up.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I am glad the hon. member for Victoria city (Mr. Tolmie) has brought up the question of Government-owned cold storage warehouses at Atlantic ports. I understand the Department of Agriculture for Nova Scotia has been impressing upon the minister that some steps should be taken to erect at Halifax a cold storage plant somewhat similar to the one it is proposed to erect at Montreal. I have nothing to say against the building of a plant at Montreal,

but I was told that- one of the reasons why this cold storage plant was 'being erected at Montreal was to furnish facilities for the shipment of -chilled or other beef at all seasons of the year. The minister knows well that .shipping facilities at the port of Montreal are limited in season. For a considerable portion of the year that port is frozen up and vessels cannot come to or go away from it. Navigation is open in the harbour of Halifax 365 days of the year every year, and I am sure the same thing may be said of St. John, although not to the same easy extent as at Halifax. I do not know if there are any hon. members from New Brunswick here -who may criticise me if I say anything about the high tide difficulties of the St. John harbour. It is, however, open all the year round and ships can come to and go from it. If the Government have decided that it is proper to spend $1,000,000 for the purpose of erecting a cold storage plant to be auxiliary to transhipment across the Atlantic, that plant should be at a place which shipping can go to and depart from at all seasons. That is, I think, a strong argument in favour of such facilities being erected at the ports of Halifax and St. John, or, if not at both, at least at one of them. In- view of the fact that the Nova Scotia Department of Agriculture -has put in its claim-and I have not heard that any particular claim was sent in from New Brunswick, although the one would require it just as much as the other-the minister should give some attention to the very legitimate request put forward. I understand the hon. member for Victoria city who has brought this matter to the attention of the minister is the president of a -certain association that has to deal with agricultural matters throughout the province.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: The Canadian National Live -Stock Council, made up of representatives from the Eastern and Western Live Stock Unions.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I have no information as to that.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
My hon. friend is an authority on the question and I am glad he has brought this matter up. I should like to point out to the minister an extraordinary thing that happened in Nova Scotia last year. The farmers in several counties such <as Pictou and Antigonish, the latter being exclusively a farming community, -are excellent farmers. They discovered that the hay crop was not up to standard last

year, and tliey were obliged to sell off hundreds of their live stock. They sold them to a gentleman who could do nothing with them but take them to a place where they could be slaughtered and put into cold storage. As there was no cold storage warehouse in the Maritime Provinces, those cattle were carried alive to Montreal or Toronto, slaughtered and the meat kept in cold storage all winter. The beef was then shipped back over nearly 1,500 miles of railroad to Nova Scotia and sold to our miners, lumbermen and other people. The minister can readily understand the enormous increase that must necessarily be put upon the first cost of that article on account of its being handled in that manner.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
There are no abattoir
plants in the Maritime Provinces?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
No, but I understand
those interested in the cattle trade are quite ready to build abattoirs if cold storage facilities were provided, but it is too expensive for them to erect a cold storage plant, and they are, therefore, looking to the Government to do so. It would be a good investment and a good policy for the Government to build such a plant. Does the minister intend in connection with the cold storage plant at Montreal, to provide a place where a car could be run in?
In order to do that, the lower story of the building would have to be made something like a railway yard. If that could be provided, it would certainly save a great deal of handling and re-handling of the contents. It might be that these facilities would be made use of only once in a while, but they would certainly 'be a splendid thing to have. I have particularly in mind what happens to our cars of fish from the Maritime Provinces. Friday is the big fish day in cities, and Thursday or early Friday morning is the best time to sell a car of fish in Montreal or Toronto. If the car happens to get there on Monday or Tuesday and has to stand in the yard during the early part of the week, when there is not so much demand for fish, my information is, the fish deteriorates and becomes unfit for sale, often resulting in a total loss. If there was a place in the cold storage building into which a car could be run and kept until its contents were disposed of, the shippers would feel secure against waste, and it would be a great encouragement to them. If this can be brought about, and the plans are not too far advanced, I would certainly suggest that limited accommodation, at all events, of
this character should be supplied in any cold storage warehouse that is to be erected.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
The cold storage warehouse to be erected in Montreal will be under the control of the harbour commissioners. I know that they had competent engineers making inquiries, and the Dairy and Cold Storage Commissioner, Mr. Rud-dick, accompanied one of the engineers to several cities in the United States to Iook over the most'up-to-date cold storage plants to be found in them. I have no doubt that as a result of their inquiries the most modern and up-to-date plant will be built in Montreal. I do not think the proposal advanced by the leader of the Opposition that a car should be run into the building, and the whole stored as a carload, is a practicable one. In fact, I think it would be very difficult, probably impossible, to carry out his suggestion. The most up-to-date facilities, however, will be provided for taking care of fish, fruit and any other perishable commodities that are shipped.
Now a word as to why Montreal wa3 selected. Montreal, of course, is a summer port, and it is during the summer months when temperatures are high that the need for cold storage is greatest. For that reason Montreal was selected as the initial point. There is already a cold storage plant in St. John, under the control of the Canadian Pacific Railway. Halifax is not as yet supplied with such a plant. I quite sympathize with the view expressed by the leader of the Opposition as to the necessity of proper abattoir and cold storage facilities in the province of Nova Scotia, or at any rate in one of the Maritime Provinces, and I presume Nova Scotia would be the most suitable, in order to encourage the development of the live stock industry in that part of Canada. It is quite true, as he has stated, that Nova Scotia cattle are at times shipped to Montreal for slaughter and the beef re-shipped for sale to the people of Nova Scotia. That on the face of it is an economic waste. At the request of the Provincial Department of Agriculture for Nova Scotia we have sent some of our officials to that province to make, in conjunction with the provincial officials, a survey of the whole situation with a view to ascertaining the best line of action to follow.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I think the minister should withdraw that statement. Toronto would be very much offended at being spoken of as a "town."
Health of Animals, $465,000.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I would draw the minister's attention to a very serious state of affairs which was mentioned in the Committee on Agriculture. The statement was made there that during last year tuberculosis among beef cattle had increased, I think, from three to over four per cent, and in hogs from nine to nineteen per cent. That is a most alarming state of affairs, and I would ask what steps the department is taking to check this disease.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Tuberculosis amongst
cattle has received the consideration of the qualified officials of the department, and the whole question has been closely and attentively studied. It is my intention to submit Supplementary Estimates for $50,000 for the-purpose of inaugurating a system of accredited herds for pure-bred cattle.
The tuberculosis trouble exists I believe in every country in the world. The United States authorities have recently undertaken a method of handling it and last year ap- * propriated $500,000 for the purpose. I have been informed this year according to their Estimates it was intended to increase the appropriation to $1,000,000. I do not need to deal with the technical aspect of the plan they had in view. If the Committee desires further information in regard to that matter I am quite sure the hon. member for Victoria City (Mr. Tolmie) who has made a close study of the matter will be pleased to

give it. The matter is receiving the attention of qualified officials of the department. The problem is a somewhat difficult one to deal with.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
What is the
cause of this rapid increase in the disease? There must be something unusual .about it. Have the officials of the department endeavoured to ascertain the cause?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I do not know that there has been any rapid increase in the spread of the disease, and I am unable to give specific causes for any increase?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I would call
the minister's attention to the statistics. I think there was an increase of 9 per cent in hogs.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: What statistics?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
They were
given in the Agricultural Committee, and it is a most alarming state of affairs if there is going to be an increase in that ratio or anything like it.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I suppose this vote includes the inspection of twelve-ounce pounds of lobster cans under the law which my hon. friend's colleague is passing to make twelve ounces of lobster a pound. Does it include all canned goods?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I do not know. I might be inclined to agree with the hon. member off hand, but the matter is not in this department and I must refer him to the Department of Marine and Fisheries.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: There must be some canned commodities that it is intended to inspect or this amount would not be asked for. Do those who come within the jurisdiction of this department, and who engage in the canning of food other than lobster, say that twelve ounces make a .pound avoirdupois?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I can assure the hon. gentleman that the Department of Agriculture insists on sixteen ounces to the pound.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
That increase was over a period of six years. I am not sure of the exact figures given at that time, but I think that is it. I certainly would like to compliment the department on the distinct advance they are making in appropriating $50,000 for the purpose of introducing the accredited herd system. If we can hope to export cattle to the United States and hold that market, and if the embargo is removed from cattle going to Great Britain and we desire to ship cattle there, we must be sure that we send only healthy animals to those two markets; otherwise we cannot expect to retain them. The accredited herd system will give the advantage to the herd that is kept clean, and I sincerely hope that the breeders of the country will avail themselves of this opportunity to the fullest extent. I desire to congratulate the Health of animals Branch of the department on the work they have accomplished during the past few years. On several occasions we have had very serious outbreaks of infectious and contagious diseases immediately along the boundary line, and in nearly all cases none of the diseases have entered Canada., By preventing disease in that way through a close system of inspection we have been saved the loss of millions of dollars, and when we consider the small appropriation-I see there is an increase to a certain extent this year- and compare that appropriation with the

enormous value of the live stock in Canada, something between one and one and a half billions of dollars, it will be recognized that a very valuable work is being accomplished by this branch of the Department of Agriculture at a nominal cost.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Is there any simple
process by which an ordinary farmer can detect tuberculosis in herds or in the individual cow?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Only by the tuberculin
test which has proved successful.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: Is this grant for salaries or for compensation for animals destroyed, or for both? The amount is $465,000.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
It includes both; $70,000
is for compensation.
For the administration and enforcement of the Meat and Canned Foods Act, ?4 42,000.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
The increase here is due
to the general increase in wages and to enlargement of the work. Under the Act qualified veterinary inspectors along with lay inspectors are kept in every abattoir and meat packing plant and canning establishment in Canada in order to insure the purety of the foods produced therein.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: Has it not been customary for some years to keep inspectors in packing plants?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Yes. I am accounting
for the increase in the vote which hon. members will see amounts to $63,000. It is due to the necessity of paying higher wages and salaries and also to an extension of the work.. More inspectors are required every year.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
What salaries are paid
the inspectors?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: The salaries, I am informed, are from $1,400 to $1,800 for veterinarians.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: It commences at $1,400?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: Yes.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: It does not include canned fish, which comes under the Marine and Fisheries Department. It includes all other canned goods.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: Does the minister know of any other class of producers who claim that twelve ounces of food make a pound avoirdupois?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: There is another industry that puts up its product in twelve ounces, and sometimes ten-ounce pounds. I refer to the manufacture of wool, which is put up in twelve-ounce and ten-ounce pounds, and even in eight-ounce pounds, according to the demands of the retail merchant.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
It is not canned.
Publications Branch, $36,300.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
In this branch I think there is scope for improvement. I have been attempting to circulate the literature of the department for a great many years, and formerly I used to get a fair supply of material for distribution. The last time I applied, about two years ago, I was informed that I could get only a very limited supply, and that I would have to submit the names of my addressees to the department. Dealing with the large number of farmers to whom I would have to give literature T realized that a limited quantity would be only a source of embarrassment to me. I might select a few names and address material to them while the others would receive nothing, and from a political standpoint it would be better for me to send none at all. So that I did not send any. I do not think that members should be called upon to attend to a matter of this kind. Once the information is put into shape by the officers of the department who go to the pains of collecting their material the hardest part of the work is over, particularly when the literature is printed; and the department should see to it that this literature finds its way to the agriculturists of the country. It is a pity that tons of this material should be wasted

from year to year, and I strongly urge upon the minister that the officers who have charge of this branch should acquaint themselves with the names and addresses of the farmers from coast to coast. It is a large undertaking, but they can very readily get this information by applying to the agricultural societies in the several provinces. In this way they would get at least 75 or 80 per cent of the names of the farmers and as they have no postage to pay it would be a comparatively simple matter to send literature to the farmers. I wish to impress upon the minister the desirability of seeing that this information reaches those whom it will benefit. Undoubtedly it would be useful and might stimulate the farmer to greater efforts in the way of increased production, besides giving him new ideas. At all events it would impress him with the idea that the department is taking an interest in him and has his prosperity at heart. I know that only very few farmers of Canada receive any literature from the department. I would like to see literature relating to the farm finding its way into more houses and into the hands of more farmers than at present, for it would certainly have beneficial results.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: There are probably between 650,000 and 700,000 farmers in Canada, and the publications branch have on their files the names of 240,000 farmers who are supplied with the class of bulletin they desire. I have found in my experience of several years that the best results are always obtained when the person who desires literature makes application for it in some form or other. Very often you get names from such a source as the voters' lists, and send circulars or pamphlets to the addresses there given, with the result that a large percentage of the literature thus sent finds its way into the waste basket. The evidence of interest on the part of the person applying for literature and the best guarantee that he will make proper rise of it when he gets it, is the fact that he goes to the trouble of applying for it. However, I entirely agree with the leader of the Opposition as to the importance of the matter.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
The Agricultural Gazette has only a limited circulation. It is distributed to teachers and colleges, agricultural institutes and district representatives in the various provinces. There are also a number of subscribers who pay a small

annual subscription. I am unable to state what the total circulation is.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I do not quite agree
with the minister as to the way in which this matter should be attended to. Possibly his view is one way of looking at it, but it seems to suggest the argument that we should not send missionaries to the distant islands and remote parts of the earth until they have made application for

some one to go and preach to them the gospel of the Nazarene. That is not the way in which the gospel is propagated. We send missionaries to the heathen and wake him up to the necessity of looking to the salvation of his soul, and in like manner we should send to the farmers, who need the information that we can give them, such literature as will be of benefit to them. If we did this we would create a desire on their part for more and more information, and applications would then be made in abundance. In many departments of life we are content to keep in the old rut, and if we do not assimilate new ideas we are apt to rest content with what was done by our grandfathers and fathers. The aim of the department should be to create a new interest in farming and they should not spare a few more dollars in putting necessary pamphlets and other useful records within the reach of the farmers if by so doing they can encourage them and stimulate an interest in rural life in Canada.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
The missionary does not
always act on his own initiative. I believe that Holy Writ records that the great St. Paul heard a call from Macedonia and proceeded thither, and I believe also that when we send missionaries to foreign lands we usually have repeated and earnest calls from those places for additional missionaries. The same applies in this matter. That is precisely the same method as we are following in the distribution of this literature. We aim to get it into the hands of the community, a desire for literature is produced and it is sent out.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I must correct my hon. friend on the Pauline doctrine. The gospel was preached at Macedonia but some of the preachers went away and those of the Christian religion felt that somebody must come to them and help them along. Hence the Macedonian cry.

speechtext: My hon. friend has raised the Macedonian cry to-night.

We endeavour to get as good a type of animal as can be purchased,

and I couid not say what the average price would be. In stallions prices would run all the way from $500 to $1,000.

International Institute of Agriculture-to assist in maintenance thereof and to provide representation thereat-$10,000.

This vote, I would like
to explain, is to provide for our membership in the International Institute of Agriculture at Rome, with which practically all the countries of the world that are engaged to any extent in agriculture are identified. This vote is simply to cover our contributions thereto and to meet our expenses in com ection therewith. The institute gathers agricultural statistics from all countries, and compiles and publishes them, and in that way seeks to disseminate accurate and complete information as to what is going on in these countries.
M. J. E. SINCLAIR: Does the vote include the expenses of sending a delegate to the meetings?

For the development of the live stock industry-$800,000.

speechtext: I happen to be interested in a similar case. I quite understand that when an inspector goes into a district it would disorganize his work if he had to go back after a fixed date. speechtext:
In connection with
this vote, could the minister suggest any way by which the farmers throughout the country could obtain pure bred stock more cheaply than it is possible for them to do at present? I do not know very much about the subject, but I am told that the prices charged for pure bred animals are very high, and practically it is beyond the reach of the ordinary farmer to obtain them. I would like to know from the minister if there is any combine or corner in connection with pure bred stock? There are, of course, large farmers and wealthy people who "play the market" to some extent in connection with stock at this time. Perhaps I should not use the expression "play the market", but many such persons make a hobby of raising fine cattle and horses and selling them at fancy prices. That is very good and we ought to be thankful, doubtless, to the people whose predilections lead them in that direction; but what I would like to know is, how can pure bred stock

be placed within reach of the ordinary farmers of the country without their paying such high prices as are charged? The Government may perhaps be taking some action along this line at present. I am satisfied, however, that there is riot enough of it done, at. all events in Nova Scotia, especially in the eastern part. There is need of further steps in this direction because I know that our cattle in many agricultural sections of 'the island of Cape Breton are not as good as they were twenty-five or thirty years ago. There is growing need of a revival in the matter of improved live stock, need of a better class of cattle and a better appreciation by the farmers of the advantage of having good stock rather than poor stock.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I cannot agree with the Mr. DAVIS: Could you not make a conclusion of the hon. gentleman. The rea- special exception of a case like this?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
The point which the hon. gentleman has brought up is an important one. The federal Department of Agriculture does give specific assistance towards the promotion of the better breeding of live stock of all kinds. As far as cattle, sheep, and swine are concerned, it, is given in this way: Provision is, made for the supplying of pure-bred sires in each of these classes to associations of farmers that organize themselves and conform to certain regulations with which compliance is easy. The total number of sires that have been distributed in Canada is over two thousand. In other words, there were about two thousand of these associations in existence last year. Of that number, I am sorry to say, there were only twenty-nine in the province of Nova Scotia. The Department of Agriculture in that province carries on a somewhat similar work, but I am not at the moment able to give information as to the extent to which it does so, or as to the degree of success it has encountered. A very considerable portion of the expenditure contemplated by this vote is for this purpose. In the case of horses a percentage of the service fee is paid by the department, where the association is regularly formed, and its application has been regularly placed with the department. In all these cases as careful attention as possible is given to the securing of sound sires of the best quality available. There is no disguising the fact, however, that the general standard of our live stock, in cattle particularly,-in the beef typeu at any rate, -in Canada, is not as high as it might be. However, I believe that with .the general spread of knowledge and the insistence on the need of improvement, we will make greater progress in the future than we have

made in the past. We very frequently find, as every hon. member knows, farmers who are very largely indifferent to the type of animals that they have. They do not seem to realize as clearly as they should that it costs as much and even more to raise a scrub animal than it does to prodluce stock of a good type.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I notice an increase in this vote of $200,000. Is the increase due to a greater number of applications for purebred sires?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Not altogether. Some cf
the increases are due to advances in salaries and wages that have taken place in every branch of the department's work. I may say, however, for the information of the hon. gentleman (iMr. Myers) that we reduced the Estimate last year for this purpose by $200,000 or more. The present increase is to bring the appropriation back to what the amount was previous to that time. We restricted the work as much as possible last year in order to economize, tout owing to the importance of the work, the vote has been restored to the old figure.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
A number of applications from the constituency which I represent were delayed in reaching the department. I believe the money asked for here will be well spent in improving the live stock of our country, but I think a little leniency or consideration should have been given to the associations referred to. I have had my attention drawn particularly to the case of one association where the secretary was ill at the time the application should have been forwarded. I brought this fact before the department, but no consideration was given to the case. I think that was very unfair indeed. These men had formed an association at considerable cost to themselves, but owing to the fact that the secretary was ill at the time the application should have gone in, it was somewhat late in reaching the department, and it was declined. Now the intention of this vote toeing to help the farmers, there should have been a certain amount of leniency displayed in that particular case-in fact two instances of the kind were brought to my notice. Of course, if there are regulations governing this matter, they should be observed, but in such cases as I am referring to, the fact that delay in making the application was caused by illness should have been taken into consideration.
son for the delay, if I remember rightly, was the prevalence of influenza in the district concerned. But it is important that regulations, particularly in governmental administration, should be lived up to. When a department establishes a definite regulation for the governance of its work and that regulation is not adhered to, that moment the department is in difficulty. The regulation which the hon. gentleman criticises provides that these applications must be lodged with the department prior to April 1; in the case to which he refers the application came in ten days or two weeks late. Fully fifty similar applications came in after the first of April, running all the way from one to three days late up to five weeks late. If you admit one and refuse another, where are you going to draw the line? If you admit them all, what is the use of the regulation? If we violate the regulation for one, we must violate it for all, or we shall be charged with discrimination, favoritism, political pull and all the other things of a like nature. While I regret to disappoint my hon. friend, nevertheless I am sure that on reflection he will see the reasonableness of the position taken by the department in the matter.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Of course, the reasons
given for delay would be as numerous as the delayed applications. If the secretary of the association, as the hon. member says, was ill, the president or some other member could have written the department, and that is all that would have been necessary.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: They had some excuse; I do not know what it was. But it seems to me that where there is no change from the previous year, a delay, of a day or two ought not to affect the case.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I have found in imy brief experience that special exceptions in Governmental administration are always exceedingly dangerous. I appreciate the position of this association, but each of the fifty applicants who were late could put up just as good an argument why his case should have special consideration.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: Possibly the minister does not take into consideration the loss occasioned by not having the privilege of using a sire in a particular year.

But as I have said, each of the fifty applicants would consider that they had equally good arguments to advance in favour of the acceptance of their application. I venture to say that in all fifty oases the application could have been sent in on time if more careful attention had been given to the matter by the officers or by some member of the association. speechtext:
I was pleased to hear the minister a few moments ago emphatically lay down the rule that he was not going to make any exceptions. I wish to say a word about agricultural societies. We

have two classes of fairs in the West, the A land the B class. Regina, Saskatoon and cities of that size -are in th-e A class, and have been getting $5,000 a year assistance.	The Regina fair last year had
a surplus of about $22,000 to hand over to the city. In the B class there are some five or six different fairs, and a limit is laid down as to the amount of prize money they must pay out to participate in this grant-. If no exceptions are to be made, that is all right; but once you begin to make exceptions the trouble starts. Exceptions have been made in the case of some of the fairs. Some fairs which did not (Comply with '-the regulations have been granted 'assistance, and others that did not comply but applied for the grant were refused assistance, or at all events, we have not been able to get any definite answer yet. I should like the minister to lay down some definite rule as to what he is going to do about these fairs. If he is not going to follow any particular rule, but give the money out indiscriminately, I think -Swift (Current and one or two other places should participate with the others who have got the grant.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
'Under the regulations
for grants to fairs the provision was that where $4,000 of their own money was spent in utility prizes for livestock the department would assist to the extent of 75 per cent of $2,500. Prior to 1918 they secured the whole $2,500, but in order to economize and make our funds stretch as far as possible that grant was reduced last year by 25 per cent. There were, of course, a number of fairs that thought they were entitled to this grant and found difficulty in getting it. We appreciate the position the fairs are in at the present time. The hon. member for Swift Current and the hon. member for Battleford have both made strong representation upon the matter, and about a week or ten days ago I instructed the officials of the Branch to carefully survey the field again with a view to reducing the amount of expenditure that was necessary in order to participate in the grant. After careful consideration they have recommended for the present year a reduction of $400. Consequently, any fair that last year spent $3,600 or over in utility prizes will participate in the grant this year.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Has	the minister any
information as to the increase or decrease in the number of cattle in Canada during the last three or four years?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
The officials advise me
there has been a considerable and steady increase in the total number of cattle. The total number of cattle in Canada now is estimated to be over 10,000,000, and the increase during the past four years has been between 2,000,000 and 3,000,000. In some of the western provinces the increase has been very noticeable.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv

When the department

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Referring again to fairs,
as I stated a moment ago, the Regina fair last year had a surplus of $22,000 over and above their expenses. Now the B class fairs are doing just as much for the building up of the livestock industry as the A class fairs, and the larger cities like Regina do not need this grant of $5,000, but the smaller fairs do need assistance to carry on. I do not care whether the grant is $5 or $500, but I want all the B class fairs to be on the same footing. Yorktown and Prince Albert for instance, which did not comply with the regulations received the grant, while others did not. All I am asking for is a square deal.
Mr. CRERAR. If the fairs which the hon. member speaks for spent $3,600 last year in utility prizes they will participate in the grant this year. We have stretched the limit I think to the utmost. As to the relative merits of A and B class fairs, I dare say there are not a few hon. members in this House who would argue that the A class were more beneficial to the community than the B class. In the A class fairs the prize lists are larger, they have a bigger exhibition of livestock, and a great many more people patronize these fairs because they are held in the larger centres. The Toronto Fair, for instance, which runs for two weeks, undoubtedly attracts a great many more people than a fair in a little town of 2,000 people that runs for only three days. The policy of the Department may be open to criticism, but I am sure that the officials of the Department have studied the matter earnestly and honestly, with a view to getting the maximum of results for the money expended. I can assure the hon. member for Swift Current that it is not in the interest of any person in the department that B class fairs should
be discriminated against in favour of A class.
