In considering the matter the officials of the department were of the view that this shortage of $22 was not due to their inability to get the money. The other case was Yorktown, where there was a shortage of $46 for the same reason. 1 have asked the hon. member for Swift Current what amount the Swift 'Current Board spent last year, but I have not been able to find out.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I am not interested so much in what this contribution is given for fairs in Prince Albert and Yorktown, nor am I opposed to the grant to the Toronto Exhibition. But it is very questionable if the Toronto Exhibition would pay out in prizes to live stock in proportion to the grant received, and the Toronto Exhibition is a very profitable venture for the city of Toronto. I hold in my hand an item from a daily paper dated the 25th of December, which says:-
Toronto Fair Surplus $ 90,5<57.
Toronto, December 24.-Santa Claus, in the triple personality of T. A. Russell, president, Johnston G. Kent, manager, and Frank Brent-nail, treasurer of the Canadian National Exhibition, slid down the chimney into the City Hall to-day and presented Toronto with a cheque for $90,557.74, the biggest surplus by a good margin that the exhibition has ever paid.
It is quite apparent that such an exhibition which is able to finance itself should be able to concede a little bit to the pioneer districts in Western Canada, and some of the money might profitably go there.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
What is being done by the department either alone or in conjunction with the Agricultural Departments in the different provinces in organizing these societies? I was very much impressed by the address to-night by the hon. member for Victoria (Mr. Tolmie), and I was thinking that if some hon. gentlemen like himself or some other person equally informed and gifted were travelling through the farming districts and telling the farmers the advantages of pure bred stock very satisfac-

tory results would accrue. I am not aware that any organized or proper effort is being made in the part of the country from which I come either by the local Agricultural Department or by this department to bring this education home to the farmers and to invite them to organize and take advantage of tne opportunities which the department offers to them.
I am sure that there are hundreds and thousands of people who are making their living as farmers to whose attention the advantage of having proper stock and the way in which they can get it has now been forcibly brought. If no effort has been made hitherto to have a proper organization along those lines and a campaign of education, I would suggest to the minister that he should have a proper arrangement with the agriculture departments of the different provinces so that this campaign of education may be carried on. There is such a thing, no doubt, as a duplicating and overlapping of effort. We have agricultural societies in Nova Scotia under the supervision and control of the local legislature which do fairly good work, but we must push this work if we are to produce the results necessary to reach the high-water mark in regard to it. I am particularly pleased with the information which the hon. member for Victoria city has given us and I trust the Department of Agriculture will be able to present this matter to the people in such a way as to reach parts of the country that have not so far taken advantage of their opportunities. I am not finding fault with the department, because they seem to be doing good worx but I would like to go one step farther and press home upon the farmers the advisability of taking advantages of the opportunities which are made available t-o them through the department.
To enforce the Seed Act, to test seeds for farmers and seed merchants, bo encourage the production and use of superior seeds, and to encourage the production of farm and garden crops, $200,000.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I notice that this item
is for the purpose of encouraging the production of farm and garden crops. There is another method of encouraging the production of farm and garden crops which is not indicated fully in the description as contained in this item, and tha't is to find a market for that which has been produced. About a month ago I took the opportunity of asking the then Acting Prime Minister (Sir Thomas White) for information regarding some correspondence I had from a citizen living in the constituency that I

have the honour to represent. The Acting Prime Minister stated then that the Government had supplied altogether $80,000,000 to help in the marketing of Canadian wheat and that they were arranging, if my memory serves me aright, a credit of $90,000,000 additional for the same purpose. ' But he failed to explain why it was that any farmer found it difficult to find a market for his wheat and intimated that the wheat was not of proper grade. I have had since then considerable .correspondence from a number of farmers in the same section, as well as a number of millers, and they all have the same story to tell, that there is a large quantity of 11 p.m. wheat, fully twenty per cent of last year's crop, still in the hands of farmers. They all say that they cannot find a market for it. It may be difficult for a man like the Minister of Finance (Sir Thomas White) or the Minister of Agriculture to understand that, and yet that is the story that comes to me from the riding of South Renfrew. The hon. member for Chateauguay-Huntingdon (Mr. Robb) .made an inquiry regarding the same subject a few days ago and the Minister of Finance informed him then that the Government were negotiating with the Greek Government for the disposal of 15,000,000 or 20,000,000 bushels of wheat. Notwithstanding this information, I am still confronted with the proposition that the farmers in South Renfrew have that quantity of wheat on their hands and are not able to dispose of it. Just a couple of days ago I received a letter from the proprietors of the Killaloe Roller Mills Company. This was sent in response to an inquiry made by me, and they informed me that there are at least ten . or twelve cars of wheat within hauling distance of their mill but that owing to the fact that they are unable to find a market for their flour they cannot purchase this wheat. The consequence is that this wheat will remain on the farmers' hands. The farmers are anxious' because, as I understand, the guaranteed price for wheat will be withdrawn and the farmers with 18,000 or 20,000 bushels of wheat in one little section of South Renfrew will be left with this wheat on their hands. There are other sections in the same position, and they naturally view the situation with considerable anxiety. I rise to discuss this issue on this item because it is my opinion that if the Government and department will find a market for that wheat they will certainly encourage production. These men were induced to in-

crease their acreage during the past two years for war purposes. In the last two years they increased their production by fifty per cent. That is the opinion of the several milling concerns in the riding. A market was held out to them as an inducement and as a result of that inducement there was increased acreage and increased production. If you want farmers to increase production no better method can be adopted than to insure a market for what they produce. Here is -the case as I find it not only in that one section of my constituency but in several other sections as well. They have the wheat on hand but no market. They want me to find out what the Government are going to do about this situation.
I would like to know the exact attitude of the Government in regard to the disposition of wheat which is in the hands of farmers at the present time, particularly in South Renfrew, in which I am naturally most interested. Will the Government undertake to find a market for that wheat at the guaranteed price? Should not the farmers expect the Government to take action along definite lines? Will the Government undertake to purchase the wheat to fill the contracts referred to a couple of days ago by the Minister of Finance? Will the hen. gentleman say that this wheat will be purchased for that purpose?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: How much wheat has the hon. gentleman's correspondent?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: One correspondent says there are twelve cars of wheat within hauling distance of his mill; another, two cars; another says that there is twenty-five per cent of the season's crop around his section, and still another tells the same story. I cannot tell what the quantity is, but there will be about 20,000 bushels in that one section of my constituency.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I do not wish to further interrupt the hon. gentleman, but I know that a ready market is being found for all the surplus wheat in Canada at the present time. If this wheat has not been marketed I fancy it must be due to other causes. The demand undoubtedly exists for it, and I am informed that it is being sold steadily and readily.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: Are all men wounded in any way expected to make claims for disability?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I must say to the minister that if he entertains any doubt as to the quality of this wheat I can assure him on that score. The quality of the wheat raised in the Bonnechere Valley is equal to what is considered Manitoba No. 1 Hard. That is the reputation of the wheat raised generally
in that section. And I am informed by one of the millers that the quality of the wheat sold there is first-class in every particular.
1 might further state that this miller wrote to the department, and I have the letter which he received in reply. It is certainly not very encouraging. With your permission, Mr. Chairman, I will read it. It 'is dated April the 24th, and is as follows:
Dear Sirs,-I have your letter of April 18th, but regret to state that there is very little in formation I can give you, except that conditions have changed materially during the past year The great shortage of ocean steamships has led to congestion in many parts of the world. An arrangement was entered into some time ago with the British Government by which the Wheat Export Company were to take the exportable surplus of the 1918 crop on the -basis of the fixed prices. The British Government, however, has -been unable to purchase the quantity at first thought necessary in view of the congestion at British ports and the very large quantity of wheat in the United Kingdom, larger quantities in fact than at any time since the outbreak of war. The whole question of the marketing of the Canadian wheat and flour is now engaging the attention of the Government. It is a difficult problem, however, in view of the present world wide conditions. Apparently matters can only adjust themselves.
It will be seen that this letter suggests no way out of the difficulty, and I would like to know if it is not possible for the Govern-men to assist the section of the country referred to in this respect.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I do not know just what form the assistance could take. 1 am not personally familiar with the circumstances of the case to which the hon. gentleman alludes, and I would suggest that he taka it up with the Acting Minister of Trade and Commerce, in whose department the transportation and marketing of grain lies. I can assure the hon. gentleman, however, that if'the grain cannot be marketed, there must be some particular reason affecting it, because grain is being sold almost every day to the United Kingdom, to France, and to neutral countries in Europe just as rapidly as tonnage is available. It may be that there is no person in the district to buy the grain, or no cars available for its shipment, or something of that kind. If the ordinary machinery exists I cannot understand why it cannot find a market. I would suggest to the hon. member that he place all the facts before the Acting Minister of Trade and Commerce and let him have inquiry made into the matter by the proper officials in his department.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I might add for the information of the minister that the letter is signed by the Deputy Minister of Trade and

Commerce, and again call his attention to the concluding sentence:	.
Apparently matters can only adjust themselves.
It leaves the matter in a most dubious position-that is to say, the department can render these parties no assistance.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I would suggest that the hon. gentleman take the matter up with the Acting Minister of Trade and Commerce.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
The letter came from that department.
'Mr. CRERAR: Yes, but it is written by the deputy.
Item 53, a vote of $25,000 for the administration and carrying out of the provisions of the Agricultural Instruction Act, will stand with the permission of the Committee, and afford opportunity, for discussion to other members of the House who are not able to be present this evening.
Pensions, European War and Active Militia-

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Does the minister (Mr. Rowell) not think it is rather late to bring up such an important question, when the attendance is so slim as it is now, a question in which the whole country is interested? I certainly think it is, if the minister is to make a statement of the Government's policy in regard to pensions.
Hon. NEWTON W. ROWELL (President of the Council): If this were a statement of the Government's policy I would at once concur in my hon. friend's suggestion. But the policy of the Government with regard to pensions, as well as the policy of the Pensions Committee, will come up for consideration when the Pensions Committee's Report is presented, which report I think will be in shape for presentation next week. The Pensions Committee has practically completed its work, and its report will then come up together with a Bill which the committee is drafting for submission to the House. All questions of policy will come up for review when the Bill is being considered. This is simply a vote of the estimated amount required on the basis of the existing pension schedule. If the Pensions Committee recommends some increases, as will likely be the case, that will involve a supplementary estimate being brought down; the whole question will come up for very full consideration when we have the committee's report before us, and the Pensions Bill which will have to be considered section by section. I thought, therefore, I would make simply a very brief statement, [Air. Pedlow.]
giving an outline of the present position of affairs. This item might then be permitted to pass, and we could discuss the whole question of policy when we come to deal with the report of the Pensions Committee.
This is simply an estimate based on a certain number of estimated pensioners- taking the figures for last year, plus the estimated number of pensions for the coming year. The total casualties in the Canadian Expeditionary Force .up to 8th of May of the present year, were 212,182. Of that number there were either killed or died of wounds or disease 63,347, and the total number of wounded was 148,835. That gives us the total possible pension claims up to date, and very few could subsequently arise; of course, some further claims may be presented before demobilization is completed. Taking first the killed, that is 63,347, it is estimated that no pension will be applied for in the case of approximately fifteen per cent of that number. That is there will be fifteen per cent with no dependents who would be entitled to claim any pension, and the Pension Board estimates that the total number of pensions which will probably be granted in respect of men killed in action or that have died of wounds will be 53,854-at least that is the total number in respect of which claim might be made to come within the provisions of the pension regulations. Now, so far 22,612 of these cases have come up for consideration by the Pensions Board, which is not quite one-half of the possible pension claimants in the case of those killed. Of the 22,612 claims which have come up for consideration and been dealt with, 16,959 have been allowed, and 5,653 have been refused on the ground that they did not come within the provisions of the pension regulations. That leaves 31,233 yet to be dealt with if claims are presented, and if they are disposed of on the same basis. In other words, if the percentage of claims that should be allowed is the same in the future as in the past, experience has shown it would come to 23,425 more pensions to be allowed in respect of those who have been killed in action or who have died of wounds. With that as a basis the Board of Pension Commissioners is able to estimate the total amount payable to dependents of those killed in action or who have died of wounds, and it is on that basis that that part of the present estimate is made up.
Then, take the case of disabilities. I gave the total number of wounded as 148,835. A number were wounded more than once and

returned to the firing line. It is impossible, of course, until all claims are in, to ascertain accurately how many have been wounded more than once. But for the purpose of this estimate the Board of Pensions Commissioners have put down the number at five per cent of the total, or 7,441, leaving 141,394 as the number of cases or disabilities for which claims might possibly he made. Of these, 71,834, about fifty per cent, have already been dealt with, and of the 71,834, 53,876 have been allowed and 17,958 disallowed, as not coming within the provisions of the pension regulations. If the remaining applications or possible applications are disposed of on the same basis, we would have 52,170 additional pensioners on the ground of disability. This estimate is based on the assumption that we shall have that additional number and that the average amount payable in case of disability will be the same in the new cases as in the cases already allowed. On that basis, the total estimated Pension Bill of the Dominion when all cases are disposed of will be $32,814,391, assuming that no increase is made in our pension schedule and that no change is made in the regulations so as to bring in cases that are now excluded. Of that amount, it is estimated that we shall require this year the amount mentioned in the Estimate. As a number of men have not been discharged from the army and the right to pension has not yet arisen, the full amount will not be required this year; it is estimated that $28,000,000 will cover the pension bill for this year on the basis of the present schedule of disabilities. If the Pension Committee recommends and the House concurs in some increase in the pension schedules, a Supplementary Estimate will be brought down to cover that estimated increase. That, in brief, is the basis of the expenditure under this vote of $28,000,000. If any further information is desired I shall be glad to give it as we proceed.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: All who have appeared in the casualty lists.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: But many of them may not be claims?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I, of course, have no personal knowledge of this case. It is the Pensions Board that deals with all these matters, and the Board is the final authority in connection with them under regulations passed by this House. I understand, however, that the Pension Board states that the facts are somewhat as follows: That on 4th October the case came to the attention of the Board of Pension Commissioners and that on the fifth of October Mr. Taylor was examined and recommended for treatment, and he was granted treatment under the Soldiers' Civil Re-establishment on the 7th October. For reasons which probably Mr. Taylor considered sufficient but which were not explained, he discontinued the treatment of his own volition within a few days after he was recommended for it. I should point out to the committee that those receiving treatment are on pay and allowance during the whole period of the treatment, and if a man is married his wife gets a sum similar to the separation allowance. It is quite true, as the hon. member has suggested, that there was some mistake in notifying the Pensions Board by the Soldiers' Civil Re-establishment, and his pension was not resumed as it should have been when he discontinued the treatment. According to the regulations while a man is receiving treatment, if he is a pensioner, he draws pay and allowance paid by the Soldiers' Civil Re-establishment and his pension is discontinued. When he ceases treatment, his pension is resumed, and under the conditions there was a holding over of the pensiofi and the man has in that sense a

grievance and ground for complaint because of the mistake made in reference to notification to the Board of Pension Commissioners. I understand the situation is at present that he has been asked to go to Winnipeg for further examination, and if treatment is recommended, for treatment. Winnipeg is a neurological centre; they have there experts who can provide the treatment. The information which the Board of Pension Commissioners has is that this is a neurological case; and that treatment of that kind is necessary and that, if applied, will restore the man to health and should give him the use of his limbs, and, therefore, that man should, they think, go to Winnipeg to take the treatment. The expense to Winnipeg is paid, and if he takes the treatment he receives pay and allowance. That is the information I have received. I have, of course, no power to give the assurance for which tne hon. member asks. The Government has no such power under the regulations adopted which were considered wise at the time in order to prevent any question of politics interfering. The rules adopted, recommended by the Pension Committee, expressly provide that the decision of the Board of Pension Commissioners is final. There is no appeal to the Government and the Government has no right to override their decision. I will, however, personally look into this matter to see if there appears to be a grievance Or miscarriage of justice, with a view to urging the board to remedy any injury if one appears to have been inflicted. That is as far as I can go, because this is a case in which the decision of the board is final.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: For examination and, if treatment is recommended, for treatment.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
That is not what the man was informed because I happen to hold in my hand the letter written by the Pensions Board to the man, who sent it to me, and I will read it to the Committee. It is addressed to Mr. John Taylor, at his residence, and reads:
Dear Sir:

Will you kindly make it convenient to call at this office as soon as possible with a view to sending you to Winnipeg for a neurological examination? Transportation and expenses will 'be supplied to you.
No mention is made of treatment, and as the man had already been sent to Winnipeg for examination on two occasions, I think he was perfectly right in refusing to go a third time after, for a year, getting a pension of $5 a month.
As regards the man's having a grievance, I can assure the minister that I know just as much about these cases as most of the medical boards of this country, and more than some of them, according to this case; and this man has a grievance, and I intend to see that it is rectified.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: The complaint made by the hon. member for Fort William and Rainy River (Mr. Manion), and the reply of the minister, is an indication that it is not fair to put these estimates through to-night, because there may be other complaints. It is now nearly twelve o'clock, and we might very well adjourn.

speakerposition: Prime Minister; Secretary of State for External Affairs
subtopic: STATEMENT OF PRIME MINISTER ON LABOUR SITUATION IN TORONTO.
speechtext:
We spent nearly the whole day-from ten o'clock in the morning until seven o'clock in the evening -endeavouring to arrive at an arrangement which would compose the differences between the employees and employers, or, failing to arrive at an agreement, we strongly urged that the questions in difference should be submitted either to an investigation by a Royal Commission or to arbitration. There was an approach towards an agreement, but no agreement was finally

reached. A great many proposals on one side and the other were put forward, and the final result, about seven o'clock in the evening, was that the employers made a proposal in writing which, I think, was furnished to the press, and which was to be submitted by the representatives of the labour organizations to the men in Toronto. I believe it was so presented, but the men did not see fit to accept it. The chief question under discussion yesterday was the granting of a week of forty-four hours, and it was upon that question that the employers finally decided to offer arbitration. We endeavoured to have the offer accompanied with some other conditions which possibly might have made it more acceptable, but it was presented finally in the form which has been made public. I understand that a considerable number of men have gone out on strike in Toronto to-day.

speechtext:
On the motion of Hon. Mr. Meighen, Bill No. 104, to amend the Judges' Act was read a second time, and the House went into Committee on the Bill, Mr. Boivin in the Chair.
On section 1-One additional judge provided for in British Columbia:

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: Is it proposed to change the number of judges, or make a change in the salaries in British Columbia?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speakerposition: Minister of the Interior; Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs
speechtext: There is no change made in the salaries; the Bill provides for the addition of one judge to the County Court Bench of British Columbia.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: Not at all. They have even a larger jurisdiction than the judges of the Superior Court in Montreal, because in the rural districts these judges not only hear civil oases, but also cases which in that city are passed upon by the judges of the Circuit Court. They likewise hear the Criminal Court cases which in Montreal and Quebec are dealt with by the judges of the Court of King's Bench. We have no such courts as County Courts in our province.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Has the minister, since we last discussed the matter of judges' salaries, arrived at a decision to increase the salary of the county court judges of British Columbia which I think it was very fully demonstrated and agreed to on the former occasion, is altogether too small?
I think the Acting Minister of Justice at that time suggested that he expected the Minister of Justice would return to Canada in time to deal with the matter; but inasmuch as there seems to be no indication of the latter's return at present, I would ask the acting minister to give that phase of the question his consideration now that we have such a Bill before us as the present one and remedy what is, without any doubt, a grave injustice to those judges.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speakerposition: Minister of the Interior; Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs
speechtext:
What I stated on the occasion of the consideration of the resolution which preceded this Bill was as stated by the hon. gentleman. Since that time,

during much of which intervening period I have been absent, it transpires that the Minister of Justice will not probably be back for any substantial portion at least of this session. Consequently I feel that the responsibility is on me of making a recommendation on the subject *which the hon. gentleman has brought to my. attention. As to what the decision of the Government will be I could not now say, but I can inform the hon. gentleman that an * answer will be given him some day next week.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: In the discussion that took place a day or two ago in regard to the Civil Service, an hon. member laid down the rule-which seemed to be an excellent one-that if we had fewer officials and paid them better, good results would follow. Is that not a good rule to apply to the judges? L notice that, by legislation of Ontario, there is to be a considerable reduction in the number of County Court judges in that province. In this case we are proposing to increase the number of judges in British Columbia. I have not sufficient knowledge of British Columbia to offer an opinion in the matter, but it seems odd that at a time when Ontario is cutting down the number of its judges British Columbia finds it necessary to make an increase. I know the difficulty that arises owing to the jurisdiction of the provinces in the matter of the courts and the fact that the Dominion has to provide the judges and pay the bills. I know this is a layman's view and that laymen ought not to say much about these things; but there is a wide-spread opinion that the rule of having fewer officials and paying them better is a good one to apply to the judges as well as to other branches of the public service.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speakerposition: Minister of the Interior; Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs
speechtext: I am thoroughly in agreement with my hon. friend (Mr. Fielding), so much so that I addressed a communication to the attorneys general of all the provinces, British Columbia among the others, looking to provincial legislation for reduction in the provinces. A practical response has come from Ontario in very substantial reductions, indeed. This Bill, however, provides for the filling of a vacancy created by the Legislature of British Columbia. In the northern portion of the island of Vancouver a considerable settlement has grown up, particularly in the coalbearing regions, since the previous distribution of judges was made, which cannot be adequately served by the number of judges they now have.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: Do these judges in British Columbia receive also surrogate and other fees, as in Ontario, in order that their salary may be brought up to some kind of a living wage? '

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speakerposition: Minister of the Interior; Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs
speechtext: I am informed that such is not the case.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speakerposition: Minister of the Interior; Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs
speechtext: The cases to which the bon. member refers have been brought to my notice; indeed, they existed prior to my assuming the duties of Acting Minister of Justice. They were subsisting while the minister himself was here. I have not made a recommendation as to filling the vacancies; indeed, I have made no recommendation as to filling any judicial vacancy in Canada. It may be that concurrently with the consideration of the salary question, I shall have to give consideration also to filling these vacancies. The reason why I did not make a recommendation was this. I certainly was not convinced that the provincial Government, say of Saskatchewan, would not be able by a readjustment of judicial districts so to provide that the present bench could render efficient service. I addressed a letter accordingly to the Attorney General, but I have not been informed of any action having been taken. There is no doubt at all that the Attorney General of the province would be in a much better position than I to judge as to the feasibility of my suggestion. I fear that his attitude is unfavourable.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Has the department any intention of increasing the salaries of judges of the Superior Court of Quebec? This question has been mooted for a number of years, and the excuse always given was
the necessity of first adjusting the salaries of judges of the county courts of Ontario; and it was stated that when that was done the Government or the department intended to take up the question as regards Superior Court judges. Many of these judges are earning far less than civil servants and they are not able to keep up with the dignity of the position. In many instances they are barely able to make both ends meet, and that is not in accord with the positions they hold as they.should be far above all possibilty of want, because they have very serious duties to perform. I hope the minister has the question under consideration.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: As a layman representative from British Columbia, I wish to endorse heartily the suggestion that the salaries of the County Court and other judges be adequately increased. When we take into consideration the importance of the position which the judges occupy and the heavy responsibilities that rest on their shoulders, I think it is highly dangerous for us to allow these men to go on living from hand to mouth. I think their salaries should be so increased as to put them on a footing where they could hold their own in a social way.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I have just been reminded that it was in 1905 that substantial increases were made in the salaries of the judges. I was in the House then, but I really forget whether the judges of the Supreme Court of Canada received an increase at that time. I have been informed that they did not. I think it is only fair that the minister should bear these judges in mind when dealing with salary increases.

I understand that the minister is considering their case, and I should like to ask whether action will be taken by the Government to put these judges on the same basis as judges in other provinces doing the same work.

In Manitoba, they rely
on Royal Commissions.

Maclean) and the Acting Minister of Justice are sitting together, and I would point out that there is a vacancy in the judiciary of district No. 6 in the province of Nova Scotia, the County Court judge having died a good many months ago. This is a large district with a good deal of work and the judge from Pictou, I think, has had to be recalled to this district. As this appointment must be made, I think the sooner it is made the better.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Can the minister give
the Committee any sort of horoscope as to
the future development of agriculture in this country, especially as regards a greater interest in farming and a desire for increased production? Does he find on the part of the people a tendency to stay on the farms or are they drifting away?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I was pleased to get this information from the hon. minister. .We have no opportunity in the House of hearing any opinions from the Minister of Agriculture except when he comes with his Estimates, and I have always felt, as I feel now, that the prominence is not given in this House to the Agricultural Department that it is entitled to and should always have had. I put my questions not with any intention of embarrassing the minister but merely to give him an opportunity of dealing with his department and
4 p.m. giving the people to understand that its importance is duly recognized. When we have any questions be fore us in connection with agriculture and farmers generally we are dealing with a large and important subject which is at the very foundation of the prosperity of the country, and the more prominence we give to agriculture and the more attention it receives at our hands, the more readily will the farmer or the man who intends going on the farm be impressed with the importance of rural life and the fact that he is engaging in an industry which the members of this House realize as vital to the prosperity of the nation. This was my object in drawing out the minister as to what has been done and the prospects of agricultural life in Canada for the years to come.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I think the minister
understands the necessity for greater and more scientific agricultural production in the future. All the financial and economic authorities who have lately given their views as regards present conditions in Canada have insisted on the fact that what is needed is greater production The chief industry of Canada is above all farming. This is a great farming community and the more we can attract the people to

country life the more wo shall do in the way of restoring the country to a basis of sound economy and prosperity. There must be more production along scientific lines. Although I am not much over the fifty-year mark, there has been in my day and generation quite a change in the method of agriculture. I shall not speak for other sections of the country, but the section with which I am most familiar. Even in the constituency of Gaspe, where the people are fishermen and farmers simultaneously, I have noticed during the last twenty years a change for the better in agricultural methods. This, I am pleased to say, is due in a large degree to the very progressive education given our farmers by the Department of Agriculture in Quebec, and also, I must say, by the officials of the Department of Agriculture at Ottawa. I do not know how the other provinces regard the lectures given to farmers, but speaking for my constituency of Gaspe I can say that the people are always pleased to meet the lecturers sent by .the Department of Agriculture and that they quietly, without any great demonstration, adopt the methods suggested by the lecturers. In addition to this, the small experimental farms, not to speak of the largest, have produced the best results. If there is one expenditure to which the minister should commit himself more in the future, it is for the multiplication of these small farms.
I have in my mind especially the recommendations made by Professor Robertson in the report of the Commission on Technical Education. These latter recommendations have been published in pamphlet form and I have found them very instructive indeed. If I had any advice to offer my hon. friend it would be to try and live up to the recommendations made by Professor Robertson. I must compliment the Department of Agriculture in Ottawa upon having given to the district to which I belong politically-the district of Quebec- the magnificent experimental farm located in the constituency of my hon. friend from Kamouraska (Mr. Lapointe). The agricultural school at St. Anne de la Pocatiere is a Quebec institution and a very progressive one, but, since its establishment at the request of my hon. friend from Kamouraska, the Government has supplemented the work of that school by the establishment of an experimental farm and, following the establishment of the farm, there have been exhibitions every year which would be of interest even to the farmers of the other provinces of Canada.

While I am in a laudatory mood, might I not congratulate sincerely the Minister of Agriculture upon the appointment which he has made of the Deputy Minister of Agriculture. I must be frank, sincere and honest in my appreciation of the good work accomplished by the Department of Agriculture. The farmers who sit in this House and the farmers in the country-at least the farmers in our part of the country- appreciate the great work which was done some years ago by the Hon. Sydney Fisher. He changed completely the complexion of the department and gave to it a very high standing in the country. The Minister of Agriculture (Mr. Crerar) enjoys to a large degree the confidence of the public because, as we know, he is a farmer and he is proud of it. In the appointment of his officials he has done the right thing in making them without regard to political considerations. He has appointed Mr. Grisdale and I have noticed that in the press and on both sides of politics that appointment has been hailed as a progressive step. Mr. Grisdale has had a long experience. He is known throughout Canada. He is a modest, humble official but stern and sturdy in the discharge of his official duties. He has another great advantage which we cannot ignore. He speaks both languages fluently. How can you expect to reach the different farming communities in the different provinces if the officers of the department cannot be understood in the literature which they send out to every section of the country or in the lectures which they deliver to their farming audiences? By appointing Mr. Grisdale you have appointed the best officer in the department to a position which he will fill, we know, with great profit to the country. Besides, any farmer from my province can come to him, speak in his own language and be answered and understood as if he were speaking to one of his own fellow countrymen. I congratulate my hon. friend on this appointment. I hope that under Mr. Grisdale the department will continue the traditions established by the predecessor of my hon. friend the Hon. Sydney Fisher, who was really the friend of the farmer.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: Provided the tariff is no bar?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: Always provided, of course, that no unnatural barrier will be raised against our products.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I remember some years ago looking into the question of cheese importations by the United States. At that time, and I presume there are now, unless the war has changed the situation, tremendous importations into the republic to the South of what I think are called fancy cheeses-cheeses that come from Switzerland, Italy and other countries, and are somewhat different from the ordinary cheese. It struck me at that time that there was a tremendous field for Canadian en-
EMr. Crerar.]
deavour in the manufacture and exportation to the American market of fancy cheeses, and I would like to know whether the Government has looked into this matter, and what steps, if any, it has taken to encourage the production of fancy cheeses in Canada.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: That matter has been receiving the attention of the department. I am not much of a connoisseur in cheese, if I might apply the term to that article, but I may say that we are making, for instance, at the Central Experimental Farm in this city, one of the best fancy cheeses produced in America. The cheeses to which the hon. gentleman alludes are imported from Europe; some people have a fancy for eating Swiss, Dutch, or Canadian cheese, as the case may be. Personally, I have never been able to see very much difference between them.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: The alleged reason was the existence of pleuro-pneumonia in Canadian herds. The evidence was supposed to rest upon the case of one particular animal that was said to have had the disease when it landed at Liverpool. It is very clear, however, that the disease did not exist in Canada. Nevertheless, an embargo was placed upon Canadian cattle, and it has remained in force ever since, despite the efforts that have been made to have it removed. I am not familiar with the steps that were taken to this end by the Government of the late Sir Wilfrid Laurier-

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Mr. Alexander was chairman, and I understood Mr. Ballantyne was on the committee in an advisory capacity. But it makes no difference. These gentlemen, taking advantage of what they knew was going to happen, wired to their agents in Western Canada and bought up all the butter held by the factories in Manitoba and Saskatchewan, and partly in Alberta, before the advance in price. Immediately in the United States prices began to go up. Milk and cream were on the free list, and the farmers along the international line and quite a distance away from the line discovered that they could sell their milk in the United States at $3.55 on a 3 per cent butter-fat basis, which worked out at .about $4.05 for extra good milk per 100 pounds. As against that, the price at which it was commandeered in Canada would give them from $1.75 to $2.05 and very naturally the flow of milk started to the United States. When the Government discovered this they placed an embargo on milk and cream, going into the United States, so that .this condition obtained for the month of October and part of November, and if I mistake not it was February before the embargo was totally raised. My friends from the western provinces who year in and year out have told us of the greater prices that have prevailed in the	Minneapolis market for wheat
can	very well	understand how the
eastern dairyman felt when he discovered that his neighbour across the line was receiving from $1 to $1.50 per 100 pounds more for milk than he was. When the farmer discovered that he could not ship his milk or cream owing to the embargo he decided to sell his cow, and that largely explains the great increase in the exports in cattle into the United States from all parts of Canada, and explains also why the cities to-day are suffering, or at any rate did suffer all winter.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: Does the hon. member mean to say that milk .sold for $4 per 100 pounds?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
In reply to the hon. member, I may say that there is no country which has been engaged in the war during the last three or four years in which fewer restrictions have been imposed on the people than in Canada. In respect of the restrictions on the exportation of milk and other products to the United States, what was the situation that existed in August last, at a time when the struggle between the German armies and the Allies had reached its greatest intensity in Europe? The British people were practically face to face with a situation where butter could not be secured, and their rations were down to half an ounce per person per week. They requested the food Administrations of the United States and Canada to take some action that would relieve them in this respect. It was essential that the morale of the British and French people should be kept at its highest possible point at that time, and as a result cf their request the United States Food Administration commandeered outright, if my memory is correct, 60 per cent of the butter supplies then in cold storage in the United States. Coupled with this question is also the matter of the price of the article at home. The United States commandeered supplies in stock without limitations as to prices, and the result was that within a few weeks, due to the withdrawal from consumption of

this large quantity of butter, prices in the United States rapidly rose until they advanced some 12 to 18 cents per pound over what they had previously been.
Mr. MoMASTER:	The hon. member for
Chateauguay-Huntingdon (Mr. Robb) stated that this butter that was commandeered by the American Government did not get across, or at least not all of it.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Between five and six
million pounds according to my memory. I have not the figures here and it is some months since I looked at them.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
lls it not true that, as a
result of commandeering the products of the prairie factories, about 1,000,000 pounds of butter came in from New Zealand, and did not the farmers of Western Canada put
up a big howl to the minister because they had lost the British Columbia market?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I am sorry to say that 1 have not any definite information on the point, but I am advised that the exports have been very slight. Recently, I believe, there have been some shipments to the United States on account of the higher prices prevailing there.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: I saw it reported in the newspapers that a large quantity of Canadian butter was exported to the United States and that it accounted for the commodity being so dear in Canada.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I noticed the same report in the newspapers, and I believe it is correct that within the last few weeks several carloads of butter have gone to the United

States. I fancy that condition will be readjusted now that the local supplies there are being increased and marketed.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: Give him a knighthood.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
One of the most important things in connection with farming is the selection of good, clean seed. The sowing of seed which contains wild seeds not only curtails the amount of the grain produced, but leaves the land in a wild state and gives rise to much additional work and trouble for years to come. As the machinery for properly cleaning grain costs a good deal of money, it is beyond the reach of the average farmer. It is up to the minister, therefore, to see that the people of Ontario are provided with an elevator at some convenient place, where they may store their grain and have it re-cl6aned and dried if necessary. I think I am not going beyond the truth when I say that had we had an elevator in some convenient place in Ontario last year half of its cost would have been made up by the saving of the beans that were lost in that province because of the lack of facilities for properly cleaning them. In the eastern part of the province the condition is not so bad, because Montreal is within easy reach. But the farmers lost three or four cents a bushel on the grain shipped by rail from Toronto to Montreal; it was inspected when it arrived there and they had to take what they could get for it. i am not much in favour of every-

thing going to the large centres, but if this grain could be re-cleaned properly, say at Toronto, where there are good railway facilities, and if there was proper elevator accommodation, with all the necessary machinery for cleaning, thousands of dollars would be saved for the people of Ontario. Some years ago much seed wheat was shipped out of Ontario to Western Canada. A good deal of that wheat was not properly cleaned and was not in proper condition when it was sent out. During the past winter thousands of bushels of oats have been shipped from Ontario to Western Canada for seed. The farmers received from sixty to seventy cents a bushel for those oats, whereas if the oats had been cleaned they could have got from seventy-five to eighty cents a bushel. The farmers were losing from five to ten cents a bushel on those oats, because cleaning would cost only a few cents a bushel. The Government has received deputations asking that an elevator be established in some convenient place in Ontario, and I hope the minister will see that we have one built for the convenience and benefit of the farmers. I believe the outlay would be paid for almost every year.

Well, demonstration
stations, but the distinction between demonstrating and illustrating how to do a thing is a distinction without very much difference. Why not make a demonstration station of the farm on which this gentleman does his experimental work and give him, for conducting this experimental or demonstration station, some adequate remuneration which will enable him, without thought for the morrow as regards his own personal fortune, to pursue his own experiments which, I understand from hon. members from the West, have been of material advantage to our country?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I have a suggestion to make to the minister, and one that I

have thought of more than once, in connection with the great wheat industry of Canada. I believe we can grow and mature a brand of wheat in the Yukon which would he of great value to the wheat growers on our western plains. It may be news to some hon. gentlemen to know that we do grow wheat in t'he Yukon.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: It is just as golden and worth a little more than that grown on the plains.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
What does it cost to
grow a bushel of wheat in the Yukon?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
That suggestion has
already been acted upon. We have in the Yukon a small' experimental station that is maintained at a cost of slightly under $2,000 a year, and I am informed that we are already experimenting at that station with three or four different varieties of
iMr. A. Thompson.]
wheat to see if we can produce the splendid results which my hon. friend anticipates, and which I hope will be realized.
In regard to the suggestion that we should bonus grist mills in New Brunswick, I am afraid that would be of doubtful value, and I frankly state I do not think the suggestion will be acted upon. If any special assistance is required for this industry in New Brunswick I think it should be contributed by the people who are immediately to benefit from it. The grist mills of New Brunswick could not in any sense be considered a national enterprise. 1 have certain views on the virtues of the bonus principle generally, but I shall not trouble the Committee with them now.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
I think the first few
items here might pass, but there are some things that hon. members wish to say on other phases of the very prolific and important subject we have been discussing. Perhaps the minister might agree to leave such matters as live stock commissioners and directors of experimental farms.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
In 1913 or about that
time, when the hon. Secretary of 'State (Mr. Burrell) was Minister of Agriculture, we used to discuss the advisability of establishing not altogether demonstration farms but small farms for the development of agriculture. The idea was that some of the $10,000,000 set apart for the development of the industry could be utilized in 'buying small farms in the neighbourhood of industrial centres, say, for instance, near the steel works in the county from which I come, where there are thousands of farmers' sons, and men from Ireland, England and Scotland who make marvellous developments of little bits of land about their houses. I-t was thought that if the Government could establish thirty or forty or even twenty small farms of between twenty-five and forty acres each, with house and barn, and give a small start in the way of developing these farms, and then sell them, men would be very anxious and willing to go in for the scheme. The idea has been developed in the West by the Canadian Pacific Railway. I understand they have built houses on certain sections of land; and they sell not only the bare land but the houses and barns and some equipment. In that way they have given a great boom to agriculture in that part of the country. We have in Nova Scotia millions of acres that are unoccupied, and it is not unusual to find a man owning four or five hundred acres and living on it with his wife, being able to scratch a bare living out of perhaps five per cent of the land. That land to which I refer could be used to great advantage if people could be found to take an interest in agriculture, and I am sure the Government would lose no money if they undertook this project. All they need is courage and enterprise, and they would find these little farms would be successful and would give a fresh impetus to agriculture. It was thought in the early days that the thing would be practicable, and there was some co-operation between the honourable gentleman (Mr. Burrell) and the Minister of Agriculture for Nova Scotia. Some start was made in the buying of old farms but the matter was not looked after properly and nothing of importance has really been done. What is absolutely e* sential for the development of the country is that it shall be a place in which the ordinary man can live in comfort, and the only way in which that can be achieved is to encourage the farmer to produce and enable him to sell at reasonable prices. The only advantage to the farmer is the profit he makes, and if he can make a large
profit it is better for the country. He may make a fair profit on a small quantity, but if he can make a proportionate profit on large quantities of produce there is a beneficial result all round. It is absolutely necessary for the Department of Agriculture to make a departure from the rut in which we have been moving for the last twenty-five years, and to show what can be done along these lines. I have no particular line to indicate to the minister, but I have suggested what might be done in the neighbourhood of large centres. I have spoken of Cape Breton because I know men there who are ready to take hold of these little farms if they are put within their reach. They have not the means themselves to buy lands and put up houses, but if they were helped up to that stage they would jump at the proposition. The market is there and they could sell their produce, and there are young men from the Old Country who are enterprising enough to do very well if they were given a start. Another thing I might point out is the desirability of encouraging the extension of tram cars that are in touch with agricultural land so as to encourage the farmer. Companies might be encouraged to push their lines into the country. These things cost money, but the minister in charge of the department must have courage to depart from the old line and not hesitate to spend money abundantly so long as good results can be obtained. We want to make 'Canada produce something proportionate to its capacity for production.
Mr. iLEiMIEUX: In connection with the distribution of literature, I have noticed that literature is printed in both languages and when any one applies to the department he can get either French or English copies. I want to inform the minister-and this can be confirmed by the deputy minister-that the best agent of the department in my province is the cure, who is generally the honorary president and sometimes the secretary of what we call the Circles Agricoles. There is one in every county, and sometimes one in every parish, and in the pulpit on nearly every 'Sunday of the year in these rural districts the cure will spend a portion of his time speaking to the farmers on agricultural matters.
I would like my hon. friend to send the literature which is issued by the department in French-not all, but the most essential bulletins-to the cures of the province of Quebec, so as to secure their devotion to the cause. Because the great issue of the day is the necessity of getting our

people back to the land and improving living conditions in the rural districts. I have offered these remarks now because unfortunately, I shall not be able to be present this evening.
Mr. 'CRERAR:	I can say to the hon.
gentleman that the suggestion which he has made will be acted upon.
At six o'clock the House resumed and took recess.
After Kecess.
The House resumed at eight o'clock.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: Does the minister think that it will be necessary to have this extra amount this year? Does he think it is a good time to increase the expenditure? I am sorry to note that every minister is making increased expenditures; I had hoped that the democratic Minister of Agriculture would cut down expenditures, not increase them. I note also that no minister is able to explain these increased expenditures. It simply is " an item we may need some time in the future"; or it is explained that " we are making provision for something we practically do not know anything about, but we want to have enough in our estimates; in other words, we want to keep up with the other twenty or so ministers; we 'want to increase our expenditures regardless of whether we need the money or not." They seem to have the idea that the country is looking for increased expenditures-for full steam ahead without regard to where the money is coming from. The minister should explain to the Committee just what he thinks of the whole system of the Department of Agriculture as at present constituted, particularly of this Central Experimental . Farm and the other

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: Order. The hon. gentleman is entering upon a subject which was discussed very fully on the Civil Government Estimates this afternoon when he was absent. I certainly cannot allow a repetition of the same arguments to-night.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
We are considering an item of $1,200,000 for experimental farms, and I wish to ask the minister if he believes that the present system of experimental farms is the best method of bringing about the better use of seeds, the raising of better stock, and so on. This farm at Spirit Lake is in my constituency, in the far north. There is another farm at Kapuskasing, only a few miles away; one is in Quebec and the other is in Ontario. Something like $80,000 a year is being spent on these farms-an extraordinarily large amount. Moreover, the expenditure on the Experimental Farm at Ottawa seems to be entirely out of proportion to the results that are being obtained. The minister tells us that they developed a kind of wheat there some years ago. The older members of the House tell me, however, that that argument has been practically worked to death here; that seems to be the only explanation each year for increasing the expenditure. Does the minister not think that a better system might be worked out by distributing smaller farms throughout the country and doing the



work on a purely business basis in the different provinces? These large farms in Ottawa and at other points are purely experimental farms. A demonstration farm is quite different from an experimental farm. A demonstration farm would show the farmers in the community how to improve their seed, their stock, and their conditions generally; the experimental farm would seem to make experiments from which the independent farmer can obtain no profit. Does not the minister think that this money could be more profitably expended on demonstration farms?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Had the hon. member been here this afternoon he would have obtained at least the greater part of the information he now seeks. In every country that is making any effort to secure sound agricultural development, experimental farms and stations and demonstration stations are maintained.
As to the increase which the hon. member criticises, the matter resolves itself simply into this, that if we are to pay the increased cost of operation, such as the increase in wages and the higher cost of material, due to causes over which the Department of Agriculture has no control, then, if we are to keep the vote at the same amount as last year, we shall have to cut down the efficiency of the farms, and that would not be a wise move nor justified in any way. The development of agriculture in every country in the world is becoming more and more dependent upon the application of sound, scientific methods, not only in respect to methods of cultivation as to cereals, fruits and vegetables, but in the field of animal husbandry, which is of immense importance. For instance, as was pointed out this afternoon, the beef animals produced in Canada are inferior to those produced in the Argentine and in the United States. Experiments which are being carried on at several stations and farms, demonstrate conclusively the advantages of producing higher class animals at practically the same or even slightly lower cost than inferior animals. Those facts are published, and they are also made known to those who visit the farms and personally acquaint themselves with the experiments that are being carried on. We have passed the time when the utility and advantages of experimental farms and stations can be successfully challenged. It is, perhaps, an open question as to what is the best method of carrying on the work. I said .this afternoon, and I will repeat it 
now for the information of the hon. member, that from the information we are gathering it seems that the establishment of illustration farms will probably prove the most effective method of bringing the farmers closely and directly in touch with the advantages of the work that is being carried on-.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: What is the difference in the weights of cattle from range country and from Eastern Canada? Where do the ranchers procure the information that a certain class of cattle is better than others? For instance, are there any herds at the Ottawa Experimental Farm? What are. the heavier cattle and what are the classes that are best suited to the different sections of Canada for beef and other purposes?

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
The department does not
carry on any experiments on ranching farm scale, that is, where cattle run out on ranges. The experiments are conducted for instance, with dairy cattle as to what is the best type, the advantages that come from certain strains of breeding, in milk production and in the butter-fat quality of the cream that is produced. Feeding experiments in cattle have been carried out not only at the Central Experimental Farm but at branch farms, to determine what profit there is to the individual carrying on work along the same line, and some very interesting results have been found. I am safe in saying that hundreds of thousands of bulletins dealing with these various matters are distributed free to the farmers, and the increasing interest in the work is manifested by the large number of additional inquiries that are coming in all the time for this information.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext:
Certainly, the whole
thing is designed to help the stock raiser. He has the advantage of coming to the farm-as stock raisers do in large numbers -to see for himself the result of the work carried on. In addition the results of these experiments are published in pamphlet form and distributed to thousands and thousands of stock raisers throughout Canada. These pamphlets give a description of the experiments and their actual results.

speechtext:

speechtext: We have a general appropriation for the establishment of new farms. We shall not, I am afraid, be able to. go very far this year in that direction. We have endeavoured to strike a fair middle course and have included in our Estimates a sum that will, we hope, enable us to establish possibly a few new experimental stations during the year, and the point to which the hon. member alludes and which has already been brought to my notice will receive consideration.

speechtext:
Horw can we ascertain the policy of the Government with respect

to numerous matters that have arisen recently in the House? The ministers in charge of the Estimates are always unable to inform us in regard to the general policy of the Government. The Government seems to be largely a Government of individuals, each with his own particular department in mind and unable to say just how far that department may go. This matter of cold storage is one of the most serious questions that confront the Canadian people to-day, and the Government should have a policy with regard to it. The press would lead us to believe that the people controlling the packing and cold storage plants have been making exorbitant profits. Ministers of the Government have defended the character and business ability of some of the gentlemen who have made these exorbitant profits. Conditions in Canada to-day are not satisfactory to the labouring people; they have the impression that the cold storage plants are getting too much out of the producers and the consumers. Probably twenty-five to thirty-three and a third per cent of Canada's produce is wasted for the want of proper storage facilities. The erection of a plant at Montreal wdll not relieve the situation in all other parts of the country. The erection of cold storage plants in the United States or in European countries seems to be a simple matter. Having regard to our long shipping distances and to the general conditions in this country, it would be good business for the Government to find out what it would cost to build plants so that they may be able to give that information to the towns and cities of Canada. A cold storage plant is just as important as the hen-coop or pig-sty. If it is necessary to take the duty off certain articles to promote a policy of this kind the Government can do it, just as they took the duty off farm tractors. The Government should reduce the high cost of living by providing better cold storage facilities and by making the profiteers dispose of their food products before they are allowed to rot. The minister says he has no power to do these things. Why, with the War-time Elections Act and all the other various Acts which have vested power in the Government they are able to do anything. All it requires is courage, and if my hon. friend would show some courage in the direction of satisfying the common people, the poor people, the producers, rather than the profiteers, he would be in very much better grace in Canada than he is to-day. I hope that this matter will receive the serious consideration of the Minister and that he will
look into the storage problem as one of the most serious problems that Canada faces.

Source.Name: proceedings1919_05_30.csv
speechtext: My hon. friend is scarcely consistent; he has quite reversed the position he took a few moments ago, when he criticised very sharply an additional expenditure of $100,000 or so in a vote previously under discussion and urged that we should practice economy. In fact, he impressed me quite strongly by the earnestness of his appeal. Now he suggests that we embark on a policy that would involve the expenditure of millions. If the hon. gentleman wishes my opinion as to the policy that should be adopted-in fact, so far as announcement has been made or anything has been done it is the policy that has been adopted-it is the duty of the federal administration to provide the necessary facilities for the transportation of these products and for the care of them at ocean ports and, generally, to assist in the trade and commerce of the country. If the hon. gentleman has in mind the erection of cold storage plants in every city, town, and village in Canada, the proposition would be a very large one and might better be taken up by municipal enterprise. We have already decided on the policy of giving assistance by way of bonus to municipal cold storage plants. Any town in my hon. friend's constituency, any town or city in Canada, can say to the Government: We propose to erect a municipal cold storage plant and to make it available for the public-for merchants, farmers and all who want to use it; and the Government will upon certain conditions give assistance to the extent of thirty per cent of the cost of erecting such a plant. It would be well to test this policy out for a few years and see what results come from it, rather than to embark on an expenditure that might run into millions.
